headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome to the Netflix Q4 2015 Earnings Call. I'm David Wells, CFO. I'm joined on my right by Reed Hastings, our CEO; and Ted Sarandos, our Chief Content Officer. Interviewing us today will be Peter Kafka from Re/code and Ben Swinburne from Morgan Stanley
componenttext: Welcome to the Netflix Q4 2015 Earnings Call. I'm David Wells, CFO. I'm joined on my right by Reed Hastings, our CEO; and Ted Sarandos, our Chief Content Officer. Interviewing us today will be Peter Kafka from Re/code and Ben Swinburne from Morgan Stanley. And just a reminder, a cautionary statement that we will be making forward-looking statements and actual results may vary. Over to the first interview question.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll start out maybe for Reed and the team with can you reflect on the fourth quarter results for us that we're all going through right now? In particular, talk the about international strength. You mentioned you were pleased with October -- September, Oc
componenttext: I'll start out maybe for Reed and the team with can you reflect on the fourth quarter results for us that we're all going through right now? In particular, talk the about international strength. You mentioned you were pleased with October -- September, October launches. So can we infer the outperformance was the expectations versus expectations came from those areas? any color you can give us on the international strength, to start us off?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: We've got over 50 countries in Q4, so we have a lot of experience, Ben, predicting these markets. And then we launched in Japan in early September and Spain, Portugal and Italy mid-October. And I'd say they've gone very well, as we said in the letter. In
componenttext: We've got over 50 countries in Q4, so we have a lot of experience, Ben, predicting these markets. And then we launched in Japan in early September and Spain, Portugal and Italy mid-October. And I'd say they've gone very well, as we said in the letter. In terms of the outperformance, it is pretty broad-based, many different contributors around the world to that. What we're seeing basically is this on-demand Internet TV, watch wherever and whenever you want, it's very popular, wherever you go in the world.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just thinking that question over the U.S. for you or also maybe for David, a little bit lighter this quarter than your guidance or budget. Talk to us a little bit about the churn, connects, dynamic and anything you'd want to add around credit card chi
componenttext: And just thinking that question over the U.S. for you or also maybe for David, a little bit lighter this quarter than your guidance or budget. Talk to us a little bit about the churn, connects, dynamic and anything you'd want to add around credit card chipsets or any other issues you want to bring out around Q4 performance in the U.S.?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well Q4, I would say was pretty close to our projections. We were literally within hours of it, but -- so we did anticipate that net additions would be lighter year-on-year. I would say that credit card was a background issue in Q3, continues to be a back
componenttext: Well Q4, I would say was pretty close to our projections. We were literally within hours of it, but -- so we did anticipate that net additions would be lighter year-on-year. I would say that credit card was a background issue in Q3, continues to be a background issue. But the larger thing is that it's just the next 50 million or a little harder than the first 50 million in terms of growth. And we're doing everything in the content side, on the product side. We're continuing to improve that service. But you're seeing the law of large numbers. When you grow steady at 5 million, 6 million net additions a year on the larger number, then that percentage growth is smaller year-over-year. And that's what we predicted, and that's what you see in our guide for Q1 as well.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, guys. Last quarter, you said the credit card issue was an background issue. this quarter, you say it's a background issue. How long do you anticipate this is going to a problem for you? Additionally, do you have any sense of why you're the only major
componenttext: Hey, guys. Last quarter, you said the credit card issue was an background issue. this quarter, you say it's a background issue. How long do you anticipate this is going to a problem for you? Additionally, do you have any sense of why you're the only major consumer company that's called this out as a problem?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I don't think we're -- Peter, this is David. I don't think that we're the only one. I think because we're recurring merchant, anywhere from 5 to 10 basis points, 15 basis points is sensitive to us. We have optimized. We spend a lot of time optimizin
componenttext: Well, I don't think we're -- Peter, this is David. I don't think that we're the only one. I think because we're recurring merchant, anywhere from 5 to 10 basis points, 15 basis points is sensitive to us. We have optimized. We spend a lot of time optimizing our recruiting, billing systems and our approach. And so we're very sensitive to it. Again, it's small thing. I think we want to focus on the larger things and not the small things. And we anticipate that the EMV rollout will continue into 2016 into Q1 and Q2. And we'll always have, even globally, these issues where there's mass reissues of things and disruptions in the operating systems that we have.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: So this small thing category, but last quarter, you added iOS sign-ups. Any impact, surprising one way or another from that?
componenttext: So this small thing category, but last quarter, you added iOS sign-ups. Any impact, surprising one way or another from that?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: We've always been able -- customers can always been able to sign up on iOS, but they had to do it in the mobile web Safari browser. And now they can do it in app, and it's a positive. It's not transformational, but it's really nice positive. And in partic
componenttext: We've always been able -- customers can always been able to sign up on iOS, but they had to do it in the mobile web Safari browser. And now they can do it in app, and it's a positive. It's not transformational, but it's really nice positive. And in particular, in new markets as we expand around the world where we're less known and less trusteed, the comfort for customers in terms of using the Apple payment mechanism versus entering their international credit card information is helpful. So think of it as one more in our long list of great payment options that have.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Reed, I want to go back to the outlook in the Q1 guidance in particular, starting with international. You mentioned in the the letter that 2016 markets are -- you're playing the long game here, but the guidance is obviously impressive and well above expec
componenttext: Reed, I want to go back to the outlook in the Q1 guidance in particular, starting with international. You mentioned in the the letter that 2016 markets are -- you're playing the long game here, but the guidance is obviously impressive and well above expectations. So it's some -- are the 2016 launches a big contributor to what you're expecting in Q1 and sort of for the year internationally? Or is this continued momentum building on the exiting markets? Any color you can share there?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's a lot of both. I mean obviously, our global guides for over 6 million net additions will be a record for Netflix. And so we're super excited about that. And what's amazing is some of our new shows like Making a Murderer not only will be huge her
componenttext: Yes, it's a lot of both. I mean obviously, our global guides for over 6 million net additions will be a record for Netflix. And so we're super excited about that. And what's amazing is some of our new shows like Making a Murderer not only will be huge here in the U.S., but it's emerging as a big hit around the world for us. And you kind of expect Jessica jones to carry internationally. And what's been phenomenal about Ted's team programming is that this more unusual content titles have also great draw around the world.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And maybe let me just ask the U.S  just us to pick up on David's question about the next 50 million. What are you doing as a management team, maybe to Ted on the content side? What is your research telling you about the people who actually actual don't ha
componenttext: And maybe let me just ask the U.S  just us to pick up on David's question about the next 50 million. What are you doing as a management team, maybe to Ted on the content side? What is your research telling you about the people who actually actual don't have Netflix today? what -- is there some genre that's not being addressed well enough? Is there a distribution decision you guys need to make to go after that? What are you doing to maybe go after that other opportunity in the U.S. market?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, David's a big thinker, so he's thinking about the next 50 million. I'll stick with the first 5 million. And where we can clearly see the next 5 million, it's I've been hearing a lot about it, but nothing yet has compelled me to join. And so the big
componenttext: Well, David's a big thinker, so he's thinking about the next 50 million. I'll stick with the first 5 million. And where we can clearly see the next 5 million, it's I've been hearing a lot about it, but nothing yet has compelled me to join. And so the big driver is getting people excited about whatever title we have and then making it easy for them to join. So whether it's integrating in smart TV or integrated into the desktop MVPD set top or the Apple TV, those are the things that make it easy to fulfill the desire. But the underlying desire is for these new titles, which is why we're so excited about the year coming and content that Ted's team put together. So maybe talk about the big hallmarks we have in the next few months.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean just upcoming in this quarter, you're going to see -- we were pleasantly surprised by how excited the world is over Fuller House. So this upcoming U.S., different kinds of programming for the next 50 million or 5 million, depending on your lev
componenttext: Yes, I mean just upcoming in this quarter, you're going to see -- we were pleasantly surprised by how excited the world is over Fuller House. So this upcoming U.S., different kinds of programming for the next 50 million or 5 million, depending on your level of aggression that you're getting more and more mainstream and in some ways with programming. But it's a function of breadth. It's a function of doing more for all tastes. So opening that up to include multicamera sitcoms like The Ranch, like Fuller House. have also had great single-camera sitcom with called Flake, and the 4 seasons of House of Cards. So you've all of this kind of breadth. Just in a single quarter, we're releasing more programming than most networks will in a whole year.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: That being pleasantly surprised that shows that are not necessarily all in English are being embraced by U.S. audiences. It's 1's of those things that is rolling around in Hollywood for a long time with U.S  folks don't watch subtitles.
componenttext: That being pleasantly surprised that shows that are not necessarily all in English are being embraced by U.S. audiences. It's 1's of those things that is rolling around in Hollywood for a long time with U.S  folks don't watch subtitles.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: The continued success of in the U.S. where you have this primarily Spanish language show that's being watched in enormously mainstream numbers in the U.S.
componenttext: The continued success of in the U.S. where you have this primarily Spanish language show that's being watched in enormously mainstream numbers in the U.S.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: As for Reed and Ted, since last quarter, several of your suppliers, most specifically Time Warner and Fox, have been even more explicit about their desire to pull back the amount of content they sell to you. Does this cause you to accelerates your origina
componenttext: As for Reed and Ted, since last quarter, several of your suppliers, most specifically Time Warner and Fox, have been even more explicit about their desire to pull back the amount of content they sell to you. Does this cause you to accelerates your original programming? Or are you already in that same trajectory?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: We've been on the of trajectory of accelerating original programming. I mentioned a couple weeks ago, we're going to launch 600 hours of new original programming this year alone. So it is a function of -- as our budget continues to grow, as our subscriber
componenttext: We've been on the of trajectory of accelerating original programming. I mentioned a couple weeks ago, we're going to launch 600 hours of new original programming this year alone. So it is a function of -- as our budget continues to grow, as our subscriber base grows, we are licensing program and we're equating programming. As a percentage of our spend, original spending is growing. But as an absolute, they licensing dollars continue to grow as well. And Fox is an important vendor for us, just like they all are. And we're also a very important source of revenue for them.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, if that rhetoric was less intense, if they are not saying we're going to stop selling to , would you be pulling back on original spending?
componenttext: I mean, if that rhetoric was less intense, if they are not saying we're going to stop selling to , would you be pulling back on original spending?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I think we've -- the positives that come from our original spending have been tremendous in terms of our international growth, in terms of really distinguishing and differentiating Netflix from an explosion of services.
componenttext: No. I think we've -- the positives that come from our original spending have been tremendous in terms of our international growth, in terms of really distinguishing and differentiating Netflix from an explosion of services.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And what do you think about the Marvel relationship? Do you see expanding that one? Or is that going to stay where it is right now?
componenttext: And what do you think about the Marvel relationship? Do you see expanding that one? Or is that going to stay where it is right now?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a pretty expensive relationship already. but we have 5 season -- 5 different series going in, we just announced yesterday that we're going to a second season of Jessica Jones. So you look at those 5 series with multiple seasons plus the crossover sea
componenttext: It's a pretty expensive relationship already. but we have 5 season -- 5 different series going in, we just announced yesterday that we're going to a second season of Jessica Jones. So you look at those 5 series with multiple seasons plus the crossover season of The Defenders, it's huge commitment. And we're all the way, along the way, you're going to be introducing new characters who have the potential of spin off and grow that relationship further. So it's very important for Marvel. It's very important for Disney.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And for us.
componenttext: And for us.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And for us, absolutely.
componenttext: And for us, absolutely.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ted, sticking with you on content. Why the call out of family programming emphasis in the letter? Any comment around sort of what you're doing maybe probably differently there? And now when you have a quarter behind you with some of your movies in the mar
componenttext: Ted, sticking with you on content. Why the call out of family programming emphasis in the letter? Any comment around sort of what you're doing maybe probably differently there? And now when you have a quarter behind you with some of your movies in the market, what you learned, how does that change your appetite around film?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, when we -- the reason we called it out is to acknowledge that there is a large volume of specifically kids programming coming out. When normally people think of Netflix' original programming, they've been thinking about our sophisticated dramas and
componenttext: Well, when we -- the reason we called it out is to acknowledge that there is a large volume of specifically kids programming coming out. When normally people think of Netflix' original programming, they've been thinking about our sophisticated dramas and adult comedies more so than within our kids programming. But quietly, we've been amassing a very big selection of original kids programming in Netflix. Kids Magazine just voted Netflix the #1 outlet for kids programming on television, which we're really proud of. And that's going to continue to grow, and we -- we're also looking to grow categories like Fuller House, which are programming that are watched together, parents watching their -- showing their kids that they just don't tolerate, but they enjoy to . and that's a underserved market, and that's why we called that out specifically. And on the movies side, it was a great first swing I think with The Ridiculous Six and Beasts of No Nation. Beasts of No Nation is in discussion about the Oscars, didn't quite make it there, but picked up nominations in almost every other category. The viewing, we're thrilled with around the world and have been continued to be thrilled with us. We've expanded into new territories. Both Ridiculous Six and Beasts of No Nation are watched in huge numbers in all our new territories. So we really excited by it, and we've got an aggressive slate in '16 to keep pushing on it.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just shifting over to the hours data, David, you gave in Las Vegas and then some in the letter. This comes up kind of every quarter, people trying to understand the penetration growth curve in this international markets. So if you look at the European mar
componenttext: Just shifting over to the hours data, David, you gave in Las Vegas and then some in the letter. This comes up kind of every quarter, people trying to understand the penetration growth curve in this international markets. So if you look at the European markets where you gave the subscriber number in last fall, I think penetration grows pretty relatively light so far, certainly versus say, the U.K. which is much stronger. What are you guys doing, whether you and David, as you think about trying to accelerate the growth of some of these markets that have been tougher out of the gate? What are the characteristics that we, as investors and analysts, should look at these markets to understand the dynamics that drive these growth rates over time?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: The first year in the U.K. was a really tough market. So it's usually successful for us now, but it's not true that it always was. We saw the same thing in Brazil for different reasons. So being light in the beginning doesn't worry us a bit. And what we'v
componenttext: The first year in the U.K. was a really tough market. So it's usually successful for us now, but it's not true that it always was. We saw the same thing in Brazil for different reasons. So being light in the beginning doesn't worry us a bit. And what we've seen in market after market like Spain, Italy, France, Germany is this building momentum as we do more and more local content. We've got this amazing show coming out in May that I think will really uplift the way our French members think about us and nonmembers in particular. So we're really looking forward to that. So it's a natural building cycle. And I think the way you should model is pretty consistent growth in all the territories of the variation is pretty modest, again if you time adjust from whenever we launch.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just on your time spent number, I think we calculated in the fourth quarter anyway, about a 12% increase per average sub year-over-year, which is impressive given you added a lot of new international markets. Anything that you can address about sort o
componenttext: And just on your time spent number, I think we calculated in the fourth quarter anyway, about a 12% increase per average sub year-over-year, which is impressive given you added a lot of new international markets. Anything that you can address about sort of the highest or -- versus the lowest and whether all markets are still growing? It would appear that the U.S. is still growing, which is impressive. Maybe you can talk about that a little bit.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we're continuing to invest more in content, more in platform in terms of the performance and the speed, and the service is growing. So I think it's natural that we're continuing to grow in all those dimensions per membership basis, as the service ma
componenttext: Well, we're continuing to invest more in content, more in platform in terms of the performance and the speed, and the service is growing. So I think it's natural that we're continuing to grow in all those dimensions per membership basis, as the service matures and the idea. I think about smartphone usage now compared to 10 years ago. Of course, the number of smartphones is up, but the usage and utility is up. I mean I think we've only scratched the surface. Netflix is a tiny percentage of all video viewing today. So we have tremendous potential growth ahead of us. If we can continue to execute them if we can continue to produce shows to have this global launch with low snafus. It's lot of a hard execution, but the market potential is really quite large.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd only add that you -- the more content that we're adding, the more likely you going to land on a show that somebody can't live without. And I think that's what you've been seeing as we're expanding in not just the volume of content, but also the breadt
componenttext: I'd only add that you -- the more content that we're adding, the more likely you going to land on a show that somebody can't live without. And I think that's what you've been seeing as we're expanding in not just the volume of content, but also the breadth of genres that we're covering in our original shows and our original movies.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Reed, we talked a couple of weeks ago India. You called out Philippines, Saudi Arabia as important markets for you. Anything else you want to sort of emphasize in terms of 130-plus countries you rolled out a couple weeks ago?
componenttext: Reed, we talked a couple of weeks ago India. You called out Philippines, Saudi Arabia as important markets for you. Anything else you want to sort of emphasize in terms of 130-plus countries you rolled out a couple weeks ago?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well those are a the number of countries that have language match. So Philippines, a lot of people speak English. We have English-language content. We have translated our service in Arabic, so that's a good match for Saudi Arabia. And then in much of the
componenttext: Well those are a the number of countries that have language match. So Philippines, a lot of people speak English. We have English-language content. We have translated our service in Arabic, so that's a good match for Saudi Arabia. And then in much of the world, Russia, Poland, Central and Eastern Europe, we're still only in English. So we've got a ways to go over the next 2 years. We'll keep adding more languages and make the service more relevant. So we look at it as sort of 2 categories where we've got language match and where we don't yet. We're seeing both growth, but more substantial growth in those obviously where we have language match. And then beyond language, we have work to do in payments in terms of in each country, there are often local payments and different traditions around payments that we'll start to work on. So think of it as we've really begun on the international and global expansion rather than it's all sawed up and we're all complete on it.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: [indiscernible] Reed, we've had 2 weeks, right? So we've been 2 weeks in terms of that launch.
componenttext: [indiscernible] Reed, we've had 2 weeks, right? So we've been 2 weeks in terms of that launch.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And what are you thinking about as you think move into markets where mobile Internet is sort of the dominant way that people get online? Traditionally, people are watching on a connected TV. What happens when they're used to watching or consuming things o
componenttext: And what are you thinking about as you think move into markets where mobile Internet is sort of the dominant way that people get online? Traditionally, people are watching on a connected TV. What happens when they're used to watching or consuming things on the phone?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, same thing. You just watch Netflix on the phone just like you watch YouTube on the phone. A lot of that phone viewing is on WiFi because of the data charges. And then what you do on the networks is trying to have the most efficient video codecs you c
componenttext: Yes, same thing. You just watch Netflix on the phone just like you watch YouTube on the phone. A lot of that phone viewing is on WiFi because of the data charges. And then what you do on the networks is trying to have the most efficient video codecs you can have, and we're working hard on that. But think of it as it's the same way that people use of Internet video services like YouTube.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, I want to come back and talk a little bit on the numbers. Can you update us on your expected cash burn for '16? And help us understand relationship between content on the -- con cost on the P&L versus cash as you move through this year, maybe into
componenttext: David, I want to come back and talk a little bit on the numbers. Can you update us on your expected cash burn for '16? And help us understand relationship between content on the -- con cost on the P&L versus cash as you move through this year, maybe into 2017?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, there's no change here. So we've said before that we are on pace to burn about $1 billion of cash, mostly on our branded or originals content. The ratio of cash to P&L is about 1 3 to 1 4, and that continues to hold. So you see that it will run up at
componenttext: Yes, there's no change here. So we've said before that we are on pace to burn about $1 billion of cash, mostly on our branded or originals content. The ratio of cash to P&L is about 1 3 to 1 4, and that continues to hold. So you see that it will run up at a peak in certain quarters that we take delivery of a lot of original content and then runs back down. But I think the 1 3 to 1 4 range of cash to P&L expense will continue to hold. And so far, our expectations of use of cash have been about as expected. You see in the letter that we wrote that we're on pace to use about $1 billion and maybe a little more this year. But we upsized our debt last year, about a year ago. And so in terms of timing, we've been looking at later this year, maybe early next year before we would need to do any more on the capital side.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And on the U.S. margins, and I realize how you allocate cost between the U.S. and international markets may change over time. But you've had a lot more operating leverage last year than perhaps we all thought heading into the year. Yet you maintain this 2
componenttext: And on the U.S. margins, and I realize how you allocate cost between the U.S. and international markets may change over time. But you've had a lot more operating leverage last year than perhaps we all thought heading into the year. Yet you maintain this 2020 guidance of 40% contribution margin. Is that just being conservative? Or do you expect maybe some change in amortization rates to slow the margin expansion down? What color can you give us about the pace of U.S. margins?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, not the latter part. I would say there are a couple points on this. One is that to the extent that we launched the rest of the world, and it was a little earlier than maybe 24 months ago that we would have been fully global or near fully global, I w
componenttext: Well, not the latter part. I would say there are a couple points on this. One is that to the extent that we launched the rest of the world, and it was a little earlier than maybe 24 months ago that we would have been fully global or near fully global, I would say the U.S. P&L did receive a little bit of relief, right? But that's a onetime thing, and that sort of goes away. The second point is we continue to add content and add it at an efficient level. I mean, we look at hours viewed and what is generated by the content versus the costs. And we continue to see new additions even in the U.S. and markets that are -- have been in place for 4 to 5 years now. We continue to see viewership, and ted talked a little bit about engaging new audiences. You'll see us do that. So I think for the foreseeable future, we think we can grow both margin and grow the content spend even in markets in the U.S.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Back to international, I know you guys aren't going to offer guidance on when you might go into China. But when and if you do, do you imagine that you're going to have to restrict or alter the catalog based on censorship or other issues with the Chinese m
componenttext: Back to international, I know you guys aren't going to offer guidance on when you might go into China. But when and if you do, do you imagine that you're going to have to restrict or alter the catalog based on censorship or other issues with the Chinese market?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the standards, at least today, they're fluid. The government uses restrict like Game of Thrones or had 10 or 15 minutes from many episodes cut from it. So there are issues conforming to those local standards. That's true of all the Western content th
componenttext: Yes, the standards, at least today, they're fluid. The government uses restrict like Game of Thrones or had 10 or 15 minutes from many episodes cut from it. So there are issues conforming to those local standards. That's true of all the Western content that's produced as well as the Chinese continent in that market. So we'll be in a level playing field with all other services.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the same territory, would you have to be in a JV? Is there some way you can enter China without doing a JV?
componenttext: On the same territory, would you have to be in a JV? Is there some way you can enter China without doing a JV?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: There's all different flavors if you look at how Disney with iTunes and others have done. So we're talking to different partners, building relationships. And again as I mentioned a few days ago, we have a very long-term look. And this could be many years
componenttext: There's all different flavors if you look at how Disney with iTunes and others have done. So we're talking to different partners, building relationships. And again as I mentioned a few days ago, we have a very long-term look. And this could be many years of discussions, or it could happen faster than that. We're going to take our time. The clearest example is really the iPhone, which took many years for Apple to get approval for that, and now it's a very large business for Apple. And so our view is it we're looking out for the business a decade from now. We should just be very patient and continue to build those relationships and listen and learn. So we're in no hurry. And most of our time and effort right now is going in how do we build the Japanese market, how do we build the Philippines market, how do we build the Saudi Arabian market, markets that are open to us and available right now.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I want to ask about content spending, maybe for David and Ted to comment on. We presume relation between subscriber growth and content spend is not linear going forward. So as you think about growing the U.S  business growth, how should we think about the
componenttext: I want to ask about content spending, maybe for David and Ted to comment on. We presume relation between subscriber growth and content spend is not linear going forward. So as you think about growing the U.S  business growth, how should we think about the pace of growth in content spending? And Ted, is the 50-50 original-acquired ratio still your long-term expectation? Or have the relationships with vertically integrated media companies may be altered that at all?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, let me take the first part and I'll turn it over to Ted. So we'd say, Ben, it is true that once you get to $4 billion of spend, the rate of growth is going to slow down. So that is definitely true on the U.S. side. But back to my earlier comment, we
componenttext: Well, let me take the first part and I'll turn it over to Ted. So we'd say, Ben, it is true that once you get to $4 billion of spend, the rate of growth is going to slow down. So that is definitely true on the U.S. side. But back to my earlier comment, we still think that there's great content to be added to the U.S. service that is efficient, that will continue to increase their competitiveness and attractiveness of the offering in the U.S. So we're going to continue to add to that, to that service. It's at a slower rate of growth, but it continues to grow. And in time, it's not true yet, but in time, we will be adding more of our original branded content than would license content. So today, we've been adding growth but we've been growing originals rather quickly. We continue to grow originals quickly, but you're seeing a lot of that added to the U.S. market. And to the extent that they're successful -- and Ted, maybe this is a good transition to you, about finding content that works across markets. There'll be a blurring of the lines between what is really U.S. content and what is international content, and vice versa.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think the matter of this is doing something that doesn't feel homogenized for the world that still feels like great programming for everybody. and we've got tremendous success so far I guess with , a primarily Spanish-language show working in count
componenttext: Yes, I think the matter of this is doing something that doesn't feel homogenized for the world that still feels like great programming for everybody. and we've got tremendous success so far I guess with , a primarily Spanish-language show working in countries that speak every different language. And Making a Murderer, as Reed pointed out, in many parts of the world, these kind of true detective documentaries are incredibly popular in prime time television. So we're pleased to see these continue to be a global genres. When you asked about our suppliers, and I think confrontation is probably overstated. But there's a lot of rhetoric going around right now about how quickly and how aggressively people will license. It's still a very competitive business. And I think what happens is that people sell their programming for the highest bidder. And if we are that bidder, we get the programming. And if we -- if someone else is, they get the programming. and that's true today. That was true 5 years ago. So I think what's happening now is we were very pleased with the results of the original spend. And that was driving that up, not being cut off in either end.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Ted, on that proof point, what should we glean from your DreamWorks extension? Obviously, that's a family genre, and I think that's kind of an output deal. You can correct me if I'm wrong. I know You don't like output deals. And on the same side, CW r
componenttext: And Ted, on that proof point, what should we glean from your DreamWorks extension? Obviously, that's a family genre, and I think that's kind of an output deal. You can correct me if I'm wrong. I know You don't like output deals. And on the same side, CW renewal has not happened. I think that deal is sort of still out there. Is that an example where you can get something done with an independent studio, but not a vertically integrated one?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I mean the DreamWorks is not an output in the traditional sense, meaning that we agreed to certain levels of programming, but we work together on what that programming is going to be and developing those shows along with DreamWorks. And we've been thr
componenttext: No, I mean the DreamWorks is not an output in the traditional sense, meaning that we agreed to certain levels of programming, but we work together on what that programming is going to be and developing those shows along with DreamWorks. And we've been thrilled with the results. they -- those -- We took it to be in the more territories and expanded the number of years of programming that will come through that deal because it's been working great. And I think in the CW deal, it's just in the process of negotiation. It's not behind in any normal process. And as you know, it's Time Warner's tradition to negotiate in the press, so you're seeing some of that from them. And right now, it's just in the process of negotiation. We should also keep in mind that no matter what happens in the CW deal, it's the programming that's currently there remains with us today to the series. So it's not like we're going to look up one day without the programming. And we like to make that deal work. It's a great relationship with CBS and Warner is in that deal and would like to continue it.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Reed, you said you didn't think Time Warner should spin off HBO. But if they noted your advice, does that change your view of the way HBO would be -- would act as a global competitor for you? Do you think they have the ability to do things outside of Time
componenttext: Reed, you said you didn't think Time Warner should spin off HBO. But if they noted your advice, does that change your view of the way HBO would be -- would act as a global competitor for you? Do you think they have the ability to do things outside of Time Warner they can't do within Time Warner?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016

componenttext: HBO has been a great competitor, one we admire for a very long time. You might have seen the recent news that they now have offering HBO Now direct to consumer in multiple nations. They just did start Nordics and then countries in Latin America, now in Spain. So they will be a formidable global competitor over time, again independent of their ownership.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Going back to David on some of the financials. David, I think you said at CES or your presentation at Las Vegas about 120 million of loss a quarter internationally. It's one levels I want to make sure that's the right way we should thinking about the year
componenttext: Going back to David on some of the financials. David, I think you said at CES or your presentation at Las Vegas about 120 million of loss a quarter internationally. It's one levels I want to make sure that's the right way we should thinking about the year. And then on raising more capital, you mentioned in the letter you're looking at lowering your cost of capital, which we presume would have been the case. What are you referring to specifically there? Are some of the gyrations in the high-yield market causing you to think about raising capital differently than you have in the past?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: So in the first question, you heard me right in terms of 120 million. Looking ahead, I would say there's 2 things that might alter that or at -- not materially, but plus or minus 10 million, 20 million. That would be foreign exchange. I mean, we continue
componenttext: So in the first question, you heard me right in terms of 120 million. Looking ahead, I would say there's 2 things that might alter that or at -- not materially, but plus or minus 10 million, 20 million. That would be foreign exchange. I mean, we continue it to have an environment where we're running deep into some heavy headwinds in foreign exchange. If that continues, that might challenge that 120 million upward a little, again 10 million, 20 million. And then the other thing is just carving out a little bit room for us. Like we said, we're 14 days, we're 2 weeks or so into a global launch. We've got lots of markets that we're in early days of setting our level of compelling and competitiveness in our service offering. This year is about investment, and you'll see that our focus -- we committed to a global breakeven, but we're also trying to build multiyear businesses in many of these markets. So if we see opportunities, I think there's a little bit of room for us to pursue this later in the year, to some additional content marketing or whatever the right mixture of investment is. But it is true, it's about 120 million. It won't meaningfully depart from that too much, but it could be 10 million, 20 million within that.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then you should assume that debt instruments are similar to the ones we've used in the past. We've been happy with those.
componenttext: And then you should assume that debt instruments are similar to the ones we've used in the past. We've been happy with those.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sorry, Ben, on your last question. Nothing's changed there other than that our confidence that we'll continue to drive some meaningful profit into '17, '18. And to the extent that people are focused on that backward-looking financial metrics in terms
componenttext: Yes, sorry, Ben, on your last question. Nothing's changed there other than that our confidence that we'll continue to drive some meaningful profit into '17, '18. And to the extent that people are focused on that backward-looking financial metrics in terms of creditworthiness, we think we'll become a better credit risk over time, irrespective of what's happening in the high-yield markets. Today, our bonds are traded pretty well.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And follow up, David, on your global breakeven point, I think operating income was down a bit in '15 versus '14. But if I look at the '16 outlook for international losses, you just gave us plus U.S. margin expansion, I think operating income overall shoul
componenttext: And follow up, David, on your global breakeven point, I think operating income was down a bit in '15 versus '14. But if I look at the '16 outlook for international losses, you just gave us plus U.S. margin expansion, I think operating income overall should grow a bit off of the '15 base. I mean, am I thinking about things the wrong way?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think you're doing the right mapping. The question was a little bit modular in terms of looking at the narrow numbers. That's true in terms of the math. But in general, I would say this year is about our continued international investment. We're not
componenttext: No, I think you're doing the right mapping. The question was a little bit modular in terms of looking at the narrow numbers. That's true in terms of the math. But in general, I would say this year is about our continued international investment. We're not really focused on making sure operating grows. The operating income growth is sort of an outcome of focus on international expansion, but also committed to consolidated breakeven.

componenttext: Let's talk on the bit more about the 2016 launches. And you guys talked about how the go-to-market strategy, is it for these markets versus say international markets? Maybe at high level operationally when you think about markets like India or parts of Africa, what's different about what you're doing here versus what we've seen before?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's extremely similar to how we launched Latin America where there's a couple countries that we focused on directly, and there's still some countries that haven't yet visited 4 or 5 years later but we have a lot of members. So the Internet is a beautiful
componenttext: It's extremely similar to how we launched Latin America where there's a couple countries that we focused on directly, and there's still some countries that haven't yet visited 4 or 5 years later but we have a lot of members. So the Internet is a beautiful thing because of its openness. So again, it's very similar to our Latin America launch.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And anything you're doing on the payment side. Since you brought up Latin America, I think that was a challenge historically. I'm sure you learned a lot. But what I can you do proactively in some of these markets to help smooth that for the consumer?
componenttext: And anything you're doing on the payment side. Since you brought up Latin America, I think that was a challenge historically. I'm sure you learned a lot. But what I can you do proactively in some of these markets to help smooth that for the consumer?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll take that one. So I think we've got a pretty robust payment teams, and we've invested internally in building that out, getting smart in terms of the payment systems across the world. We're pressing on gift cards and prepaid cards that might open up t
componenttext: I'll take that one. So I think we've got a pretty robust payment teams, and we've invested internally in building that out, getting smart in terms of the payment systems across the world. We're pressing on gift cards and prepaid cards that might open up the market to those people that don't have access to credit, debit card. But in rest of world, again, it's pretty early days. And I think we'll take the approach that we took in first Latin America, which is look at our next best opportunities to open up additional pockets of the market. We've done this before, not just in LatAm but in other places, and we'll continue with our playbook in the rest of the world. Our partners are another element of this, right? So Reed mentioned iOS. we'll be looking to draft of large partners in the group in terms of iOS, Android and other options. And there's a lot of evolution going on in the payments world. I got misquoted at Citi by saying that we're interested in Bitcoin, but what I said was they'll be nice to have in 5 to 10 years a borderless currency like Bitcoin. I think those people that are so excited about it are interested in breaking down those barriers and in using the power of Internet at the Internet age to reduce the friction of payments that are existing today in terms of some of these banking structures. So we'll be drafting of those long term as well. But in the near term, can expect us to just knock down the opportunities in terms of adding local payment methods, credit debit cards, drafting of partners as well.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Are you guys -- you are participating the T-Mobile in their program. Are you going to work with Verizon on I think they call it free V announced today?
componenttext: Are you guys -- you are participating the T-Mobile in their program. Are you going to work with Verizon on I think they call it free V announced today?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't know enough of the details of Free V. But generally great thing what T-Mobile is doing is making unlimited video consumption a possibility, with freedom from worry about the data caps. And the quick profile from the customer's standpoint on is the
componenttext: I don't know enough of the details of Free V. But generally great thing what T-Mobile is doing is making unlimited video consumption a possibility, with freedom from worry about the data caps. And the quick profile from the customer's standpoint on is they only get DVD quality on their 4- or 5-inch screen, which when you look at the DVD quality, it's actually very, very good. But that's a really unique program that T-Mobile has been and received a great reception amongst our users. And we're seeing viewing going up and I think T-Mobile is seeing several positive benefits from it. So we hope those kinds of program expand.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Reed, can you tell us why you're comfortable in participating in programs like that and how it differs you explained in Comcast with their data caps?
componenttext: So Reed, can you tell us why you're comfortable in participating in programs like that and how it differs you explained in Comcast with their data caps?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's voluntary on the customer. Any customer of T-Mos can decide to turn it on or turn it off. That would be a big difference. And then they're not charging their providers. it's an open program. Many of our competitors, such as Hulu and HBO, are in
componenttext: Well, it's voluntary on the customer. Any customer of T-Mos can decide to turn it on or turn it off. That would be a big difference. And then they're not charging their providers. it's an open program. Many of our competitors, such as Hulu and HBO, are in the program also. But it's an open, no-charge program. what they really focus on trying to get the customer some optionality of limited DVD quality, and then you've got unlimited viewing, which their customers are choosing in -- in droves.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: We you go with the $7.50 to $8 price point in these international markets, particularly emerging markets where that's a relatively expensive price. Do you reserve the right to sort of go down market over time as well?
componenttext: We you go with the $7.50 to $8 price point in these international markets, particularly emerging markets where that's a relatively expensive price. Do you reserve the right to sort of go down market over time as well?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we're starting off definitely appealing to elites. I mean, I mentioned in Russia and Eastern Europe, we're still in English. In Vietnam and Cambodia, we're in English. So we're serving elites. You can think of it as a shorthand as iPhone owners. So
componenttext: Well, we're starting off definitely appealing to elites. I mean, I mentioned in Russia and Eastern Europe, we're still in English. In Vietnam and Cambodia, we're in English. So we're serving elites. You can think of it as a shorthand as iPhone owners. So they've paid $800 for an iPhone. They're comfortable with entertainment in English. so for them, $8, $10 is a sweet spot price. certainly in future years as we do more and more and trying to expand into a mass market, we can look at additional pricing options. But we feel good about our pricing value for these global originals right now.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just on these international markets, there's been a lot of press coverage on the VPN situation and proxies. Maybe can walk us through what you are doing as a company that's going to change your policy from prior periods? And could you envision a situa
componenttext: And just on these international markets, there's been a lot of press coverage on the VPN situation and proxies. Maybe can walk us through what you are doing as a company that's going to change your policy from prior periods? And could you envision a situation where that might impact your net adds because you have millions of customers in the international markets that suddenly have -- went from having a fake U.S. account to having no access?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't think we'll see any impact. We've always enforced proxy blocking with a blacklist. Now we've got an expanded and enhanced blacklist. So I don't think we're going to see an huge change.
componenttext: I don't think we'll see any impact. We've always enforced proxy blocking with a blacklist. Now we've got an expanded and enhanced blacklist. So I don't think we're going to see an huge change.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just to be clear. So you don't think there's any huge change with the VPNs and other proxy workarounds, then why go ahead and do it at all? Is this purely to placate content providers?
componenttext: Just to be clear. So you don't think there's any huge change with the VPNs and other proxy workarounds, then why go ahead and do it at all? Is this purely to placate content providers?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: You can call it placate or you can call it catering to their desires, which -- they have legitimate desires. If we license content in Canada, it's not fair for us to be -- or our customers to be getting that if we've only pays for Canada. So we're trying
componenttext: You can call it placate or you can call it catering to their desires, which -- they have legitimate desires. If we license content in Canada, it's not fair for us to be -- or our customers to be getting that if we've only pays for Canada. So we're trying to pay for it all by shifting to global licenses, and we're working with our content providers on that. But it's perfectly reasonable with the content owners par. And we know there'll be some people affected that are using it today, which is why we wanted to be open about. But it's really a continuation of what we've always done now with this enhanced blacklist and some other techniques.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we've got all our originals are fully global. They go live in every country at the same time around the world. Increasingly, we are spending most of our licensing dollars on content that's accessible in that way. From small things all the way to big t
componenttext: And we've got all our originals are fully global. They go live in every country at the same time around the world. Increasingly, we are spending most of our licensing dollars on content that's accessible in that way. From small things all the way to big things like the Oscar-nominated movie The Big Short, we'll have the pay-TV window  around world, so people will be able to watch that movie on Netflix wherever they are.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: In the past, you said piracy is a major competitor. Any concern that the VPN and proxy workarounds will push some of your users back to piracy?
componenttext: In the past, you said piracy is a major competitor. Any concern that the VPN and proxy workarounds will push some of your users back to piracy?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: If we see that, there's probably so few of them, it's not a big contributor to overall global piracy. Overall, global piracy is a big the problem, and we are working with all the content owners partially to be a great carrot and also to have other service
componenttext: If we see that, there's probably so few of them, it's not a big contributor to overall global piracy. Overall, global piracy is a big the problem, and we are working with all the content owners partially to be a great carrot and also to have other services like HBO and Amazon be great carrots. So we can work together on this antipiracy agenda.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And I think geofilter hacking and piracy are maybe probably distant cousins at best. I mean I think of geofilter hacking as people hacking to pay versus piracy where people are hacking not to pay.
componenttext: Yes. And I think geofilter hacking and piracy are maybe probably distant cousins at best. I mean I think of geofilter hacking as people hacking to pay versus piracy where people are hacking not to pay.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Curious if you guys can talk over what you're investing in the technology side? I think your long-term letter talked about over $700 million in tech and development in 2016. There's some comments in the letter about complexity-based encoding. What I'd lov
componenttext: Curious if you guys can talk over what you're investing in the technology side? I think your long-term letter talked about over $700 million in tech and development in 2016. There's some comments in the letter about complexity-based encoding. What I'd love to hear, beyond the general areas you're spending money, is what are you doing to reduce the required speed or bit rate that's needed to stream and enjoy Netflix? And I'm particularly thinking about the 2016 in the mobile-first markets.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the whole industry is working on these advanced version of H265 to be able to do very high quality encoding with small bit rates. so YouTube's made great progress on that. we made great progress. So I think again, people have been working and effi
componenttext: I think the whole industry is working on these advanced version of H265 to be able to do very high quality encoding with small bit rates. so YouTube's made great progress on that. we made great progress. So I think again, people have been working and efficient video encoding for 50 years. That's one of the classic computer science problem. So we're seeing good progress there. We're seeing a lot of progress in our algorithms and being able to rank videos for each person, even better, being able to promote to the right person the right content. Hopefully, you've seen some of that in your own experience where the suggestions, that is the billboard at the top of the page, are more often very appropriate and some thing you're just dying to watch.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: What are the minimum speeds you think someone's going to need in a market like India, on fixed line or mobile, to actually stream Netflix?
componenttext: What are the minimum speeds you think someone's going to need in a market like India, on fixed line or mobile, to actually stream Netflix?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the minimum's around 0.5 megabit. So that's been consistent in the past. That's a fairly low quality picture. It's around 700 to 800 kilobits to be able to do DVD quality.
componenttext: Well, the minimum's around 0.5 megabit. So that's been consistent in the past. That's a fairly low quality picture. It's around 700 to 800 kilobits to be able to do DVD quality.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: You guys have said a few times now that Making a Murderer surprised you, its success surprised you. Can you talk about sort of why you had more modest expectations for it, and whether that, the surprise of that success have gone -- had you sort of rethink
componenttext: You guys have said a few times now that Making a Murderer surprised you, its success surprised you. Can you talk about sort of why you had more modest expectations for it, and whether that, the surprise of that success have gone -- had you sort of rethink some of your modeling?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it surprised me because I know so little about these things. When I met with the filmmakers and heard about the murderer sequence was interesting, but I thought it would a specialty thing. I would stay Ted and his team aren't that surprised. They al
componenttext: Well, it surprised me because I know so little about these things. When I met with the filmmakers and heard about the murderer sequence was interesting, but I thought it would a specialty thing. I would stay Ted and his team aren't that surprised. They always believed in this content.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: It had a -- there was something very special about this from the beginning. When it came to us, it was 7 years in the making already, and this was -- came to us over 3 years ago, and recognized that even before making original docs, that they had really s
componenttext: It had a -- there was something very special about this from the beginning. When it came to us, it was 7 years in the making already, and this was -- came to us over 3 years ago, and recognized that even before making original docs, that they had really something special in their hands. The surprise was that it see perform at the level scripted series. Even our best documentary series have done very, very well, but not performed in such mainstream numbers.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right, so given that surprise, did that, "all right, we're going to sort of rethink how we evaluate some of our shows?" Or you were sort of this is a happy success and you're happy to move on with?
componenttext: Right, so given that surprise, did that, "all right, we're going to sort of rethink how we evaluate some of our shows?" Or you were sort of this is a happy success and you're happy to move on with?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's on the continuum of expanding our genres, anyway. so it was only our second documentary series. We followed -- we started with Chefs Table, which is a very different show. And the next documentary series are probably going to very different are
componenttext: Yes, it's on the continuum of expanding our genres, anyway. so it was only our second documentary series. We followed -- we started with Chefs Table, which is a very different show. And the next documentary series are probably going to very different are Making a Murderer as well. in fact, it starts in a couple of weeks, which is -- or this week, I'm sorry. Chelsea Handler with Chelsea Does will be our next documentary series.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Real quickly, Ted, I guess for Ted. competitors report that you're, in many cases, overspending by a significant amount on original programming as well as repeats. Do you think that gap is going to continue? Do think it's going to increase? Do you think y
componenttext: Real quickly, Ted, I guess for Ted. competitors report that you're, in many cases, overspending by a significant amount on original programming as well as repeats. Do you think that gap is going to continue? Do think it's going to increase? Do you think you can actually probably limit your spending?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: First, I want to thank them for endorsing our spending to talent. But the truth of it is the only reason we can, in their own word -- in John's own words, have up spending for a series is because we get shocked in our viewing on that series. David expecte
componenttext: First, I want to thank them for endorsing our spending to talent. But the truth of it is the only reason we can, in their own word -- in John's own words, have up spending for a series is because we get shocked in our viewing on that series. David expected, as David said earlier, the efficiency of the content spend has been great. Meaning that we're spending a lot of great shows and, we get a lot of viewing relative to license programming or relative to other programming as well. So we've been excited about it as part of -- and I think it's a competitive marketplace, and overspending is relative part showed that get down like The Crown, which are relatively expensive shows are successful. It's money well spent, the way it was for House of Cards or Orange is the New Black.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Out of respect for one of our longtime questioners and your colleague, Rich Greenfield, who had a question about Charter. And was it good if Charter acquires TWC for the Internet industry, OTT? I'll answer proactively that I think it would be a tremendous
componenttext:
Out of respect for one of our longtime questioners and your colleague, Rich Greenfield, who had a question about Charter. And was it good if Charter acquires TWC for the Internet industry, OTT? I'll answer proactively that I think it would be a tremendous positive for the OTT industry because Charter has agreed to a multiyear strong net neutrality policy, something no one else has publicly agreed to, and that would cover not only the Charter footprint but the Time Warner Cable footprint. And that means that we, Hulu, Amazon and others can compete on an open basis. And so we think it will be a huge step forward for U.S. policy in terms of OTT.
Thank you all, Peter. Thank you, Ben. We'll talk to you again soon.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you.
componenttext: Thank you.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome to the Netflix Q4 2015 Earnings Call. I'm David Wells, CFO. I'm joined on my right by Reed Hastings, our CEO; and Ted Sarandos, our Chief Content Officer. Interviewing us today will be Peter Kafka from Re/code and Ben Swinburne from Morgan Stanley
componenttext: Welcome to the Netflix Q4 2015 Earnings Call. I'm David Wells, CFO. I'm joined on my right by Reed Hastings, our CEO; and Ted Sarandos, our Chief Content Officer. Interviewing us today will be Peter Kafka from Re/code and Ben Swinburne from Morgan Stanley. Just a reminder, a cautionary statement that we will be making forward-looking statements and actual results may vary. Over to the first interview question.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll start out maybe for Reed and the team. Let's -- can you reflect on the fourth quarter results for us that we're all going through right now? In particular, talk about the international strength. You mentioned you were pleased with the October -- Sept
componenttext: I'll start out maybe for Reed and the team. Let's -- can you reflect on the fourth quarter results for us that we're all going through right now? In particular, talk about the international strength. You mentioned you were pleased with the October -- September, October launches. So can we infer that the outperformance versus your expectation maybe came from those areas? Or any color you can give us on the international strength, to start us off?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: We've got over 50 countries in Q4, so we had a lot of experience, Ben, predicting these markets. And then we launched in Japan in early September and Spain, Portugal and Italy in mid-October. And I'd say they've gone very well, as we said in the letter. I
componenttext: We've got over 50 countries in Q4, so we had a lot of experience, Ben, predicting these markets. And then we launched in Japan in early September and Spain, Portugal and Italy in mid-October. And I'd say they've gone very well, as we said in the letter. In terms of the outperformance, it was pretty broad-based, many different contributors around the world to that. And what we're seeing basically is that this on-demand Internet TV, watch wherever and whenever you want, it's very popular, wherever you go in the world.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just taking that question over to the U.S. for you or also maybe for David. A little bit lighter this quarter than your guidance or budget. Talk to us a little bit about the churn, connects, dynamic and anything you'd want to add around credit card ch
componenttext: And just taking that question over to the U.S. for you or also maybe for David. A little bit lighter this quarter than your guidance or budget. Talk to us a little bit about the churn, connects, dynamic and anything you'd want to add around credit card chipsets or any other issues you want to bring out around Q4 performance in the U.S.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Q4, I would say, was pretty close to our projection. We were literally within hours of it, but -- so we did anticipate that net additions would be lighter year-on-year. I would say credit card was a background issue in Q3, continues to be a backgrou
componenttext: Well, Q4, I would say, was pretty close to our projection. We were literally within hours of it, but -- so we did anticipate that net additions would be lighter year-on-year. I would say credit card was a background issue in Q3, continues to be a background issue. But the larger thing is that it's just the next 50 million are a little harder than the first 50 million in terms of growth. And we're doing everything on the content side, on the product side. We're continuing to improve that service. But you're seeing that law of large numbers. When you grow steady at 5 million, 6 million net additions a year on a larger number, then that percentage growth is smaller year-over-year. And that's what we predicted, and that's what you see in our guide for Q1 as well.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, guys. Last quarter, you said the credit card issues were a background issue. This quarter you said it's a background issue. How long do you anticipate this is going to be a problem for you? Additionally, any sense of why you're the only major consume
componenttext: Hey, guys. Last quarter, you said the credit card issues were a background issue. This quarter you said it's a background issue. How long do you anticipate this is going to be a problem for you? Additionally, any sense of why you're the only major consumer company that's called this out as a problem?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't think we're the -- Peter, this is David. I don't think that we're the only one. I think because we're a recurring merchant, anywhere from 5 to 10 basis points, 15 basis points is sensitive to us. We have optimized. We spend a lot of time optimizin
componenttext: I don't think we're the -- Peter, this is David. I don't think that we're the only one. I think because we're a recurring merchant, anywhere from 5 to 10 basis points, 15 basis points is sensitive to us. We have optimized. We spend a lot of time optimizing our recurring billing systems and our approach, and so we're very sensitive to it. Again, it's a small thing. I think we want to focus on the larger things and not the small things. We anticipate that the EMV rollout will continue into 2016 into Q1 and Q2. And we'll always have, even globally, these issues where there's mass reissues of things and disruptions in the recurring systems that we have.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: So this may fall into the small thing category, but last quarter you added iOS sign-ups. Any impact, surprising one way or another, from that?
componenttext: So this may fall into the small thing category, but last quarter you added iOS sign-ups. Any impact, surprising one way or another, from that?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: We've always been able -- customers have always been able to sign up on iOS, but they had to do it in the mobile web Safari browser and now they can do it in app. And it's a positive. It's not transformational, but it's really nice positive. And in partic
componenttext: We've always been able -- customers have always been able to sign up on iOS, but they had to do it in the mobile web Safari browser and now they can do it in app. And it's a positive. It's not transformational, but it's really nice positive. And in particular, in new markets as we expand around the world where we're less known and less trusted, the comfort for customers in terms of using Apple payment mechanism versus entering their international credit card information is helpful. So think of it as one more in our long list of great payment options that we have.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Reed, I want to come back to the outlook and the Q1 guidance in particular, starting with international. You mentioned in the letter the 2016 markets are -- you're playing the long game here, but the guidance is obviously impressive and well above expecta
componenttext: Reed, I want to come back to the outlook and the Q1 guidance in particular, starting with international. You mentioned in the letter the 2016 markets are -- you're playing the long game here, but the guidance is obviously impressive and well above expectations. So is some -- are the 2016 launches a big contributor to what you're expecting in Q1 and sort of for the year internationally? Or is this continued momentum building on the existing markets? Any color you can share there?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's a lot of both. I mean, obviously our global guides for over 6 million net additions will be a record for Netflix, and so we're super excited about that. And what's amazing is we're seeing some of our new shows like Making a Murderer not only be
componenttext: Yes, it's a lot of both. I mean, obviously our global guides for over 6 million net additions will be a record for Netflix, and so we're super excited about that. And what's amazing is we're seeing some of our new shows like Making a Murderer not only be huge here in the U.S., but it's emerging as a big hit around the world for us. And you kind of expect Jessica Jones to carry internationally. What's been phenomenal about Ted's team programming is that these more unusual content titles have also had great draw around the world.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And let me just ask for the U.S., just to pick up on David's comment with the next 50 million, so what are you doing as a management team, maybe to Ted, on the content side? What is your research telling you about the people who actually don't have Netfli
componenttext: And let me just ask for the U.S., just to pick up on David's comment with the next 50 million, so what are you doing as a management team, maybe to Ted, on the content side? What is your research telling you about the people who actually don't have Netflix today? What -- is there some genre that's not being addressed well enough? Is there a distribution decision you guys need to make to go after that? What are you doing to maybe go after that other opportunity in the U.S. market?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, David's a big thinker, so he's thinking about the next 50 million. I'll stick with the next 5 million. And when we can clearly see the next 5 million, it's -- I've been hearing a lot about it but nothing yet has compelled me to join. And so the big
componenttext: Well, David's a big thinker, so he's thinking about the next 50 million. I'll stick with the next 5 million. And when we can clearly see the next 5 million, it's -- I've been hearing a lot about it but nothing yet has compelled me to join. And so the big driver is getting people excited about whatever title we have and then making it easy for them to join. So whether it's integrating in the smart TV or integrated into the MVPD set-top or the Apple TV, those are the things that, Ben, make it easy to fulfill that desire. The underlying desire is for these new titles, which is why we're so excited about the year coming and the content that Ted's team has put together. So maybe you could talk about some of the big hallmarks we have in the next few months?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
