As a percentage of our spend, original spending is growing. But as an absolute, their licensing dollars are continuing to grow as well. And Fox is an important vendor for us, just like they all are, and we're also a very important source of revenue for them.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, if that rhetoric was less intense, if they weren't out there saying, "Look, we're going to stop selling to SVOD," would you be pulling back on original spending?
componenttext: I mean, if that rhetoric was less intense, if they weren't out there saying, "Look, we're going to stop selling to SVOD," would you be pulling back on original spending?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I think we've -- the positives that have come from original spending have been tremendous in terms of our international growth, in terms of really distinguishing and differentiating Netflix from an explosion of SVOD services.
componenttext: No. I think we've -- the positives that have come from original spending have been tremendous in terms of our international growth, in terms of really distinguishing and differentiating Netflix from an explosion of SVOD services.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then what do you think about the Marvel relationship? Do you see expanding that one? Or is that going to sort of stay steady where it is right now?
componenttext: And then what do you think about the Marvel relationship? Do you see expanding that one? Or is that going to sort of stay steady where it is right now?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a pretty expensive relationship already. I mean, we have 5 season -- 5 different series going in. We just announced yesterday that we're going to a second season of Jessica Jones. So when you look at those 5 series with multiple seasons plus the cros
componenttext: It's a pretty expensive relationship already. I mean, we have 5 season -- 5 different series going in. We just announced yesterday that we're going to a second season of Jessica Jones. So when you look at those 5 series with multiple seasons plus the crossover season of The Defenders, it's a huge commitment. And all the way, along the way, you're going to be introducing new characters who have the potential to spin off and grow that relationship even further. So it's very important for Marvel. It's very important for Disney.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And for us.
componenttext: And for us.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And for us, absolutely.
componenttext: And for us, absolutely.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just, Ted, sticking with you on content. Why the call out of family programming emphasis in the letter? Any comment around sort of what you're doing maybe differently there? And now that you have a quarter behind you with some of your movies in the market
componenttext: Just, Ted, sticking with you on content. Why the call out of family programming emphasis in the letter? Any comment around sort of what you're doing maybe differently there? And now that you have a quarter behind you with some of your movies in the market, what did you learn? How does that change your appetite around film?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we -- the reason we called that out is to acknowledge that there is a large volume of, specifically, of kids programming coming out. When normally people think of Netflix original programming, they've been thinking about our sophisticated dramas and
componenttext: Well, we -- the reason we called that out is to acknowledge that there is a large volume of, specifically, of kids programming coming out. When normally people think of Netflix original programming, they've been thinking about our sophisticated dramas and adult comedies more so than our kids programming. But quietly, we've been amassing a very big selection of original kids programming in Netflix. Kidscreen Magazine just voted Netflix the #1 outlet for kids programming on television, which we're really proud of, and that's going to continue to grow. And we're just -- we're also looking to grow categories like Fuller House, which are programming that are watched together: parents watching their kid -- a show that their kids love, that they just don't tolerate but they enjoy too. And it's a really underserved market, and that's why we called that out specifically. And on the movies side, it was a great first swing, I think, with Ridiculous Six and Beasts of No Nation. Beasts of No Nation is in the discussion about the Oscars, didn't quite make it there, but picked up nominations in almost every other category. The viewing we're thrilled with around the world and have been continued to be thrilled with, as we've expanded into new territories. Both Ridiculous Six and Beasts of No Nation are watched in huge numbers in all of our new territories. So we're really excited by it, and we've got an aggressive slate in '16 to keep pushing on it.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just shifting over to the hours data, Reed, that you gave in Las Vegas and then some in the letter. This comes up kind of every quarter, people trying to understand the penetration growth curve in these international markets. So if you look at the Eur
componenttext: And just shifting over to the hours data, Reed, that you gave in Las Vegas and then some in the letter. This comes up kind of every quarter, people trying to understand the penetration growth curve in these international markets. So if you look at the European markets where you gave the subscriber number last fall, I think penetration grows relatively light so far, certainly versus, say, the U.K., which was much stronger. What are you guys doing, maybe you and David, as you think about trying to accelerate the growth in some of these markets that had been tougher out of the gate? And what are the characteristics that we as investors and analysts should look at in these markets to understand the dynamics that drive these growth rates over time?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: The first year in the U.K. was a really tough market. So it's usually successful for us now, but it's not true that it always was. We saw the same thing in Brazil for different reasons. So being light in the beginning doesn't worry us a bit. And what we'v
componenttext: The first year in the U.K. was a really tough market. So it's usually successful for us now, but it's not true that it always was. We saw the same thing in Brazil for different reasons. So being light in the beginning doesn't worry us a bit. And what we've seen in market after market like Spain, Italy, France, Germany, is this building momentum as we do more and more local content. We've got this amazing show, Marseille, coming out in May that I think will really uplift the way our French members think about us and nonmembers in particular, so we're really looking forward to that. So it's a natural building cycle, and I think the way you should model it is pretty consistent growth in all of the territories. The variation is pretty modest, again, if you time adjust it from whenever we launch.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just on your time spent number, I think we calculated in the fourth quarter, anyway, about a 12% increase per average sub year-over-year, which is impressive given you added a lot of new international markets. Anything you can tell us about sort of th
componenttext: And just on your time spent number, I think we calculated in the fourth quarter, anyway, about a 12% increase per average sub year-over-year, which is impressive given you added a lot of new international markets. Anything you can tell us about sort of the highest or -- versus the lowest and whether all markets are still growing? It would appear that the U.S. is still growing, which is impressive. Maybe you could talk about that a little bit.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we're continuing to invest more in content, more in platforms in terms of the performance and the speed and the service is growing. So I think it's natural that we're continuing to grow on all those dimensions on the per membership basis as the serv
componenttext: Well, we're continuing to invest more in content, more in platforms in terms of the performance and the speed and the service is growing. So I think it's natural that we're continuing to grow on all those dimensions on the per membership basis as the service matures and the idea. Think about smartphone usage now compared to 10 years ago. Of course, the number of smartphones is up, but the usage and utility is up. And I think we've only scratched the surface. Netflix is a tiny percentage of all video viewing today. So we have tremendous potential growth ahead of us if we can continue to execute, if we could continue to produce great shows, to have this global launch with no snafus. It's a lot of hard execution, but the market potential is really quite large.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would only add that you -- the more content that we're adding, the more likely you're going to land on a show that somebody can't live without. And I think that's what we keep saying is we're expanding in not just the volume of content, but also the bre
componenttext: I would only add that you -- the more content that we're adding, the more likely you're going to land on a show that somebody can't live without. And I think that's what we keep saying is we're expanding in not just the volume of content, but also the breadth of genres that we're covering in our original shows and our original movies.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Reed, when we talked a couple of weeks ago, I'd envision India, you called out Philippines, Saudi Arabia, as particularly important markets for you. Anything else you want to sort of emphasize in terms of the 130-plus countries you rolled out a couple wee
componenttext: Reed, when we talked a couple of weeks ago, I'd envision India, you called out Philippines, Saudi Arabia, as particularly important markets for you. Anything else you want to sort of emphasize in terms of the 130-plus countries you rolled out a couple weeks ago?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, those are a number of countries that have language match. So Philippines, a lot of people speak English. We have English-language content. We have subtitles in Arabic. We've translated our service in Arabic, so that's a good match for Saudi Arabia.
componenttext: Well, those are a number of countries that have language match. So Philippines, a lot of people speak English. We have English-language content. We have subtitles in Arabic. We've translated our service in Arabic, so that's a good match for Saudi Arabia. And then in much of the world, Russia, Poland, Central and Eastern Europe, we're still only in English. So we've got a ways to go over the next 2 years. We'll keep adding more languages and make the service more relevant. So we look at it as sort of 2 categories where we've got language match and where we don't yet. We're seeing both growth, but more substantial growth in those obviously where we have language match. And then beyond language, we have work to do on payments in terms of in each country, there are often local payments or different traditions around payments that we'll start to work on. So think of it as we've really begun on the international or global expansion rather than it's all sewed up and we're all complete on it.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: [indiscernible] Reed, we've had 2 weeks, right? So we've been 2 weeks in terms of that launch.
componenttext: [indiscernible] Reed, we've had 2 weeks, right? So we've been 2 weeks in terms of that launch.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And what are you thinking about as you move into markets where mobile Internet is sort of the dominant way that people get online? Traditionally, people are watching you on a connected TV. What happens when they're used to watching or consuming things on
componenttext: And what are you thinking about as you move into markets where mobile Internet is sort of the dominant way that people get online? Traditionally, people are watching you on a connected TV. What happens when they're used to watching or consuming things on a phone?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, same thing. You just watch Netflix on the phone just like you watch YouTube on the phone. A lot of that phone viewing is on WiFi because of the data charges. And then what you do on the cellular networks is try to have the most efficient video codecs
componenttext: Yes, same thing. You just watch Netflix on the phone just like you watch YouTube on the phone. A lot of that phone viewing is on WiFi because of the data charges. And then what you do on the cellular networks is try to have the most efficient video codecs you can have, and we're working hard on that. But think of it as it's the same way that people use other Internet video services like YouTube.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, I want to come back and maybe talk a little bit on the numbers. Can you update us on your expected cash burn for '16 and then help us understand the relationship between content on the -- cost on the P&L versus cash as we move through this year, ma
componenttext: David, I want to come back and maybe talk a little bit on the numbers. Can you update us on your expected cash burn for '16 and then help us understand the relationship between content on the -- cost on the P&L versus cash as we move through this year, maybe into 2017?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, there's no change here. So we've said before that we're on pace to burn about $1 billion of cash, mostly on our branded or originals content. That ratio of cash to P&L is about 1 3 to 1 4, and that continues to hold. So you see that it will run up in
componenttext: Yes, there's no change here. So we've said before that we're on pace to burn about $1 billion of cash, mostly on our branded or originals content. That ratio of cash to P&L is about 1 3 to 1 4, and that continues to hold. So you see that it will run up in a peak in certain quarters if we take delivery of a lot of original content and then runs back down. But I think the 1 3 to 1 4 range of cash to P&L expense will continue to hold, and so far our expectations of use of cash have been about as expected. You see in the letter that we wrote that we're on pace to use about $1 billion and maybe a little more this year. But we upsized our debt deal last year, about a year ago. And so in terms of timing, we'd be looking at later this year, maybe early next year before we would need to do any more on the capital side.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And on the U.S. margins, and I realize how you allocate cost between the U.S. and international markets may change over time, but you had a lot more operating leverage last year than perhaps we all thought heading into the year, yet you maintain this 2020
componenttext: And on the U.S. margins, and I realize how you allocate cost between the U.S. and international markets may change over time, but you had a lot more operating leverage last year than perhaps we all thought heading into the year, yet you maintain this 2020 guidance of 40% contribution margin. Is that just being conservative? Or do you expect maybe some change in amortization rates to slow the margin expansion down? What color can you give us about the pace of U.S. margins?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, not the latter. I would say there are a couple of points on this. One is that to the extent that we launched rest of the world and it was a little earlier than maybe 24 months ago that we would have been fully global or near fully global, I would sa
componenttext: Well, not the latter. I would say there are a couple of points on this. One is that to the extent that we launched rest of the world and it was a little earlier than maybe 24 months ago that we would have been fully global or near fully global, I would say the U.S. P&L did receive a little bit of relief, right? But that's a onetime thing, and that sort of goes away. The second point is we continue to add content and add it at an efficient level. I mean, we look at the hours viewed and what is generated by the content versus the cost. And we continue to see new additions even in the U.S. and markets that are -- have been in place for 4 to 5 years now. We continue to see viewership, and Ted talked a little bit about engaging new audiences. You'll see us do that. So I think for the foreseeable future, we think we can grow both margin and grow the content spend even in markets in the U.S.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Back to international, I know you guys aren't going to offer any more guidance on when you might go into China. But when and if you do, do you imagine that you're going to have to restrict or alter the catalog based on censorship or other issues with the
componenttext: Back to international, I know you guys aren't going to offer any more guidance on when you might go into China. But when and if you do, do you imagine that you're going to have to restrict or alter the catalog based on censorship or other issues with the Chinese market?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the standards, at least today, they're fluid, that government uses restrict like Game of Thrones reportedly is -- had 10 or 15 minutes from any episodes cut from it. And so there are issues conforming to those local standards. That's true of all of t
componenttext: Yes, the standards, at least today, they're fluid, that government uses restrict like Game of Thrones reportedly is -- had 10 or 15 minutes from any episodes cut from it. And so there are issues conforming to those local standards. That's true of all of the Western content that's produced as well as the Chinese content of that market. So we'll be on a level playing field with all other services.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And on the same territory, would you have to enter via a JV or is there some way you could enter China without doing a JV?
componenttext: And on the same territory, would you have to enter via a JV or is there some way you could enter China without doing a JV?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: There's all different flavors, if you look at how Disney Life or iTunes or others have done. So we're talking to different partners, building the relationships. But again, as I mentioned a few days ago, we have a very long-term look, and this could be man
componenttext: There's all different flavors, if you look at how Disney Life or iTunes or others have done. So we're talking to different partners, building the relationships. But again, as I mentioned a few days ago, we have a very long-term look, and this could be many years of discussions or it could happen faster than that. We're going to take our time. And the clearest example is really the iPhone, which took many years for Apple to get approval for that, and now it's a very large business for Apple. And so our view is if we're looking out for the business a decade from now, we should just be very patient and continue to build those relationships and listen and learn. So we're in no hurry. And most of our time and effort right now is going in how do we build the Japanese market, how do we build the Philippines market, how do we build the Saudi Arabian market, markets that are open to us and available right now.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I want to ask about content spending, maybe for David and Ted to comment on. We presume a relation between subscriber growth and content spend is not linear going forward. So as you guys think about growing the U.S. business, how should we think about the
componenttext: I want to ask about content spending, maybe for David and Ted to comment on. We presume a relation between subscriber growth and content spend is not linear going forward. So as you guys think about growing the U.S. business, how should we think about the pace of growth in content spending? And Ted, is the 50-50 original-acquired ratio still your long-term expectation? Or have the relationships with the vertically integrated media companies maybe altered that at all?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me take the first part and then I'll throw it to Ted. So we'd say, Ben, it is true that once you get to $4 billion of spend, the rate of growth is going to slow down. So that is definitely true on the U.S. side. But back to my earlier comment, we stil
componenttext: Let me take the first part and then I'll throw it to Ted. So we'd say, Ben, it is true that once you get to $4 billion of spend, the rate of growth is going to slow down. So that is definitely true on the U.S. side. But back to my earlier comment, we still think that there's great content to be added to the U.S. service that is efficient, that will continue to increase the competitiveness and attractiveness of the offering in the U.S. So we're going to continue to add to that, to that service. It's at a slower rate of growth, but it continues to grow. And in time, it's not true yet, but in time, we will be adding more of our original branded content than our licensed content. So today we've been adding both. We've been growing originals rather quickly. We'll continue to grow originals quickly, but you're seeing a lot of that added to the U.S. market. And to the extent that we're successful, and Ted, maybe this is a good transition to you, about finding content that works across markets, there'll be a blurring of the lines between what is really U.S. content and what is international content and vice versa.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, I think the art of this is going to be to doing something that doesn't feel homogenized for the world that still feels like great programming for everybody. And then we've had tremendous success so far, like I said, with Narcos, a primarily S
componenttext: Yes, I mean, I think the art of this is going to be to doing something that doesn't feel homogenized for the world that still feels like great programming for everybody. And then we've had tremendous success so far, like I said, with Narcos, a primarily Spanish-language show, working in countries that speak every different language. And Making a Murderer, as Reed pointed out, in many parts of the world, these kind of True Detective documentaries are incredibly popular in prime time television. So we're pleased to see these continue to be real global genres. What you asked about, about our suppliers, and I think confrontation is probably overstated, but there's a lot of rhetoric going around right now about how quickly and how aggressively people will license. It's still a very competitive business. And I think what happens is that people sell their programming to the highest bidder. And if we're that bidder, we get the programming. And if we -- and if someone else is, they'll get the programming. And that's true today and that was true 5 years ago. So I think what's happening now is we're very pleased with the results of the original spend, and that's what's driving it up, not a fear of being cut off on either end.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Ted, just on that point, what should we glean from your DreamWorks extension? Obviously, that's a family genre, and I think it's kind of an output deal. You could correct me if I'm wrong. I know you don't like output deals. And then on the same side,
componenttext: And Ted, just on that point, what should we glean from your DreamWorks extension? Obviously, that's a family genre, and I think it's kind of an output deal. You could correct me if I'm wrong. I know you don't like output deals. And then on the same side, the CW renewal has not happened. I think that deal is sort of still out there. Is that an example where you can get something done with an independent studio but not with a vertically integrated one?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I mean, the DreamWorks is not an output in the traditional sense, meaning that we agreed to certain levels of programming, but we work together in what that programming is going to be and developing those shows along with DreamWorks. And we've been th
componenttext: No, I mean, the DreamWorks is not an output in the traditional sense, meaning that we agreed to certain levels of programming, but we work together in what that programming is going to be and developing those shows along with DreamWorks. And we've been thrilled with the results. Those -- we took it into more territories and expanded the number of years of programming that will come through that deal because it's been working great. And I think on the CW deal, it's just in the process of negotiation. It's not behind in any normal process. And as you know, it's a time-honored tradition to negotiate in the press, so you're seeing some of that from them and right now, it's just in the process of negotiation. You should also keep in mind that no matter what happens in the CW deal is the programming that's currently there remains with us through the run of those series. So it's not like we're going to wake up one day without the programming. And we'd like to make that deal work. It's great programming. We have a great relationship with CBS and Warner Bros. on that deal, and we'd like to continue it.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Reed, you said you didn't think Time Warner should spin out HBO. But if they ignore your advice, does that change your view of the way HBO would be -- would act as a global competitor for you if you think they have ability to do things outside of Time War
componenttext: Reed, you said you didn't think Time Warner should spin out HBO. But if they ignore your advice, does that change your view of the way HBO would be -- would act as a global competitor for you if you think they have ability to do things outside of Time Warner they can't do within Time Warner?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: HBO has been a great competitor, one we admire for a very long time. You might have seen the recent news that they now have offering HBO Now direct to consumer in multiple new nations. They started just in the Nordics, then some countries in Latin America
componenttext: HBO has been a great competitor, one we admire for a very long time. You might have seen the recent news that they now have offering HBO Now direct to consumer in multiple new nations. They started just in the Nordics, then some countries in Latin America, now in Spain. So they will be a formidable global competitor over time, again, independent of their ownership.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then speaking of competitors, Ted, want to offer a theory about why your competitors at NBC and Fox and other networks spend a lot of time talking about you last week at the Critics Association?
componenttext: And then speaking of competitors, Ted, want to offer a theory about why your competitors at NBC and Fox and other networks spend a lot of time talking about you last week at the Critics Association?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: It might just be putting up a shiny object to deflect and talk about Netflix instead of what's going on in their own networks these days. But I really couldn't tell you why. It was -- NBC was a particular puzzle both -- mostly because they used as an exam
componenttext: It might just be putting up a shiny object to deflect and talk about Netflix instead of what's going on in their own networks these days. But I really couldn't tell you why. It was -- NBC was a particular puzzle both -- mostly because they used as an example a show that they produced for us to try to illustrate how -- what was and wasn't working with some data that didn't feel very true to us. So [indiscernible] surprised. It surprised everybody at NBC too, I think.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's just a tactical miss, which is kind of funny in the press. It's...
componenttext: I think it's just a tactical miss, which is kind of funny in the press. It's...

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Does The Talent or anyone else still ask for numbers? Or are they happy now or accustomed [indiscernible]?
componenttext: Does The Talent or anyone else still ask for numbers? Or are they happy now or accustomed [indiscernible]?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. If you follow the coverage from the TCA, most of them offered up that they're very happy with the relationship and not to be under the kind of weekly ratings pressure that wouldn't matter much to the success anyway. So they're happy not to focus on it
componenttext: No. If you follow the coverage from the TCA, most of them offered up that they're very happy with the relationship and not to be under the kind of weekly ratings pressure that wouldn't matter much to the success anyway. So they're happy not to focus on it.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Coming back to David on some of the financials. David, I think you said at CES or at your presentation out in Las Vegas, about 120 million of loss a quarter internationally. I just want to level set, make sure that's the right way we should be thinking ab
componenttext: Coming back to David on some of the financials. David, I think you said at CES or at your presentation out in Las Vegas, about 120 million of loss a quarter internationally. I just want to level set, make sure that's the right way we should be thinking about the year. And then on raising more capital, you mentioned in the letter you're looking at lowering your cost of capital, which we presume would have been the case. What are you referring to specifically there? Are some of the gyrations in the high-yield market causing you to think about raising capital differently than you have in the past?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: So in the first question, you heard me right in terms of 120 million. Looking ahead, I would say there's 2 things that might alter that or -- not materially, but plus or minus 10 million, 20 million. That would be foreign exchange. I mean, we continue to
componenttext: So in the first question, you heard me right in terms of 120 million. Looking ahead, I would say there's 2 things that might alter that or -- not materially, but plus or minus 10 million, 20 million. That would be foreign exchange. I mean, we continue to have an environment where we're running deep into some pretty heavy headwinds in foreign exchange. If that continues, that might challenge that 120 million upward a little, again, 10 million, 20 million. And then the other thing is just carving out a little bit of room for us. Like I said, we're 14 days -- we're 2 weeks or so into a global launch. We've got lots of markets that we're in early days of setting our level of compelling and competitiveness in our service offering. This year is about investment and you'll see that. We're focused -- we're committed to a global breakeven, but we're also trying to build multiyear businesses in many of these markets. So if we see opportunities, I think there's a little bit of room for us to pursue those later in the year, to pour some additional content marketing, whatever the right mixture of investment is. But it is true. It's about 120 million. It won't meaningfully depart from that too much, but it could be 10 million, 20 million within that.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then you should assume that debt instruments are similar to the ones we've used in the past. We've been very happy with those.
componenttext: And then you should assume that debt instruments are similar to the ones we've used in the past. We've been very happy with those.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sorry, Ben, on your last question, nothing's changed there other than our confidence that we'll continue to drive some meaningful profit into '17, '18. And to the extent that people are focused on backward-looking financial metrics in terms of credit
componenttext: Yes, sorry, Ben, on your last question, nothing's changed there other than our confidence that we'll continue to drive some meaningful profit into '17, '18. And to the extent that people are focused on backward-looking financial metrics in terms of creditworthiness, we think that we'll become a better credit risk over time, irrespective of what's happening in the high-yield markets. Today, our bonds have traded pretty well.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can I just follow up, David, on your global breakeven point? I think operating income was down a bit in '15 versus '14. But if I look at the '16 outlook for international losses you just gave us, plus some U.S. margin expansion, I think operating income o
componenttext: Can I just follow up, David, on your global breakeven point? I think operating income was down a bit in '15 versus '14. But if I look at the '16 outlook for international losses you just gave us, plus some U.S. margin expansion, I think operating income overall should grow a bit off the '15 base, or maybe I'm thinking about things the wrong way? I just want to...

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think you're doing the right math, but I think that question is a little bit of a modeler in terms of looking at the narrow numbers. That's true in terms of the math. But in general, I would say this year is about our continued international investm
componenttext: No, I think you're doing the right math, but I think that question is a little bit of a modeler in terms of looking at the narrow numbers. That's true in terms of the math. But in general, I would say this year is about our continued international investment. We're not really focused on making sure operating grows. The operating income growth is sort of an outcome of focus on international expansion, but also committed to consolidated breakeven.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood.
componenttext: Understood.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: You guys said you're releasing people from grandfathering this spring amidst price hikes. David or anyone else, are you thinking about ways you might reach out to folks who are going to see their bill go up by $1 or $2 and keeping churn as low as possible
componenttext: You guys said you're releasing people from grandfathering this spring amidst price hikes. David or anyone else, are you thinking about ways you might reach out to folks who are going to see their bill go up by $1 or $2 and keeping churn as low as possible?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's pretty simple. I mean, we'll let them know that -- the certain date the price change takes effect. So nothing dramatic, pretty straightforward, simple stuff.
componenttext: Yes, it's pretty simple. I mean, we'll let them know that -- the certain date the price change takes effect. So nothing dramatic, pretty straightforward, simple stuff.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And Reed, while I've got you here, now you've been able to watch sort of what Amazon's doing with its bundle and Starz and Hulu, any thought about attaching yourself to any other over-the-top service in some sort of bundle?
componenttext: Great. And Reed, while I've got you here, now you've been able to watch sort of what Amazon's doing with its bundle and Starz and Hulu, any thought about attaching yourself to any other over-the-top service in some sort of bundle?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, we do direct consumer research, and we haven't been able to detect any significant take rate on those. So we'll continue to watch and learn and detect, are people on Hulu taking a lot of show time, or is it pretty much on the margin...
componenttext: Yes, I mean, we do direct consumer research, and we haven't been able to detect any significant take rate on those. So we'll continue to watch and learn and detect, are people on Hulu taking a lot of show time, or is it pretty much on the margin...

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: But you're not seeing it right now?
componenttext: But you're not seeing it right now?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're not seeing it so far.
componenttext: We're not seeing it so far.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let's talk a little bit more about the 2016 launches. Can you guys talk about how the go-to-market strategy, is it for these markets versus say prior to international markets? Maybe at a high level, operationally, when you're thinking about markets like I
componenttext: Let's talk a little bit more about the 2016 launches. Can you guys talk about how the go-to-market strategy, is it for these markets versus say prior to international markets? Maybe at a high level, operationally, when you're thinking about markets like India or parts of Africa, what's different about what you're doing here versus what we've seen before?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's extremely similar to how we launched Latin America where there's a couple countries that we focused on directly, and there's still some countries that we haven't yet visited 4 or 5 years later but we have a lot of members. So the Internet is a beauti
componenttext: It's extremely similar to how we launched Latin America where there's a couple countries that we focused on directly, and there's still some countries that we haven't yet visited 4 or 5 years later but we have a lot of members. So the Internet is a beautiful thing because of its openness. So again, it's very similar to our Latin America launch.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Anything you're doing on the payment side? Since you brought up Latin America, I think that was a challenge initially. I'm sure you've learned a lot. But what can you do proactively in some of these markets to help smooth that for the consumer?
componenttext: Anything you're doing on the payment side? Since you brought up Latin America, I think that was a challenge initially. I'm sure you've learned a lot. But what can you do proactively in some of these markets to help smooth that for the consumer?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll take that one. So I think we've got a pretty robust payments teams. So we've invested internally in building that out, getting smart in terms of the payment systems across the world. We're pressing on gift cards and prepaid cards that might open up t
componenttext: I'll take that one. So I think we've got a pretty robust payments teams. So we've invested internally in building that out, getting smart in terms of the payment systems across the world. We're pressing on gift cards and prepaid cards that might open up the market to those people that don't have access to a credit, debit card. But in rest of world, again, it's pretty early days. And I think we'll take the approach that we took in Latin America, which is just to look at our next best opportunities to open up additional pockets of the market. We've done this before not just in LatAm but in other places, and we'll continue with that playbook in the rest of the world. Our partners are another element of this, right? So Reed mentioned iOS. We'll be looking to draft off of large partners in the group in terms of iOS, Android and other options. And there's a lot of evolution going on in the payments world. I got misquoted at Citi by saying that we're interested in Bitcoin. But what I said was, it'd be nice to have in 5 to 10 years a borderless currency like Bitcoin. I think those people that are so excited about it are interested in breaking down those barriers and in using the power of the Internet and the Internet age to reduce the friction of payments that are existing today in some of these banking structures. So we'll be drafting off those long term as well. But in the near term, expect us to continue to just knock down the best opportunities in terms of adding local payment methods, credit, debit cards, drafting off partners as well.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Are you guys -- you're participating with T-Mobile on their Binge On program. Are you going to work with Verizon on I think they're calling it FreeBee thing they announced today?
componenttext: Are you guys -- you're participating with T-Mobile on their Binge On program. Are you going to work with Verizon on I think they're calling it FreeBee thing they announced today?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't know enough of the details of FreeBee. But generally, the great thing what T-Mobile is doing is making unlimited video consumption a possibility with freedom from worrying about the data caps. And the quid pro quo from the customer's standpoint on
componenttext: I don't know enough of the details of FreeBee. But generally, the great thing what T-Mobile is doing is making unlimited video consumption a possibility with freedom from worrying about the data caps. And the quid pro quo from the customer's standpoint on Binge On is that they only get DVD quality on their 4- or 5-inch screen, which when you look at the DVD quality is actually very, very good. But that's a really unique program that T-Mobile has done and it's seeing a great reception amongst our users. And we're seeing viewing going up, and I think T-Mobile is seeing some real positive benefits from it. So we hope those kind of programs expand.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Reed, can you explain why you're comfortable in participating in programs like that and how that differs from stuff you've complained about at Comcast in the past with their data caps?
componenttext: So Reed, can you explain why you're comfortable in participating in programs like that and how that differs from stuff you've complained about at Comcast in the past with their data caps?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's voluntary on the customer. Any customer of T-Mos can decide to turn it on or turn it off. That would be a big difference. And then they're not charging any of their providers. It's an open program. Many of our competitors, such as Hulu and HBO,
componenttext: Well, it's voluntary on the customer. Any customer of T-Mos can decide to turn it on or turn it off. That would be a big difference. And then they're not charging any of their providers. It's an open program. Many of our competitors, such as Hulu and HBO, are in the program also. But it's an open, no-charge program where they're really focused on trying to get the customer some optionality of limited to DVD quality and then you get unlimited viewing, which their customers are choosing in droves.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: So you don't feel that the network putting its thumb and saying we favor this kind of programming from this kind of studio or this kind of service.
componenttext: So you don't feel that the network putting its thumb and saying we favor this kind of programming from this kind of studio or this kind of service.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Correct. That's the big difference. That's right.
componenttext: Correct. That's the big difference. That's right.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Reed, why did you go with the $7.50, $8 price point in these international markets, particularly emerging markets where that's a relatively expensive price? Do you reserve the right to sort of go down market over time as well?
componenttext: Reed, why did you go with the $7.50, $8 price point in these international markets, particularly emerging markets where that's a relatively expensive price? Do you reserve the right to sort of go down market over time as well?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we're starting off definitely appealing to elites. I mean, I mentioned that in Russia and Eastern Europe, we're still in English. In Vietnam and Cambodia, we're in English. So we're serving elites. You can think of them as a shorthand as iPhone owne
componenttext: Well, we're starting off definitely appealing to elites. I mean, I mentioned that in Russia and Eastern Europe, we're still in English. In Vietnam and Cambodia, we're in English. So we're serving elites. You can think of them as a shorthand as iPhone owners. So they've paid $800 for an iPhone. They're comfortable with entertainment in English. And so for them, $8, $10 is a sweet spot price. Certainly, in future years, as we do more and more in trying to expand into the mass market, we can look at additional pricing options. But we feel good about our pricing and value for these global originals right now.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just on these international markets, there's been a lot of press coverage on the VPN situation and proxies. Maybe you can walk us through what you are doing as a company that's going to change your policy from prior periods? And could you envision a s
componenttext: And just on these international markets, there's been a lot of press coverage on the VPN situation and proxies. Maybe you can walk us through what you are doing as a company that's going to change your policy from prior periods? And could you envision a situation where that might impact your net adds because you have millions of customers in the international market that suddenly have -- went from having a fake U.S. account to having no access?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't think we'll see any impact. We've always enforced proxy blocking with a blacklist. Now we've got an expanded and enhanced blacklist. So I don't think we're going to see any huge change.
componenttext: I don't think we'll see any impact. We've always enforced proxy blocking with a blacklist. Now we've got an expanded and enhanced blacklist. So I don't think we're going to see any huge change.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just to be clear. So if you don't think there's going to be any huge change with the VPNs and other proxy workarounds, then why go ahead and do it at all? Is this purely to placate content providers?
componenttext: Just to be clear. So if you don't think there's going to be any huge change with the VPNs and other proxy workarounds, then why go ahead and do it at all? Is this purely to placate content providers?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: You can call it placate or you can call it catering to their desires, which -- they have legitimate desires. If we license content in Canada, it's not fair for us to be -- or our customers to be getting that if we've only paid for Canada. So we're trying
componenttext: You can call it placate or you can call it catering to their desires, which -- they have legitimate desires. If we license content in Canada, it's not fair for us to be -- or our customers to be getting that if we've only paid for Canada. So we're trying to pay for it all by shifting to global licenses, and we're working with content providers on that. But it's perfectly reasonable what the content owners want, and we know there'll be some people affected that are using it today, which is why we wanted to be open about it. But it's really a continuation of what we've always done now with this enhanced blacklist and some other techniques.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And remember, all of our originals are fully global. They go live in every country at the same time around the world. Increasingly, we are spending most of our licensing dollars on content that's accessible in that way. From small things all the way to bi
componenttext: And remember, all of our originals are fully global. They go live in every country at the same time around the world. Increasingly, we are spending most of our licensing dollars on content that's accessible in that way. From small things all the way to big things like the Oscar-nominated movie, The Big Short, we'll have the pay-TV window around the world so people will be able to watch that movie on Netflix wherever they are.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: In the past, you said that piracy is a major competitor. Any concern that the VPN and proxy workarounds will push some of your users back to piracy?
componenttext: In the past, you said that piracy is a major competitor. Any concern that the VPN and proxy workarounds will push some of your users back to piracy?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: If we see that, there's probably so few of them. It's not a big contributor to overall global piracy. Overall global piracy is a big problem, and we are working with all the content owners partially to be a great carat and also to have the other services
componenttext: If we see that, there's probably so few of them. It's not a big contributor to overall global piracy. Overall global piracy is a big problem, and we are working with all the content owners partially to be a great carat and also to have the other services like HBO and Amazon be great carats. And so we can work together on this antipiracy agenda.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and I think geofilter hacking and piracy are maybe distant cousins at best. I mean, I think of geofilter hacking as people hacking to pay versus piracy where people are hacking not to pay.
componenttext: Yes, and I think geofilter hacking and piracy are maybe distant cousins at best. I mean, I think of geofilter hacking as people hacking to pay versus piracy where people are hacking not to pay.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Curious if you guys can talk about where you're investing on the technology side. I think your long-term letter talked about over $700 million in tech and development in 2016. There are some comments in the letter about complexity-based encoding. What I'd
componenttext: Curious if you guys can talk about where you're investing on the technology side. I think your long-term letter talked about over $700 million in tech and development in 2016. There are some comments in the letter about complexity-based encoding. What I'd love to hear beyond the general areas you're spending money is what are you doing to reduce the required speed or bit rate that's needed to stream and enjoy Netflix? And I'm particularly thinking about the 2016 in the mobile-first markets.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the whole industry is working on these advanced versions of H.265 to be able to do very high quality encoding with small bit rates. And so YouTube's made great progress on that. We've made great progress. So I think, again, people have been workin
componenttext: I think the whole industry is working on these advanced versions of H.265 to be able to do very high quality encoding with small bit rates. And so YouTube's made great progress on that. We've made great progress. So I think, again, people have been working on efficient video encoding for 50 years. That's one of the classic computer science problems. So we're seeing good progress there. We're seeing a lot of progress on our algorithms and being able to rank videos for each person even better, being able to promote to the right person the right content. Hopefully, you've seen some of that in your own experience where the suggestions, that is the billboard at the top of the page, are more often very appropriate and something you're just dying to watch.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: What are the minimum speeds you think someone's going to need in a market like India on fixed line or on mobile to actually stream Netflix?
componenttext: What are the minimum speeds you think someone's going to need in a market like India on fixed line or on mobile to actually stream Netflix?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the minimum is around 0.5 megabit. So that's been consistent in the past. That's a fairly low-quality picture. It's around 700 or 800 kilobit to be able to do DVD quality.
componenttext: Well, the minimum is around 0.5 megabit. So that's been consistent in the past. That's a fairly low-quality picture. It's around 700 or 800 kilobit to be able to do DVD quality.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: You guys have said a few times now that Making a Murderer surprised you, its success surprised you. Can you talk a bit about sort of why you had more modest expectations for it, and whether that -- the surprise of that success has gone -- had you sort of
componenttext: You guys have said a few times now that Making a Murderer surprised you, its success surprised you. Can you talk a bit about sort of why you had more modest expectations for it, and whether that -- the surprise of that success has gone -- had you sort of rethink sort of your modeling?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it surprised me because I know so little about these things. When I met with the filmmakers and heard about the Murderer, sequence was interesting, but I thought it would be a specialty thing. I would say Ted and his team aren't that surprised. They
componenttext: Well, it surprised me because I know so little about these things. When I met with the filmmakers and heard about the Murderer, sequence was interesting, but I thought it would be a specialty thing. I would say Ted and his team aren't that surprised. They always believed in this content.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it had a -- there was something very special about it from the beginning. When it came to us, it was 7 years in the making already and this was -- came to us over 3 years ago and recognize then, even before making original docs, that they had somethi
componenttext: Yes, it had a -- there was something very special about it from the beginning. When it came to us, it was 7 years in the making already and this was -- came to us over 3 years ago and recognize then, even before making original docs, that they had something really special on their hands. The surprise is that we see it perform at the level of some of our scripted series. Even our best documentary series have done very, very well, but not performed in such mainstream numbers.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. So given that's surprising, you thought, "All right. We're going to sort of rethink how we evaluate some of our shows." Or you sort of, this is a happy success and you're happy to move on with it.
componenttext: Right. So given that's surprising, you thought, "All right. We're going to sort of rethink how we evaluate some of our shows." Or you sort of, this is a happy success and you're happy to move on with it.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, it's on the continuum of expanding our genres anyway. So it's only our second documentary series. We followed -- we started with Chef's Table, which is a very different show, and the next documentary series are probably very different from Ma
componenttext: Yes, I mean, it's on the continuum of expanding our genres anyway. So it's only our second documentary series. We followed -- we started with Chef's Table, which is a very different show, and the next documentary series are probably very different from Making a Murderer as well. In fact, it starts in a couple of weeks -- or this week, I'm sorry. Chelsea Handler's Chelsea Does will be our next documentary series.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take one more question and then let everyone go.
componenttext: We'll take one more question and then let everyone go.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Real quickly, Ted -- I guess for Ted. Your competitors report that you're, in many cases, overspending by a significant amount for original programming as well as repeats. Do you think that gap's going to continue? Do you think it's going to increase? Do
componenttext: Real quickly, Ted -- I guess for Ted. Your competitors report that you're, in many cases, overspending by a significant amount for original programming as well as repeats. Do you think that gap's going to continue? Do you think it's going to increase? Do you think eventually it's going to fall in line with what they're spending?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, first, I'd like to thank them for endorsing our spending to talent. But the truth of it is the only reason we can, in their own word -- in John's own words, have shock [ph] in our spending for a series is because we get shock [ph] in our viewing on
componenttext: Well, first, I'd like to thank them for endorsing our spending to talent. But the truth of it is the only reason we can, in their own word -- in John's own words, have shock [ph] in our spending for a series is because we get shock [ph] in our viewing on that series. To David's -- like David said earlier, the efficiency of the content spend has been great, meaning that we're spending a lot on great shows and they get a lot of viewing relative to licensed programming or relative to other programming as well. So we've been excited about it as part of -- and I think it's a competitive marketplace, and overspending is relative. I'd say if a show like The Get Down, like The Crown, which are relatively expensive shows, are successful, it's money well spent, the way it was for House of Cards and Orange is the New Black.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Out of respect for one of our longtime questioners and your colleague, Rich Greenfield, who had a question about Charter, and was it good if Charter acquires TWC for the Internet industry OTT? I'll answer proactively that I think it would be a tremendous
componenttext:
Out of respect for one of our longtime questioners and your colleague, Rich Greenfield, who had a question about Charter, and was it good if Charter acquires TWC for the Internet industry OTT? I'll answer proactively that I think it would be a tremendous positive for the OTT industry because Charter has agreed to a multiyear strong net neutrality policy, something no one else has publicly agreed to and that, that would cover not only the Charter footprint but the Time Warner Cable footprint. And that means that we, Hulu, Amazon and others can compete on an open basis. And so we think it would be a huge step forward for U.S. policy in terms of OTT.
Thank you all, Peter. Thank you, Ben. We'll talk to you again soon.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you.
componenttext: Thank you.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome to the Netflix Q1 2016 earnings call. I'm David Wells, CFO. I'm joined today by Reed Hastings, CEO; and Ted Sarandos, Chief Content Officer. Interviewing us today, will once again be Ben Swinburne from Morgan Stanley and Peter Kafka from Re/code.
componenttext: Welcome to the Netflix Q1 2016 earnings call. I'm David Wells, CFO. I'm joined today by Reed Hastings, CEO; and Ted Sarandos, Chief Content Officer. Interviewing us today, will once again be Ben Swinburne from Morgan Stanley and Peter Kafka from Re/code. Just a warning before we begin that we will be making forward-looking statements. Actual results may vary. I think Ben, you have the first question, so over to you.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Thank you. Maybe, Reed, you can start out by just reflecting on the quarterly results you guys, just delivered relative to your expectations, and maybe you could start out, in the new markets you launched in the beginning of the year and how those p
componenttext: Sure. Thank you. Maybe, Reed, you can start out by just reflecting on the quarterly results you guys, just delivered relative to your expectations, and maybe you could start out, in the new markets you launched in the beginning of the year and how those performed relative to your expectations?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. We were incredibly excited to grow the over 81 million subscribers. That's an enormous quarter for us that way. Some of it was from our expansion around the world. It's 130 countries, so there's quite a bit of variety. And remember that most of thos
componenttext: Sure. We were incredibly excited to grow the over 81 million subscribers. That's an enormous quarter for us that way. Some of it was from our expansion around the world. It's 130 countries, so there's quite a bit of variety. And remember that most of those countries, we haven't yet seen the full potential of because we're only in English and only with international credit cards. So over the next couple of years, as we further localize, we'll be able to see more opportunity. But by going so broad, we've increased our rate of learning and so we're really excited about approach and looking forward to the rest of the year.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And how did you feel the U.S. markets behaved this quarter versus your expectations? You had noted in the letter, a lot of strength from the originals that came in ahead of expectations. I'm guessing that's on gross connects, but how did the originals per
componenttext: And how did you feel the U.S. markets behaved this quarter versus your expectations? You had noted in the letter, a lot of strength from the originals that came in ahead of expectations. I'm guessing that's on gross connects, but how did the originals performed even relative to what I'm sure were fairly your barely bullish expectations in the U.S. market?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, in the U.S. market, we did about 2.25 million net adds, which is nearly identical, not only to last year but to the year before. So what you see is this continued growth and we're thrilled to keep that growth steady at between 5 million and 6 millio
componenttext: Well, in the U.S. market, we did about 2.25 million net adds, which is nearly identical, not only to last year but to the year before. So what you see is this continued growth and we're thrilled to keep that growth steady at between 5 million and 6 million net additions. And the content just keeps improving and that keeps the word-of-mouth growing. So we're very excited about that formula and what we saw in Q1.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Reed, you guys have been watching Amazon for a long time. You compete with them at least on content for quite some time. Four years ago, you predicted the economic standalone servers priced under yours, they announced that yesterday. What's your view on t
componenttext: Reed, you guys have been watching Amazon for a long time. You compete with them at least on content for quite some time. Four years ago, you predicted the economic standalone servers priced under yours, they announced that yesterday. What's your view on them now? And in particular, the announcement they made yesterday, do you think they're trying to compete head-to-head with you for subscriber dollars? Are they trying to underscore the value of prime overall?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hulu is doing some great work, Amazon is, HBO, Showtime. There are so many competitors and everyone is working hard to build the best content. And so we're seeing growth in the overall Internet TV market. Of course, that's displacing linear TV and it's na
componenttext: Hulu is doing some great work, Amazon is, HBO, Showtime. There are so many competitors and everyone is working hard to build the best content. And so we're seeing growth in the overall Internet TV market. Of course, that's displacing linear TV and it's natural that everybody is coming in as they realize that the future is Internet TV. And in terms of our shows, we're very excited about what we're doing, not only are we expanding the number of original series we're doing but we're also expanding into original movies. So again, this is all part of the natural evolution from linear TV to Internet TV.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Amazon has been talking to programmers for a while about adding linear channels, so you're looking at a scenario where they might have an offering that's similar to yours for the on-demand stuff, the mix originals and older movies and TV shows, plus curre
componenttext: Amazon has been talking to programmers for a while about adding linear channels, so you're looking at a scenario where they might have an offering that's similar to yours for the on-demand stuff, the mix originals and older movies and TV shows, plus current content live. What does that look like to you? Is it in terms of prospects of competing against that head-to-head?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're very focused on global competition. Obviously around the world, it's very fast-growing for us. We're coming towards 50-50 international, domestic revenue. And so we're focused on content that we can have around the world, which is why we're investin
componenttext: We're very focused on global competition. Obviously around the world, it's very fast-growing for us. We're coming towards 50-50 international, domestic revenue. And so we're focused on content that we can have around the world, which is why we're investing in original movies, original series so that we can have that content and also producing around the world like our French series Marcel or Spanish in Narcos. And that's very different from carrying other people's single nation networks. So that's just a very different business. It's not one we focus on a lot. We know what we want to be, which is a great global producer and distributor of content and other people will do other things. And that's fine. They may be very successful.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me throw a question out for David and/or Ted about -- thinking about the second quarter guidance internationally. There's a lot to chew on there. The number you laid out is probably below where most were expecting. I'm wondering if you could talk, Dav
componenttext: Let me throw a question out for David and/or Ted about -- thinking about the second quarter guidance internationally. There's a lot to chew on there. The number you laid out is probably below where most were expecting. I'm wondering if you could talk, David, about how you thought through putting the second quarter guide together around seasonality, some of the comp issues you talked about in the letter. And whether we're seeing more -- a sort of a more earlier than expected level of seasonality in some of these markets that are still 1 or 2 years old. And Ted, there's a narrative out of Europe in particular that the incumbents are sort of teaming up against you from a content perspective and you've got a lot of stuff coming down the pike on originals. Can you talk about your relationship with suppliers overseas since that's probably an area people have spent less time thinking through?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, I'll let David kick it out there. You could go first.
componenttext: Sure, I'll let David kick it out there. You could go first.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: In terms of thinking about the guy, just a reminder that we put in the letter, that absent the strong performance that we saw last year from the very recently launched Australia, New Zealand markets, our guide would've been up. So I think you haven't yet
componenttext: In terms of thinking about the guy, just a reminder that we put in the letter, that absent the strong performance that we saw last year from the very recently launched Australia, New Zealand markets, our guide would've been up. So I think you haven't yet seen sort of a normalized pattern of growth from us in terms of a year-on-year growth expectation across our international markets because we've been layering on our new markets as we go. So I think from our perspective, we were super happy with the results of Q1 and we wanted in Q2 that to continue and it is, but we're mindful of the fact that we've got these large blooms of launches last year and then in Q1 this year, with the rest of world markets, the Netflix global launch, that are going to continue forward because they're addressing pent-up demand. So for us, we're focused on continuing -- continued growth in those markets and that's what we're seeing and we're focused on continued improvement from an economic sense of reducing those losses. And this year, you're seeing us continue to invest but the U.S. is growing so overall, operating profit is improving as we go and into next year.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: As you say, the reaction from the broadcasters across Europe is not different than it's been anywhere else. They -- there's always uncertainty when we come to the new market. What role we're going to play? How complimentary we're going to be versus compet
componenttext: As you say, the reaction from the broadcasters across Europe is not different than it's been anywhere else. They -- there's always uncertainty when we come to the new market. What role we're going to play? How complimentary we're going to be versus competitive, and I think everyone just likes to be weigh their options in terms of their competitive strength. We're buying a lot of pan-European rights as part of our global acquisitions, which I think prime makes a bit nervous too while they're trying to figure out what the next moves will be. But again, I don't think it's that unusual. I mean, even here in the U.S., where 3 of our largest suppliers, [indiscernible] Hulu, it's probably much of the same motivation.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just as a follow-up, I don't think you mentioned, VPN changes in the letter, but that's obviously has happened. Is that impacting at all the second quarter guidance at all?
componenttext: And just as a follow-up, I don't think you mentioned, VPN changes in the letter, but that's obviously has happened. Is that impacting at all the second quarter guidance at all?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, that change was in the first quarter. It's a very small, but quite focal minority. So it's really inconsequential to us as you could see in the Q1 results.
componenttext: No, that change was in the first quarter. It's a very small, but quite focal minority. So it's really inconsequential to us as you could see in the Q1 results.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the only thing I'd add to that, Ben, is we were able to grow in the first quarter, we had a very strong U.S. growth at the same time, we had a very robust Netflix global launch. So I think it validates sort of the fact that we're seeing new demand for
componenttext: And the only thing I'd add to that, Ben, is we were able to grow in the first quarter, we had a very strong U.S. growth at the same time, we had a very robust Netflix global launch. So I think it validates sort of the fact that we're seeing new demand for Netflix in those markets.

componenttext: Sure.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Currently. What about live in general? There's a lot of interest, Twitter, YouTube, Facebook in particular, the idea on broadcasting live video over the Internet. You guys have tweaked your model a little bit or will tweak between Chelsea Handler, where y
componenttext: Currently. What about live in general? There's a lot of interest, Twitter, YouTube, Facebook in particular, the idea on broadcasting live video over the Internet. You guys have tweaked your model a little bit or will tweak between Chelsea Handler, where you're going to sort of move away from the dumping out all the stuff in one go and sort of staggering it. So if you're not doing live -- if you don't plan to do live now, why not consider it down the pipe?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sorry, to correct you, we have never dumped anything. We have given it a proper platform with all of the great content that it deserves.
componenttext: Sorry, to correct you, we have never dumped anything. We have given it a proper platform with all of the great content that it deserves.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: A full release. So Chelsea is viewed live, and that we're going to be putting it up to our subscribers just a couple of hours after its recorded live in front of an audience. There's not a technological reason we wouldn't want to go live. But you should t
componenttext: A full release. So Chelsea is viewed live, and that we're going to be putting it up to our subscribers just a couple of hours after its recorded live in front of an audience. There's not a technological reason we wouldn't want to go live. But you should think about our brand proposition is very much about on-demand. So to the extent that watching on-demand is better than watching live, we bring a ton of value to it. And other people doing live, I think it's great. It's not a further expansion of Internet television to include live. We don't have to do everything to be part of that expansion.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And rather than invest in things like live sports, we're investing in things like The Crown, which is just an epic production, and maybe you could talk a little bit about that.
componenttext: And rather than invest in things like live sports, we're investing in things like The Crown, which is just an epic production, and maybe you could talk a little bit about that.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we're being shot right now in the U.K. We've previewed some footage of it to the European press last week. They just love it. It's a massive cast, a massive production that would tell the life of Queen Elizabeth, starring Clara Foy, as the queen and
componenttext: Yes, we're being shot right now in the U.K. We've previewed some footage of it to the European press last week. They just love it. It's a massive cast, a massive production that would tell the life of Queen Elizabeth, starring Clara Foy, as the queen and we'll follow her live through her relationships with the Prime Ministers, all the way through to current times. So it's a very -- it's those kind of things that we think are massively global that we can produce on a larger scale than anybody else that we really think we can win the day on.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, coming back to the second quarter guidance again, but on the U.S. market, why did you decide to delay or spread the on grand father and through the remainder of the year? You mentioned you don't expect much of an impact, but you decided to sort of
componenttext: David, coming back to the second quarter guidance again, but on the U.S. market, why did you decide to delay or spread the on grand father and through the remainder of the year? You mentioned you don't expect much of an impact, but you decided to sort of spread it out. Maybe you can just walk us through what you've learned in your testing so far and the thought process around that?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think we've always been a testing company. So perhaps there shouldn't be an expectation that this will be a gradual in terms of layering that out. We've got a number of markets that are coming off on grandfather in not just the U.S., and some of those a
componenttext: I think we've always been a testing company. So perhaps there shouldn't be an expectation that this will be a gradual in terms of layering that out.
