We've got a number of markets that are coming off on grandfather in not just the U.S., and some of those are times, 3 to 4 months as we go. So I think it's just about messaging it, that was important to us to make sure that subscribers sort of knew that this was happening and to put it in front of them, and that's what we're going to do. And we want to do that, do right by the consumer and do right by Netflix as we go. So I think we're just taking our time to do that.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Ted, what are you seeing in terms of the efficiency of your spend as you continue to build on originals? And I'm curious, you've had more data points around film results, have more coming up. How are the film's performing relative to your expectations
componenttext: And Ted, what are you seeing in terms of the efficiency of your spend as you continue to build on originals? And I'm curious, you've had more data points around film results, have more coming up. How are the film's performing relative to your expectations and relative maybe to the spending on TV series?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the efficiencies are a little hard to match because you've got a couple of our hours of viewing versus 13 -- 10 to 13 hours of viewing on the series. But relative to how we license other movies, we've been pretty happy with the direction that it's g
componenttext: Well, the efficiencies are a little hard to match because you've got a couple of our hours of viewing versus 13 -- 10 to 13 hours of viewing on the series. But relative to how we license other movies, we've been pretty happy with the direction that it's going. We have a few films under our belt. What we're really looking at is how broadly people engage with them, how do they play around the world. All those data points have been really positive and as we keep going, I think that, that content can be as efficient as a series relative to other films. So we're still learning as we go though.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you guys talk about your M&A strategy? Are you looking at Paramount, which may be partly for sale? What about Stars, which is unofficially for sale? And if you don't want to comment on those in particular, what are you thinking about as you consider l
componenttext: Can you guys talk about your M&A strategy? Are you looking at Paramount, which may be partly for sale? What about Stars, which is unofficially for sale? And if you don't want to comment on those in particular, what are you thinking about as you consider large acquisitions?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's been 15 years we've been public and 20 existing, and we've done no M&A. So I think that probably speaks for itself.
componenttext: It's been 15 years we've been public and 20 existing, and we've done no M&A. So I think that probably speaks for itself.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And as you guys push into the studio film business, making your own movie, because it makes sense to sort of at least do a smaller acquisition that would help you sort of get some of those competencies in in-house?
componenttext: And as you guys push into the studio film business, making your own movie, because it makes sense to sort of at least do a smaller acquisition that would help you sort of get some of those competencies in in-house?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Peter, we've seen that not just on the films, but on several of our series whether Netflix is increasing in the studio and the network on those shows. So we are building that efficiency in-house. The Ranch that just premiered a few weeks ago is a Netflix-
componenttext: Peter, we've seen that not just on the films, but on several of our series whether Netflix is increasing in the studio and the network on those shows. So we are building that efficiency in-house. The Ranch that just premiered a few weeks ago is a Netflix-produced show and we'll be doing a lot more of those coming on. We're building it versus buying it.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we'll just hire the people that we want to build it. That could in principle, be a constraint on our rate of growth, but Ted's been able to attract an incredible team in LA and so when you look at the growth in our originals, you can see that we can
componenttext: Yes, we'll just hire the people that we want to build it. That could in principle, be a constraint on our rate of growth, but Ted's been able to attract an incredible team in LA and so when you look at the growth in our originals, you can see that we can deliver on that, on this organic hiring basis, which of course, is much stronger for the long-term than if you try to deduce it with M&A.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Reed, can you talk a little bit about how investors and shareholders should look at various opportunities internationally? For example, Brazil is a market that may be at first blush, wouldn't appear to be right for Netflix given sort of low pay-TV penetra
componenttext: Reed, can you talk a little bit about how investors and shareholders should look at various opportunities internationally? For example, Brazil is a market that may be at first blush, wouldn't appear to be right for Netflix given sort of low pay-TV penetration, lower household income, lower broadband speeds and yet you've described that as a rocketship, you've done really well there. And yet may be other more sort of developed markets in Europe have been slower. What are the characteristics and things that are outside of Netflix's control that drives success? And what are the things you're doing that you're doing -- maybe didn't do a year ago to make sure you capture the opportunity?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: One of the major things I think is e-commerce and payment systems to the degree that there's convenient way to pay for airline tickets, for example, online. That's really helpful. But we're continuing to work with all the different ISPs, phone billing sol
componenttext: One of the major things I think is e-commerce and payment systems to the degree that there's convenient way to pay for airline tickets, for example, online. That's really helpful. But we're continuing to work with all the different ISPs, phone billing solutions, other things and we'll grow as the payment infrastructure, the e-commerce infrastructure grows. So when you think about it in the long-term, everybody around the world is going to be watching Internet video, and we want to be well-positioned so as all of these countries evolve towards Internet video that we grow with them. In some cases, that'll be 10 years, 15 years, in other cases, it'll be in the next 2 or 3 years. But it's a long-term investment and country by country, it's worked out extremely well for us. So that's why we're so invested in international expansion. We're very confident that in the long term, everybody is going to be watching TV shows and movies over the Internet and we hope to be one of the leading brands for that around the world.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And let me just ask -- go ahead, David.
componenttext: And let me just ask -- go ahead, David.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: The only thing I would add to that to the tune, and Reed would say is, we can't anticipate everything. I think 5 years ago, when we were first launching the markets, we thought maybe we could anticipate most things. But every time we've launched, there's
componenttext: The only thing I would add to that to the tune, and Reed would say is, we can't anticipate everything. I think 5 years ago, when we were first launching the markets, we thought maybe we could anticipate most things. But every time we've launched, there's been 1 or 2 things that we haven't anticipated. What we have gotten good at as a company is fast learning and fast improvement. And so I think that gives us some confidence as well that as things come up, we'll be able to address them quickly.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And remember, when you look at Facebook and YouTube, which are ad supported, but viewing and consumption is generally 80% international, 20% domestic. We've got a lot of international goals to go before we can aspire to that point.
componenttext: And remember, when you look at Facebook and YouTube, which are ad supported, but viewing and consumption is generally 80% international, 20% domestic. We've got a lot of international goals to go before we can aspire to that point.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me just pick up on a question Peter asked earlier, that's sort of talks about where Amazon has taken the bundle and taken the perspective of incumbent MVPD's. You saw surely, Reed, the DISH built in other sling or as built as a slim offer, sort of a l
componenttext: Let me just pick up on a question Peter asked earlier, that's sort of talks about where Amazon has taken the bundle and taken the perspective of incumbent MVPD's. You saw surely, Reed, the DISH built in other sling or as built as a slim offer, sort of a low price point IP delivered bundle of networks. DIRECTV's going to have 3 cheaper OTT launches later this year. We're starting to see these things proliferate more. Does that change sort of your competitive position as you think about sort of this big pricing umbrella getting smaller over the next year plus and becoming more IP?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, those are all single nation solutions, and we're really focused on local content and expanding globally. And so I don't see really that much nexus between them. Again, as we said in the letter, when you think about your own experience of what do you d
componenttext: No, those are all single nation solutions, and we're really focused on local content and expanding globally. And so I don't see really that much nexus between them. Again, as we said in the letter, when you think about your own experience of what do you do some night if you're not watching Netflix? Once in a while, it's cable television. Once in a while, it's video gaming, it's browsing Facebook, killing time on the web generally. There's so much out there. So are the only inhibitor in our growth is how great is our service? Can we make it so it's never buffering, so it always starts up instantly. So the recommendations are incredible and the content is exciting. And we can do all that. We'll continue to grow globally even though HBO or DISH or others are also growing. So their growth doesn't take away from us.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Reed, can you explain just for the record, why you guys went ahead and sort of reduced the quality of the streams on certain wireless carriers? And how that's different than the complaints you've launched against people like Comcast in the last couple of
componenttext: Reed, can you explain just for the record, why you guys went ahead and sort of reduced the quality of the streams on certain wireless carriers? And how that's different than the complaints you've launched against people like Comcast in the last couple of years?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Mobile generally has small data caps and very expensive per gigabyte charges like $10 to $20 per gigabyte supplemental. And so we wanted to save data for our users by using very tight and small in codes, especially when it's being watched on a 4 or
componenttext: Sure. Mobile generally has small data caps and very expensive per gigabyte charges like $10 to $20 per gigabyte supplemental. And so we wanted to save data for our users by using very tight and small in codes, especially when it's being watched on a 4 or 5-inch screen. And what we'll be adding going forward is an option so consumers can set they want to do extreme data saving, moderate data saving or no data saving at all. And so we're about to let the users just do it. But the advantage of doing it for people in the past was to save on -- to avoid those data plan overages that are pretty unique to mobile.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And that option you described where you can sort of opt in and sort of a quality, why is that a reaction to the stores that came out in the last few weeks?
componenttext: And that option you described where you can sort of opt in and sort of a quality, why is that a reaction to the stores that came out in the last few weeks?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, we've added lots of options over time to allow more customization. If you look, we've had one on the wired side. We just hadn't implemented it yet or rolled it out on the mobile side. But that's always been planned.
componenttext: No, we've added lots of options over time to allow more customization. If you look, we've had one on the wired side. We just hadn't implemented it yet or rolled it out on the mobile side. But that's always been planned.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Another regulatory question or I guess, an SEC question. That opens set-top box proposal that President Obama endorsed, if that goes through, what sort of changes or options does that open up for you?
componenttext: Another regulatory question or I guess, an SEC question. That opens set-top box proposal that President Obama endorsed, if that goes through, what sort of changes or options does that open up for you?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: For us, the open set-top is the Roku or the Apple TV or the Smart TV. It's a basic Internet device that runs apps, and that's what we think the future is, is that kind of broad openness. And we don't really follow very closely like the intricacies of the
componenttext: For us, the open set-top is the Roku or the Apple TV or the Smart TV. It's a basic Internet device that runs apps, and that's what we think the future is, is that kind of broad openness. And we don't really follow very closely like the intricacies of the cable set-top industry in the U.S. as opposed to these great global platforms that are IP-centric like a Samsung Smart TV.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: So it's not meaningful to you if it goes through?
componenttext: So it's not meaningful to you if it goes through?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't think so.
componenttext: I don't think so.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ted, I wanted to ask you a little bit about your relationship with your major suppliers. You, I'm sure, see or hear the rhetoric as we do growing out of Hollywood. Maybe start with Disney. How is that relationship today? They've obviously come under some
componenttext: Ted, I wanted to ask you a little bit about your relationship with your major suppliers. You, I'm sure, see or hear the rhetoric as we do growing out of Hollywood. Maybe start with Disney. How is that relationship today? They've obviously come under some pressure around ESPN and cord shaving. But your relationship with Disney is as strong as it's been? And should we expect that you may be able to expand your Marvel TV relationship, but in particular, I'd love to hear any sense of how Daredevil Season 2 is performing and performed relative to the first season with that audience built?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I mean, these have always been relatively complex relationships where you are both supplier and sometimes competitor. So in the case of Disney, they're a major supplier and they're our producing partner. They produced our Marvel Defender series. We jus
componenttext: So I mean, these have always been relatively complex relationships where you are both supplier and sometimes competitor. So in the case of Disney, they're a major supplier and they're our producing partner. They produced our Marvel Defender series. We just kicked off our fifth season of production on this show. It's a very lucrative piece of business for Disney, obviously and a great partnership in that way. And there's no way to kind of isolate the 2 sets of businesses completely. So while we -- they're a great producing partner. They're great licensing supplier, and we're always trying to figure out ways that we don't bump into one another competitively but sometimes it's inevitable. Daredevil Season 2 was fantastic. I think critics loved it. Our -- the viewing numbers have really grown, and we've added an enormous number of people to Daredevil Season 1, both because the excitement around Season 2 and there were an additional territories now that didn't have the opportunity to see the show in the first go-round. So it's been a real success and we're really excited to be in business with them. And all of our suppliers that either produce for us or license to us, and probably compete with us on some level and we're just always trying to navigate those waters very similar the way networks to one another and produce for one another.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then the changes you're seeing out there impact the timing with which you can get to your 50-50 split of server original spending and acquired? And you threaded in the letter, 5% of your spending I think today is on films. How would you fit film spend
componenttext: And then the changes you're seeing out there impact the timing with which you can get to your 50-50 split of server original spending and acquired? And you threaded in the letter, 5% of your spending I think today is on films. How would you fit film spending inside of that 50-50 mix long-term?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, right now, we're trying to complement our film selection between aggressively ramping up our global originals, but sums of people want to see it everywhere in the world. Plus licensing, we're an opportunistic, we've been doing pickups of films at fi
componenttext: Well, right now, we're trying to complement our film selection between aggressively ramping up our global originals, but sums of people want to see it everywhere in the world. Plus licensing, we're an opportunistic, we've been doing pickups of films at film festivals, particularly ones that have broader commercial appeal like next month, we have a film called the Fundamentals of Caring with Paul Rudd, that I think fans are going to really love when we launch that around the world. And then originally, we're also doing some opportunistic licensing. As you know, we picked up the Disney Pay 1 output later this year and we also like -- just in this quarter, we'll have the Minions, we'll have Goosebumps, we'll have the Transylvania -- Hotel Transylvania 2 and we'll have the film that won the Academy award for best picture, Spotlight, exclusively on Netflix in the U.S. So it'll be hard to comp against those kind of numbers as we're ramping up films because we still have a great selection of other films as well. But we're going to keep pushing on it. There's no mandate or no initiative to help quickly when we'll get there, and success, we just want to keep pushing it forward.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And later this week, we'll be releasing the fresh trailer for the duo for Adam Sandler's next film for us. I mean the trailer is incredible. I think you're going to find that this is a movie that really delivers for the Adam Sandler fans extended.
componenttext: And later this week, we'll be releasing the fresh trailer for the duo for Adam Sandler's next film for us. I mean the trailer is incredible. I think you're going to find that this is a movie that really delivers for the Adam Sandler fans extended.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And that will be global -- available globally as well in May.
componenttext: And that will be global -- available globally as well in May.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Reed, maybe Ted, if I had a plan, I can download some of Amazon's original, like its all on Amazon's original content, some of their studio license and take it with me for off-line viewing. YouTube, Red has been doing that. Why not offer that for some or
componenttext: Reed, maybe Ted, if I had a plan, I can download some of Amazon's original, like its all on Amazon's original content, some of their studio license and take it with me for off-line viewing. YouTube, Red has been doing that. Why not offer that for some or all of your content?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: We should keep an open mind on this. We've been so focused on click and watch and the beauty and simplicity of streaming. But as we expand around the world, where we see an uneven set of networks, it's something we should keep an open mind about.
componenttext: We should keep an open mind on this. We've been so focused on click and watch and the beauty and simplicity of streaming. But as we expand around the world, where we see an uneven set of networks, it's something we should keep an open mind about.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and this one is a little more feature off a distance. But how long have you managed before some combination of VR, AR, 360, I mean the stuff you see people experimenting on Facebook, YouTube, becomes relevant to what you do?
componenttext: Yes, and this one is a little more feature off a distance. But how long have you managed before some combination of VR, AR, 360, I mean the stuff you see people experimenting on Facebook, YouTube, becomes relevant to what you do?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's mostly going to be an intense gaming format for a couple of years. Due to the price of the consoles, so think of it like the PlayStation 5 or the Xbox 2 or something. It's heritage to console gaming. We'll be a lot of that market. And then ev
componenttext: I think it's mostly going to be an intense gaming format for a couple of years. Due to the price of the consoles, so think of it like the PlayStation 5 or the Xbox 2 or something. It's heritage to console gaming. We'll be a lot of that market. And then everybody hopes that it matures into something that lower cost and more ubiquitous. So I don't think it'll have direct effect on us on the next couple of years because I think the center points for VR will be other sorts of things than watching the TV show in a VR headset. I don't think that will be all very popular.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, turning to some of the financials, you gave some color for the year around contribution loses, international I think. Looking for something around $370 million for the year now, which is less than what you had articulated and had thought previously
componenttext: David, turning to some of the financials, you gave some color for the year around contribution loses, international I think. Looking for something around $370 million for the year now, which is less than what you had articulated and had thought previously. What's driving that improvement? And it sounds like that's a focus for you as you head into next year, I mean if you could spend a little bit of time talking about what's moving the international losses lower and how that may trend into '17?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's nothing more than growing revenue faster than your content spend. It's just the fact that we've got multiple markets now that are improving year-on-year in terms of growth and economics and We stack them together, and you've got a picture where
componenttext: Well, it's nothing more than growing revenue faster than your content spend. It's just the fact that we've got multiple markets now that are improving year-on-year in terms of growth and economics and We stack them together, and you've got a picture where collectively, they're covering many of the new markets that we can launch this year and in the next year or the year after. Depending on the size of that market. They could be covering them all. I think we're giving ourselves a little bit of flexibility because the more of an opportunity we see, the more we may put that into the business in terms of additional investments in content. But we feel like today that we can do all of that and still grow operating profit, which is why we can continue to make the statements about meaningful operating profit next year, but we feel like we can do both. So I don't think internally, there isn't a different plan, perhaps versus expectations people felt like there might be higher losses internationally. But it's been fairly consistent, I'd say over the last 3 to 6 months.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And do you want to talk about the weakening of the dollar and how that affects us?
componenttext: And do you want to talk about the weakening of the dollar and how that affects us?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. We did highlight this in the letter. And You live -- we live by the currency, die by the currency in terms of the fluctuations. Last year, we had a lot of headwinds, especially on the international revenue line. We had to explain sort of why our int
componenttext: Sure. We did highlight this in the letter. And You live -- we live by the currency, die by the currency in terms of the fluctuations. Last year, we had a lot of headwinds, especially on the international revenue line. We had to explain sort of why our international average subscription price was flat in certain quarters when it still was growing. This year, we're seeing the reverse of that with the weakening of the dollar, at least in the first part of the year here, where international contribution margin was benefiting from that. So we did highlight that from the letter [indiscernible]

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And David, as a follow-up, you're doing more and more global deals. Can you remind us how you're allocating licensing costs and whether that's having an impact on the sort of quarterly movements in margin you guys guided to, I think a sequential margin st
componenttext: And David, as a follow-up, you're doing more and more global deals. Can you remind us how you're allocating licensing costs and whether that's having an impact on the sort of quarterly movements in margin you guys guided to, I think a sequential margin step down in the U.S. How much is the allocation sort of issues or allocation thought process impacting those moves?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, part of that, the U.S. P&L or the U.S. contribution margin, we said this before, I'll retreat it, it's definitely benefiting through that the fact that we're launching more international markets. So the cost of that global original that Ted talks abo
componenttext: Yes, part of that, the U.S. P&L or the U.S. contribution margin, we said this before, I'll retreat it, it's definitely benefiting through that the fact that we're launching more international markets. So the cost of that global original that Ted talks about is being spread by more markets, there's some relief to the U.S. P&L. And in terms of the allocation mechanism, that's really by media market value. In the early days, we were doing it by broadband households. That was overcharging certain markets where if you had a very knowledgeable and experienced media buyer in the market, they would say, "well, there's no way that anyone would pay for this particular title at this amount in the market." So we refined that to sort of a median market value that's been validated by some third-party survey information. And I would say in general, it's vetted by our own buying team internally as to what will be paid for that particular title in the market.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then margin, being tight in Q2 is really related to the large amount of content and associated marketing from launch in those content that we're very fortunate to have.
componenttext: And then margin, being tight in Q2 is really related to the large amount of content and associated marketing from launch in those content that we're very fortunate to have.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: You guys are moving people towards a $10 month price point in the U.S. For the folks who have a $12 plan, what are they using it for? Are they using it to get high def? Are they using it for 4 streams, what's the usage for those customers?
componenttext: You guys are moving people towards a $10 month price point in the U.S. For the folks who have a $12 plan, what are they using it for? Are they using it to get high def? Are they using it for 4 streams, what's the usage for those customers?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, ultra high def forte is becoming quite popular. We're the leading source of ultra high def content now, ultra high def televisions are for sale. Best Buy and Costco. So we're seeing that ecosystem development. And if you pay $1,000 or $2,000 dollars
componenttext: Yes, ultra high def forte is becoming quite popular. We're the leading source of ultra high def content now, ultra high def televisions are for sale. Best Buy and Costco. So we're seeing that ecosystem development. And if you pay $1,000 or $2,000 dollars for a 4k TV, it's pretty natural to bump your Netflix to the $12 plan in the U.S. and about equal internationally to be able to get access to that 4K streams and see what your TV can really do.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And so that's the majority of the people who are paying $12 for using -- for the ultra high def?
componenttext: And so that's the majority of the people who are paying $12 for using -- for the ultra high def?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's right. The video quality is really the big driver. And similarly, our standard def plan, which is DVD quality, is great for people $7.99. And so that's a really strong option too. So we're not trying to buy as people. We're trying to help them make
componenttext: That's right. The video quality is really the big driver. And similarly, our standard def plan, which is DVD quality, is great for people $7.99. And so that's a really strong option too. So we're not trying to buy as people. We're trying to help them make a choice that they feel great about and that they'll stay with. So think of us as really investing at both ends the $7.99, $9.99 and $11.99.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And you spell out in your letter that the price hikes that are coming this month, next month, that you'll be staggering it throughout the year, it's not all going to happen in one fell swoop. Is that a change in plan? Or is that always the direction you w
componenttext: And you spell out in your letter that the price hikes that are coming this month, next month, that you'll be staggering it throughout the year, it's not all going to happen in one fell swoop. Is that a change in plan? Or is that always the direction you were going?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's always what we thought. It's just a little bit cautious, but it won't hurt. We don't particularly need the revenue in the short term, so it's fine to just spread it out.
componenttext: That's always what we thought. It's just a little bit cautious, but it won't hurt. We don't particularly need the revenue in the short term, so it's fine to just spread it out.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, just coming back a couple on, on the numbers, the content -- the contractual obligations were up I think $12.3 [ph] billion at the end of the quarter, which is a bit of a jump at the end of last year. Is that the Disney Pay 1 deal kicking in? Or an
componenttext: David, just coming back a couple on, on the numbers, the content -- the contractual obligations were up I think $12.3 [ph] billion at the end of the quarter, which is a bit of a jump at the end of last year. Is that the Disney Pay 1 deal kicking in? Or any other color you'd add as to why that number inflated a bit?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's really the Netflix global launch. So you've got to think about it as we're adding more content now for the rest of the world. It's our newer markets as we add more content. Those markets are growing in content spend more quickly than some of our more
componenttext: It's really the Netflix global launch. So you've got to think about it as we're adding more content now for the rest of the world. It's our newer markets as we add more content. Those markets are growing in content spend more quickly than some of our more established markets. So you combine those, and I think what you'll find is if you take that obligations number over our average membership for the quarter, it's still in that band of about 150, 160. And it really has only popped up this quarter because of that new launch, basically of Netflix global.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And remember, on Disney, we have Pay 1 today in Canada and then we'll be adding it this fall in the U.S.
componenttext: And remember, on Disney, we have Pay 1 today in Canada and then we'll be adding it this fall in the U.S.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just on the cash outlook, cash flow outlook, should we still be thinking about $1 billion burn this year? And any color for next year? And when might Netflix generate substantial free cash flow?
componenttext: And just on the cash outlook, cash flow outlook, should we still be thinking about $1 billion burn this year? And any color for next year? And when might Netflix generate substantial free cash flow?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: So no change on the outlook on either this year or next year, I would say $1 billion was a pretty good guide for both this year and next year. And in really -- on free cash flow positive, it really depends on the size of the business. It depends on how mu
componenttext: So no change on the outlook on either this year or next year, I would say $1 billion was a pretty good guide for both this year and next year. And in really -- on free cash flow positive, it really depends on the size of the business. It depends on how much more we'll continue to grow the content, which does depend on the size of the business. So now we're in the -- I'll turn the question around and say how big will we be and then I'll tell you when we'll be free cash flow positive.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's how big we'll be and then how crazy does Ted go on these productions? And what we found is this really big productions, like The Crown are just terrific for us in global brand building. And so we're very excited about being able to deploy the cash to
componenttext: It's how big we'll be and then how crazy does Ted go on these productions? And what we found is this really big productions, like The Crown are just terrific for us in global brand building. And so we're very excited about being able to deploy the cash to create shows, like that and like the Get Down that's coming this fall also.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And you should kind of think about it, there's big productions, play a much more like big blockbuster film. And the fact that, not only do they get more watching in the U.S., but they travel much better too. So you see in all this non-English-speaking ter
componenttext: And you should kind of think about it, there's big productions, play a much more like big blockbuster film. And the fact that, not only do they get more watching in the U.S., but they travel much better too. So you see in all this non-English-speaking territories, these series performed very well.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Reed, I was going to ask because I think you recorded in the Guardian, talking about or predicting spectacular budgets for a TV series. Is that -- are your comments just now reflecting that expectation? And does that suggest any reduction in the ret
componenttext: Well, Reed, I was going to ask because I think you recorded in the Guardian, talking about or predicting spectacular budgets for a TV series. Is that -- are your comments just now reflecting that expectation? And does that suggest any reduction in the return on spending that Ted is doing?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I suggest an increase in return on spending, if anything. That is when you spend on the big items, they go much, much further than a whole lot of substitutable content. So we're interested in both spectacular content and spectacular membership growth.
componenttext: No, I suggest an increase in return on spending, if anything. That is when you spend on the big items, they go much, much further than a whole lot of substitutable content. So we're interested in both spectacular content and spectacular membership growth.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: What we thought is that people globally love high production quality content.
componenttext: What we thought is that people globally love high production quality content.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's why U.S. content has traveled the world historically so well because of the production value that we're seeing. So when you see things like, next month, we'll have our 4 [ph] season of Orange is the New Black. That was kind of surprise to most people
componenttext: It's why U.S. content has traveled the world historically so well because of the production value that we're seeing. So when you see things like, next month, we'll have our 4 [ph] season of Orange is the New Black. That was kind of surprise to most people and that it didn't have any of the established movie star talent that those other shows have, but it built up just on the quality of storytelling and then the spectacular cast and the ability to get to know them better, and that as we enter its fourth season now, it's got tens of millions of fans around the world that can't wait for that show. Sometimes you can get that built-in excitement with somebody who brings their own draw and their own star power like a Will Smith movie or a Brad Pitt movie that comes out. Or a Naomi Watts starting in a TV series for Netflix or Drew Barrymore starring in the TV series for Netflix, this is a way that people can more quickly get to know some of our newer IP.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Orange is only 60 days away on June 17.
componenttext: And Orange is only 60 days away on June 17.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: June 17.
componenttext: June 17.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Does that bigger, better supersize attitude, is that going to apply to feature films that you'd like to release theatrically? Could you do a Star Wars-size production or does the pushback from the traditional sort of a distributors prevent you from really
componenttext: Does that bigger, better supersize attitude, is that going to apply to feature films that you'd like to release theatrically? Could you do a Star Wars-size production or does the pushback from the traditional sort of a distributors prevent you from really going whole hog on a movie like that?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: You should look at our original films as similar to a slate of studio films, and Fox, they have Star Wars, they also have Brooklyn and a lot of things in between and that's what we're looking at too. Whether or not a movie at the Star Wars level makes sen
componenttext: You should look at our original films as similar to a slate of studio films, and Fox, they have Star Wars, they also have Brooklyn and a lot of things in between and that's what we're looking at too. Whether or not a movie at the Star Wars level makes sense yet, we'll see. But we're ramping up. You saw recently that we announced that we're doing the next Will Smith movie called Bright, with David there directing, which is a big-budget summer movie. In fact, it'll be David and Will, as soon as they come out of Suicide Squad, they'll be -- they got their best next film and it will premier on Netflix in 2017, included in your subscription cost. So while we're all debating around big ticket day in and day paper view, we will be debuting that movie on Netflix included in your subscription cost all over the world.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: But you're not going into the ten pole strategy the big studios have gone to yet where you're doing a handful of very, very large production. You want to range them?
componenttext: But you're not going into the ten pole strategy the big studios have gone to yet where you're doing a handful of very, very large production. You want to range them?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: We've got a range of production, that's correct.
componenttext: We've got a range of production, that's correct.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then you mentioned the day in and day debate where you've seen the directors come out and say, we like the idea of playing with the window, what its called what do I think -- the screening room product. Does that mean anything to you? Is that somethin
componenttext: And then you mentioned the day in and day debate where you've seen the directors come out and say, we like the idea of playing with the window, what its called what do I think -- the screening room product. Does that mean anything to you? Is that something you guys can participate in?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, like I said, we wouldn't mind having our films available on that product, to the extent that people want to see it. Our focus is on movie lovers and movie fans, and trying to get them the content that they want at reasonable prices and in great window
componenttext: No, like I said, we wouldn't mind having our films available on that product, to the extent that people want to see it. Our focus is on movie lovers and movie fans, and trying to get them the content that they want at reasonable prices and in great windows. So for us, being able to produce our own films gives us more control over those windows and the quality of the films themselves. So screening room to me, would be a great way to get content in front of consumers, if they're willing to pay for it.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Reed, you've talked historically about a 60 million to 90 million subscriber opportunity in the U.S. And I'm just wondering as you sit here today, if you can update us on your expectations, long-term in the U.S. market, is there anything that you think is
componenttext: Reed, you've talked historically about a 60 million to 90 million subscriber opportunity in the U.S. And I'm just wondering as you sit here today, if you can update us on your expectations, long-term in the U.S. market, is there anything that you think is happening as it's happening today to get you there? For example, whether MVPD set-top distribution, broad distribution in the U.S. and say a new charter or a Comcast would really help accelerate the growth in the United States?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it helps a little bit. We're integrated with sudden link in the U.S., which is about 1 million subscribers. And of course, in Europe, we're integrated in many platforms. But think of it as the fundamental trough Internet TV. You can get it on the Sma
componenttext: Yes, it helps a little bit. We're integrated with sudden link in the U.S., which is about 1 million subscribers. And of course, in Europe, we're integrated in many platforms. But think of it as the fundamental trough Internet TV. You can get it on the Smart TV, you can get it on an Apple TV. So there's a lot of ways around it where we don't have that distribution on cable, but it's 1 more platform and all platforms are good. It's not something we need to say, get to 60 million to 90 million. And we're continuing to see just that steady growth. I mean to have 2.25 million net additions in the U.S. in Q1, basically the same as the prior 2 years. It was felt so great. So we're really excited about what the new content as a build is able to do for us.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Ted, one of the things we hear from particularly investors in Europe, is that there's a limit to how far U.S. exports can get you? I don't know whether you agree or disagree with that. But I'm just wondering if you think particularly markets like Euro
componenttext: And Ted, one of the things we hear from particularly investors in Europe, is that there's a limit to how far U.S. exports can get you? I don't know whether you agree or disagree with that. But I'm just wondering if you think particularly markets like Europe and France, who might have let's say unique content taste that you need to go more local with your spending in those markets and maybe some of the earlier international markets, for example?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I do think that what's popular in the market is much more reflection on what's been available to that market over long periods of time. So what we've been really encouraged by is how -- just how international our original series have been. So you ta
componenttext: Well, I do think that what's popular in the market is much more reflection on what's been available to that market over long periods of time. So what we've been really encouraged by is how -- just how international our original series have been. So you take a non-english-speaking territory or as we talked about Brazil earlier, and not only is it a non-English-speaking, it's a non-Spanish-speaking Latin American territory. And in the last 30 days, 8 of the top 10, most watched things in Brazil have been Netflix original series. So they're very -- these are very -- these shows play very well, throughout Europe as well. Now that being said, we think it's worth it to complement these selection by focusing on some local productions in those territories throughout Europe and throughout Latin America. So we had mentioned that on May 5, we will feel launch Marseille, which is our first French language show, filmed in France, starting Depardieu. We're also filming original series in Spain, in Brazil, in Italy. So we are definitely investing in local language content particularly in those markets that are showing some desire for more local programming but as a complement to our global offering.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And David, does that mean by default, those markets maybe lower margin than the U.S. market long term?
componenttext: And David, does that mean by default, those markets maybe lower margin than the U.S. market long term?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I don't think that's what Ted is saying, and I don't you can equate it to -- I mean, even when we're looking for a local original like Marseille, we're considering the economics of that production based on the total French diaspora. So it's not just p
componenttext: No, I don't think that's what Ted is saying, and I don't you can equate it to -- I mean, even when we're looking for a local original like Marseille, we're considering the economics of that production based on the total French diaspora. So it's not just people in France, but people outside of France that are interested in French language content. So I don't think you can -- you can't necessarily equate those 2, and we preferenced the content when we're developing those local originals for things that have potential demand outside of the original market that is produced.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our Japanese original, Hibana, for example, we'll launching this quarter and that will be available globally. So think of all that content, we're developing it locally, distributing it globally and connecting the world through that. We think that's a
componenttext: And our Japanese original, Hibana, for example, we'll launching this quarter and that will be available globally. So think of all that content, we're developing it locally, distributing it globally and connecting the world through that. We think that's a very powerful formulation that will help us grow for many years ahead.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: The Marseilles example, Gerard Depardieu is the biggest star in France and one of the biggest stars in the world. And we have about 2 million people in the U.S. who watch French language television regularly on Netflix. So that's what we're talking about
componenttext: The Marseilles example, Gerard Depardieu is the biggest star in France and one of the biggest stars in the world. And we have about 2 million people in the U.S. who watch French language television regularly on Netflix. So that's what we're talking about the scale that we can bring to a production like that, both France and Europe, but really for the world.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Say, what's your biggest non-English-speaking audience in the U.S? You said France is 2 million -- French 2 million...
componenttext: Say, what's your biggest non-English-speaking audience in the U.S? You said France is 2 million -- French 2 million...

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Probably Hispanic.
componenttext: Probably Hispanic.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I imagine it would be Hispanic.
componenttext: I imagine it would be Hispanic.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Makes sense. Reed, were you surprised that HBO said they had about 800,000 subs after about 6 months of going through head-to-head with you as a standalone product?
componenttext: Makes sense. Reed, were you surprised that HBO said they had about 800,000 subs after about 6 months of going through head-to-head with you as a standalone product?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: A little bit. I think it's a great product. I use it all the time. But then I think for many other people, they probably just subscribe to HBO and cable and they're used to that.
componenttext: A little bit. I think it's a great product. I use it all the time. But then I think for many other people, they probably just subscribe to HBO and cable and they're used to that.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: So you think the number will be higher than 800?
componenttext: So you think the number will be higher than 800?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, just because I find it -- the thing I like about HBO now is it's just easier to use. You can use it on the mobile. You can use it on many different Internet platforms, but then I'm pretty Internet-centric. So it may not be apparently, I'm not as typi
componenttext: Yes, just because I find it -- the thing I like about HBO now is it's just easier to use. You can use it on the mobile. You can use it on many different Internet platforms, but then I'm pretty Internet-centric. So it may not be apparently, I'm not as typical of the audience. But they're continuing to do great work, and what that does is just reinforce to the consumers, how great this new Internet thing is for TV. I mean it just sets the drumbeat. So I hope they continue to have more and more success.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: But there's more money coming into the market for programming, HBO, Showtime, Stars. You guys, Amazon, Crackle is getting into it, Horizon's spending a lot of money. CBS...
componenttext: But there's more money coming into the market for programming, HBO, Showtime, Stars. You guys, Amazon, Crackle is getting into it, Horizon's spending a lot of money. CBS...

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: CBS, All Access, the list goes on. That's just in the U.S.
componenttext: CBS, All Access, the list goes on. That's just in the U.S.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Does that number continue to get bigger in perpetuity? Does it retract at some point, people say, all right we sort of lower down on it and we'll pull back on spend?
componenttext: Does that number continue to get bigger in perpetuity? Does it retract at some point, people say, all right we sort of lower down on it and we'll pull back on spend?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's hard to tell. People talk about the growing content spend. But what we're able to do is find the shows and get the shows that we want, and we have to pay a lot for them. But coming back to the amount of freights earlier, they're really spectacular in
componenttext: It's hard to tell. People talk about the growing content spend. But what we're able to do is find the shows and get the shows that we want, and we have to pay a lot for them. But coming back to the amount of freights earlier, they're really spectacular in what we're doing. And I think when you see Orange, when you see the Get Down, when you see The Crown, you'll know why we're investing in what we do.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Peter, I think it's a debate around how to best monetize your content. And if you believe you can over the long haul, best monetize your content with your own app, you'll bring that back. And if you believe you can best monetize it by licensing Netflix, y
componenttext: Peter, I think it's a debate around how to best monetize your content. And if you believe you can over the long haul, best monetize your content with your own app, you'll bring that back. And if you believe you can best monetize it by licensing Netflix, you can do that.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: With the feedback initially, from members around your price points in the rest of the world markets you launched in January, obviously relatively expensive versus existing sort of pay TV or entertainment options. Any thought about changing your sort of gl
componenttext: With the feedback initially, from members around your price points in the rest of the world markets you launched in January, obviously relatively expensive versus existing sort of pay TV or entertainment options. Any thought about changing your sort of global price point approach in those markets?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: We really haven't seen price be much of an issue. But then today, we're serving english language speaking elites around in these countries. So in the model of what we're doing in targeting the high end, the price is fine. We'll see over the coming years a
componenttext:
We really haven't seen price be much of an issue. But then today, we're serving english language speaking elites around in these countries. So in the model of what we're doing in targeting the high end, the price is fine. We'll see over the coming years as we expand and we may need some flexibility eventually, but nothing in the short-term. 
And we're on our way with the last 2 questions here.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll just quickly follow up on that and I'll hand it to Peter for the last one. David, you guys are working on more local language offerings that are better payment processes, other kind of operational improvements in those rest of world markets. What's t
componenttext: I'll just quickly follow up on that and I'll hand it to Peter for the last one. David, you guys are working on more local language offerings that are better payment processes, other kind of operational improvements in those rest of world markets. What's the timing there? Should we be thinking about that for the remainder of this year or is it a longer term time frame?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's kind of both. So you'll see some this year, but really it's about the next 2 to 3 years in terms of improvement. We've only just started skimming these markets. So we'll be looking at them opportunity by opportunity, and you'll see some this year, bu
componenttext: It's kind of both. So you'll see some this year, but really it's about the next 2 to 3 years in terms of improvement. We've only just started skimming these markets. So we'll be looking at them opportunity by opportunity, and you'll see some this year, but you'll see some continue into next year and even into 2018, I think what we have is a big opportunity in front of us as Reed pointed out. Many of our Internet peers have a dramatically larger business outside of the U.S. versus inside the U.S. so we're pretty excited about that opportunity.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I think one of the more exciting parts about being in all these countries is being able to discover the next great story to tell the world. So because we're more focused thinking about India, where we're thinking about other couple of years ago, we ac
componenttext: And I think one of the more exciting parts about being in all these countries is being able to discover the next great story to tell the world. So because we're more focused thinking about India, where we're thinking about other couple of years ago, we acquired this great film called at Sundance this year, and we'll be premiering around the world in June. With that -- it really is a discovery of a great Indian director named, who I think everyone is going to be talking about him in the next few years and having that kind of global sensibility increasingly is going to help the programming for everybody, not just to subscribers in those countires.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And so in a movie like, it's an English, so it's accessible to many people. But YouTube has over 50 languages, we only have about 20. So that scales for you roughly how far we've got to go.
componenttext: And so in a movie like, it's an English, so it's accessible to many people. But YouTube has over 50 languages, we only have about 20. So that scales for you roughly how far we've got to go.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean you guys are moving into more and more kids content. Does it make sense for you to eventually own the IP yourself, instead of licensing it through Disney or Dreamworks, so you can create ancillary revenue screens?
componenttext: I mean you guys are moving into more and more kids content. Does it make sense for you to eventually own the IP yourself, instead of licensing it through Disney or Dreamworks, so you can create ancillary revenue screens?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: We do a lot of both. The consumer products addition to those projects are relative to the content value itself is pretty small. But we can look to optimize those stuff down the road. In Q2, we're launching 9 seasons of original kids content, including a n
componenttext: We do a lot of both. The consumer products addition to those projects are relative to the content value itself is pretty small. But we can look to optimize those stuff down the road. In Q2, we're launching 9 seasons of original kids content, including a new season of All Hail King Julien, which is nominated for a daytime Emmy. This year, we have 33 daytime Emmy nominations for our kids content across 7 of our different shows. So we're -- so we're really focused on building up the quality of that programming that's exclusive and original to Netflix.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: See, and Ted Sarandos, Reed Hastings, land at some point?
componenttext: See, and Ted Sarandos, Reed Hastings, land at some point?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: We were going to nominate as Kafka land. So I want to wrap up here. I want to thank Peter Kafka, who's been with us these last few calls. And he's retiring from this side job. And thank you for your involvement in this. And to all the investors, thank you
componenttext: We were going to nominate as Kafka land. So I want to wrap up here. I want to thank Peter Kafka, who's been with us these last few calls. And he's retiring from this side job. And thank you for your involvement in this. And to all the investors, thank you for your support. We had a -- just a great quarter with 6.5 million net adds, over 81 million subscribers. We cannot wait to break through 100 million subscribers sometime next year. It's going to be a big celebration. We're looking forward to it. So thank you very much.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks.
componenttext: Thanks.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome to the Netflix Q1 2016 Earnings Call. I'm David Wells, CFO. I'm joined today by Reed Hastings, CEO; and Ted Sarandos, Chief Content Officer. Interviewing us today will once again be Ben Swinburne from Morgan Stanley and Peter Kafka from Re/code. J
componenttext: Welcome to the Netflix Q1 2016 Earnings Call. I'm David Wells, CFO. I'm joined today by Reed Hastings, CEO; and Ted Sarandos, Chief Content Officer. Interviewing us today will once again be Ben Swinburne from Morgan Stanley and Peter Kafka from Re/code. Just a warning before we begin that we will be making forward-looking statements. Actual results may vary. I think Ben, you have the first question, so over to you.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Thank you. Maybe, Reed, you can start out by just reflecting on the quarterly results you guys, just delivered relative to your expectations, and maybe you could start out, in the new markets you launched at the beginning of the year and how those p
componenttext: Sure. Thank you. Maybe, Reed, you can start out by just reflecting on the quarterly results you guys, just delivered relative to your expectations, and maybe you could start out, in the new markets you launched at the beginning of the year and how those performed relative to your expectations?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. We were incredibly excited to grow to over 81 million subscribers. That's an enormous quarter for us that way. Some of it was from our expansion around the world. It's 130 countries, so there's quite a bit of variety. And remember that most of those
componenttext: Sure. We were incredibly excited to grow to over 81 million subscribers. That's an enormous quarter for us that way. Some of it was from our expansion around the world. It's 130 countries, so there's quite a bit of variety. And remember that most of those countries, we haven't yet seen the full potential of because we're only in English and only with international credit cards. So over the next couple of years, as we further localize, we'll be able to see more opportunity. But by going so broad, we've increased our rate of learning and so we're really excited about the approach and looking forward to the rest of the year.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And how did you feel the U.S. markets behaved this quarter versus your expectations? You had noted in the letter, a lot of strength from the originals that came in ahead of expectations. I'm guessing that's on gross connects, but how did the originals per
componenttext: And how did you feel the U.S. markets behaved this quarter versus your expectations? You had noted in the letter, a lot of strength from the originals that came in ahead of expectations. I'm guessing that's on gross connects, but how did the originals perform even relative to what I'm sure were your fairly bullish expectations in the U.S. market?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the U.S. market, we did about 2.25 million net adds, which is nearly identical, not only to last year but to the year before. So what you see is this continued growth, and we're thrilled to keep that growth steady at between 5 million and 6 million
componenttext: Well, the U.S. market, we did about 2.25 million net adds, which is nearly identical, not only to last year but to the year before. So what you see is this continued growth, and we're thrilled to keep that growth steady at between 5 million and 6 million net additions. And the content just keeps improving and that keeps the word-of-mouth growing. So we're very excited about that formula and what we saw in Q1.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Reed, you guys have been watching Amazon for a long time. You compete with them at least on content for quite some time. Four years ago, you predicted that Canal with stand-alone servers priced under yours, they announced that yesterday. What's your view
componenttext: Reed, you guys have been watching Amazon for a long time. You compete with them at least on content for quite some time. Four years ago, you predicted that Canal with stand-alone servers priced under yours, they announced that yesterday. What's your view of them now? And in particular, with the announcement they made yesterday, do you think they're trying to compete head-to-head with you for subscriber dollars? Or are they trying to underscore the value of prime overall?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hulu is doing some great work, Amazon is, HBO, Showtime. There are so many competitors, and everyone is working hard to build the best content. And so we're seeing growth in the overall Internet TV market. Of course, that's displacing linear TV and it's n
componenttext: Hulu is doing some great work, Amazon is, HBO, Showtime. There are so many competitors, and everyone is working hard to build the best content. And so we're seeing growth in the overall Internet TV market. Of course, that's displacing linear TV and it's natural that everybody is coming in as they realize that the future is Internet TV. And in terms of our shows, we're very excited about what we're doing. Not only are we expanding the number of original series we're doing, but we're also expanding into original movies. So again, this is all part of the natural evolution from linear TV to Internet TV.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Amazon has been talking with programmers for a while about adding linear channels. So you're looking at a scenario where they might have an offering that's similar to yours for the on-demand stuff, the mix originals and older movies and TV shows, plus cur
componenttext: Amazon has been talking with programmers for a while about adding linear channels. So you're looking at a scenario where they might have an offering that's similar to yours for the on-demand stuff, the mix originals and older movies and TV shows, plus current content live. What does that look like to you as a -- in terms of prospects of competing against that head-to-head?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're very focused on global competition. Obviously around the world, it's very fast-growing for us. We're coming towards 50-50 international, domestic revenue. And so we're focused on content that we can have around the world, which is why we're investin
componenttext: We're very focused on global competition. Obviously around the world, it's very fast-growing for us. We're coming towards 50-50 international, domestic revenue. And so we're focused on content that we can have around the world, which is why we're investing in original movies, original series so that we can have that content and also producing around the world like our French series Marseille or Spanish in Narcos. And that's very different from carrying other people's single nation networks. So that's just a very different business. It's not one we focus on a lot. We know what we want to be, which is a great global producer and distributor of content and other people will do other things. And that's fine. They may be very successful.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll throw a question out for David and/or Ted about -- thinking about the second quarter guidance internationally. There's a lot to chew on there. The number you laid out is probably below where most of we were expecting. I'm wondering if you could talk,
componenttext: I'll throw a question out for David and/or Ted about -- thinking about the second quarter guidance internationally. There's a lot to chew on there. The number you laid out is probably below where most of we were expecting. I'm wondering if you could talk, David, about how you thought through putting the second quarter guide together around seasonality, some of the comp issues you talked about in the letter. And whether we're seeing more -- a sort of a more earlier-than-expected level of seasonality in some of these markets that are still 1 or 2 years old. And Ted, there's a narrative out of Europe, in particular, that the incumbents are sort of teaming up against you from a content perspective and you've got a lot of stuff coming down the pike on originals. Can you talk about your relationship with suppliers overseas since that's probably an area people have spent less time thinking through?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, I'll let David kick it out there. You could go first.
componenttext: Sure, I'll let David kick it out there. You could go first.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: In terms of thinking about the guy, just a reminder that we put in the letter, that absent the strong performance that we saw last year from the very recently launched Australia, New Zealand market, our guide would've been up. So I think you haven't yet s
componenttext: In terms of thinking about the guy, just a reminder that we put in the letter, that absent the strong performance that we saw last year from the very recently launched Australia, New Zealand market, our guide would've been up. So I think you haven't yet seen sort of a normalized pattern of growth from us in terms of a year-on-year growth expectation across our international markets because we've been layering on new markets as we go. So I think from our perspective, we were super happy with the results of Q1 and we wanted, in Q2, that to continue and it is, but we're mindful of the fact that we've got these large blooms of launches last year and then in Q1 this year, with the rest of world markets for the Netflix global launch, that are going to continue forward because they're addressing pent-up demand. So for us, we're focused on continuing -- continued growth in those markets and that's what we're seeing and we're focused on continued improvement from an economic sense of reducing those losses. And this year, you're seeing us continue to invest but the U.S. is growing. So overall, operating profit is improving as we go and into next year.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: As you say, the reaction from the broadcasters across Europe is not different than it's been anywhere else. They -- there's always uncertainty when we come to the new market. What role we're going to play? How complimentary we're going to be versus compet
componenttext: As you say, the reaction from the broadcasters across Europe is not different than it's been anywhere else. They -- there's always uncertainty when we come to the new market. What role we're going to play? How complimentary we're going to be versus competitive, and I think everyone just likes to weigh all their options in terms of their competitive strength. We're buying a lot of pan-European rights as part of our global acquisitions, which I think probably makes them a bit nervous too while they're trying to figure out what the next moves will be. But again, I don't think it's that unusual. I mean, even here in the U.S., where 3 of our largest suppliers, [indiscernible] with probably much of the same motivation.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just as a follow-up, there is -- I don't think there is any mention of VPN changes in the letter, but that obviously has happened. Is that impacting at all the second quarter guidance at all?
componenttext: And just as a follow-up, there is -- I don't think there is any mention of VPN changes in the letter, but that obviously has happened. Is that impacting at all the second quarter guidance at all?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. All that change was in the first quarter. It's a very small, but quite vocal minority. So it's really inconsequential to us as you could see in the Q1 results.
componenttext: No. All that change was in the first quarter. It's a very small, but quite vocal minority. So it's really inconsequential to us as you could see in the Q1 results.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the only thing I'd add to that, Ben, is we were able to grow in the first quarter, we had a very strong U.S. growth. At the same time, we had a very robust Netflix global launch. So I think it validates sort of the fact that we're seeing new demand fo
componenttext: And the only thing I'd add to that, Ben, is we were able to grow in the first quarter, we had a very strong U.S. growth. At the same time, we had a very robust Netflix global launch. So I think it validates sort of the fact that we're seeing new demand for Netflix in those markets.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure.
componenttext: Sure.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is for Reed. You keep getting asked this, but I want to keep asking because the question keeps coming up. Any interest in live sports in any capacity?
componenttext: This is for Reed. You keep getting asked this, but I want to keep asking because the question keeps coming up. Any interest in live sports in any capacity?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Any interest in what?
componenttext: Any interest in what?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Live sports.
componenttext: Live sports.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Live sports. Ted, I'll let you handle that question. It worked so well for us last time. We knew it.
componenttext: Live sports. Ted, I'll let you handle that question. It worked so well for us last time. We knew it.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: There's no interest in live sports, currently.
componenttext: There's no interest in live sports, currently.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Currently. What about live in general? There's a lot of interest, Twitter, YouTube, Facebook in particular, the idea of broadcasting live video over the Internet. You guys have tweaked your model a little bit or will be tweaking it a bit with Chelsea Hand
componenttext: Currently. What about live in general? There's a lot of interest, Twitter, YouTube, Facebook in particular, the idea of broadcasting live video over the Internet. You guys have tweaked your model a little bit or will be tweaking it a bit with Chelsea Handler, where you're going to sort of move away from the dumping out all the stuff in one go and sort of staggering it. So if you're not doing live -- if you don't plan to do live now, why not consider it down the pipe?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: So, to correct you, we have never dumped anything. We have given it a proper platform with all of the great content that it deserves.
componenttext: So, to correct you, we have never dumped anything. We have given it a proper platform with all of the great content that it deserves.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: A full release.
componenttext: A full release.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
