componenttextpreview: Not a ton. We're continuing to improve the content, which is the fundamental driver of value per subscribers, how much they watch, how unique the content is, how exclusive it is. We're going to continue to improve and again with new members, we haven't se
componenttext: Not a ton. We're continuing to improve the content, which is the fundamental driver of value per subscribers, how much they watch, how unique the content is, how exclusive it is. We're going to continue to improve and again with new members, we haven't seen any effect. We changed prices to our 8, 10 and 12 last October and we've had a couple of quarters of great growth on the gross ad side. So I think this is really around change resistance. Whatever the price is for something, people don't like it to go up. But in terms of new members, which is most of what drives growth, the new pricing is working great.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And in terms of -- for David, in terms of the timing of the links that you provided to Google Trends, I think the uptick started the week of April third, so is the third through the 16th, predated when you gave earnings last quarter? What was the response
componenttext: And in terms of -- for David, in terms of the timing of the links that you provided to Google Trends, I think the uptick started the week of April third, so is the third through the 16th, predated when you gave earnings last quarter? What was the response? Was it immediate in terms of the uptick in volumes or interest, or was it somewhat delayed?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, let's keep in mind Ben -- or Scott, that the -- what we're talking about is a very small change, right? But because of the large base, a small change can result in sort of 300,000 subscribers, which is the missed that we had on domestic resulting. B
componenttext: Well, let's keep in mind Ben -- or Scott, that the -- what we're talking about is a very small change, right? But because of the large base, a small change can result in sort of 300,000 subscribers, which is the missed that we had on domestic resulting. But we did see it. We've learned through that in the past, not to overreact to immediate trend changes. So it was a swing factor when were discussing Q2 and into Q3, and sort of trying to sift through what might affect us in the quarter. We saw a little bit of it, but it was very, right before we sort of said earnings and we were on this call, 3 months ago. And so we felt it was a small factor, but it did persist through the quarter and that's one of the major driver of the lower year-on-year growth and also the lower growth versus expectations.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just sticking on the theme for around churn with another question. David, what are you seeing with the un-grandfathering members as they face different pricing options,  I mean you tested a lot over the last couple of months. What are you seeing in terms
componenttext: Just sticking on the theme for around churn with another question. David, what are you seeing with the un-grandfathering members as they face different pricing options,  I mean you tested a lot over the last couple of months. What are you seeing in terms of their choices? And how does that impact sort of your ARPU expectation? And when should we -- when would will be the grandfathering process be finished in the U.S.? Is that something in the fourth quarter? Any help there will be great.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it finishes in the fourth quarter. So it finishes about midway towards the end of November. And then in terms of their choices, especially around plan mix or whether they choose the high plan or the low plan, it's as we expected. So we continue to se
componenttext: Yes, it finishes in the fourth quarter. So it finishes about midway towards the end of November. And then in terms of their choices, especially around plan mix or whether they choose the high plan or the low plan, it's as we expected. So we continue to see folks choose the lower plan and some smaller increments, and the higher plan and some increments, so our expectation of ASP growth are still there, about consistent. What we're talking about is the population that it didn't face an immediate grandfathering choice. That's the part that was a bit of a surprise to us and continues to persist.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And does any of your data suggest you've seen anything interesting around numbers that were inactive or may be membership sharing as a result of the pricing changes?
componenttext: And does any of your data suggest you've seen anything interesting around numbers that were inactive or may be membership sharing as a result of the pricing changes?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: No on both counts so.
componenttext: No on both counts so.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. This question may have been addressed in the letter given that you gave on grandfathering commentary around international as well. But we'd be interested if you could just talk through your expectations for existing markets versus new markets and wh
componenttext: Okay. This question may have been addressed in the letter given that you gave on grandfathering commentary around international as well. But we'd be interested if you could just talk through your expectations for existing markets versus new markets and where you be in this.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, let's see. I would say that we -- the trend was across multiple markets. And as we put in the letter, it was in markets that were more highly penetrated and less highly penetrated. That's why we think it is about sort of the pricing talk that was af
componenttext: Sure, let's see. I would say that we -- the trend was across multiple markets. And as we put in the letter, it was in markets that were more highly penetrated and less highly penetrated. That's why we think it is about sort of the pricing talk that was affected. But in addition to that, we would say that our newer markets have an expectation of multi-year growth. So we know that we've got our work cut out for us, and that we hit a point where we're not adding on any new additional markets. But we are going to be seeing periods of accelerated growth and decelerated growth and we've seen that in the past where some markets sort of pick up and then moderate, and then pick up again. And I think that's what we saw in this quarter forward. We're indicating that we've got multi years just like we have in Latin America to build that market to where it has taken us, 4 or 5 years at this point, to get it there.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Reed you...
componenttext: And Reed you...

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: In new markets, in Asia and Central Eastern Europe. It's significantly different from early Latin America. It paints a pretty similar picture at least for these first 6 months.
componenttext: In new markets, in Asia and Central Eastern Europe. It's significantly different from early Latin America. It paints a pretty similar picture at least for these first 6 months.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Reed, you reiterated the $60 million to $90 million in the U.S. We'd be interested if you could add some color in terms of where do you think the friction points are, if it's content portfolio, competition, those being the 2 most significant. Where do
componenttext: And Reed, you reiterated the $60 million to $90 million in the U.S. We'd be interested if you could add some color in terms of where do you think the friction points are, if it's content portfolio, competition, those being the 2 most significant. Where do you see sources of friction and what gives you confidence still in that range?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't think there really is any friction. I mean Smart TVs are continuing to sell. Everyone's using Internet video and Internet television more and more. You see the rise of these virtual MPPDs. All of these things are building out in the Internet ecosy
componenttext: I don't think there really is any friction. I mean Smart TVs are continuing to sell. Everyone's using Internet video and Internet television more and more. You see the rise of these virtual MPPDs. All of these things are building out in the Internet ecosystem. And I don't see why 10, 20 years from now, why every American household isn't subscribing to Netflix, except for maybe competition. So we've got to stay on our toes on that basis. But think about entertainment and pay television are pretty ubiquitous. So in the Internet video, that's a pretty big step that's continuing to pay off. So you put those 2 forces together, that's why feel so good about the long-term in this market.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was going to ask about a little bit more about the guidance, David. Last quarter, you called out the comp versus Australia, which was I think a bigger one or a tougher one than we all understood. We look at third quarter, I think you have Japan and then
componenttext: I was going to ask about a little bit more about the guidance, David. Last quarter, you called out the comp versus Australia, which was I think a bigger one or a tougher one than we all understood. We look at third quarter, I think you have Japan and then fourth quarter, Southern Europe. Could you just maybe put those at least in relative context for -- versus Q2 so we can think about what those headwinds may or may not look like?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, I mean, there's always a headwind when we've had a prior launch of the large market or a market like Australia where we saw strong initial uptake. In terms of that moderating, you've got a lot of pent up demand that then sort of reverts to a more no
componenttext: Sure, I mean, there's always a headwind when we've had a prior launch of the large market or a market like Australia where we saw strong initial uptake. In terms of that moderating, you've got a lot of pent up demand that then sort of reverts to a more normal growth pattern over time. That can take several quarters, it can take 2 quarters. We can see different experiences by market. So I would say Japan was a pent up market in some respects and then starts to moderate. So that does factor into the comp. And some of our other markets may be experiencing flat or even down year on growth, it's just a mixture across that. But like I said, we've seen markets that have decelerated and then pick up again and then accelerate. So collectively, across the -- all of our basket of investments in markets, we think there is a large long-term opportunity that we're going to optimize against. And we know that we've got work cut out for some of our newer markets, but it will take time to get there.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I just want to ask you about the Olympics and where you're factoring that in or how you're factoring that into your guidance. You mentioned gross additions remain healthy, which at least to me, sounds like flat-to-up, but I'll let you comment if you c
componenttext: And I just want to ask you about the Olympics and where you're factoring that in or how you're factoring that into your guidance. You mentioned gross additions remain healthy, which at least to me, sounds like flat-to-up, but I'll let you comment if you choose. Are you assuming that impact to gross ads? And if so, is it a U.S. phenomenon or a global phenomenon in the third quarter?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: It would be global. And so you're back -- you're correctly surmising that gross ads, you can say roughly in line year-on-year. And so with an assumption of a hit from the Olympics, which largely affect us -- affects us in the past on gross ads, all our ne
componenttext: It would be global. And so you're back -- you're correctly surmising that gross ads, you can say roughly in line year-on-year. And so with an assumption of a hit from the Olympics, which largely affect us -- affects us in the past on gross ads, all our new subscribers coming in. The basket effect in terms of the year-over-year trend. We expect that to be a meaningful, small but still meaningful impact on the quarter. Negative impact.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: You haven't announced the X1 -- the Xfinity deal with Comcast. And was -- without a time line, I was wondering if you could give any clarity in terms of timing. And then more broadly, how you think about MPBT in the U.S. as a driver of subscribers in the
componenttext: You haven't announced the X1 -- the Xfinity deal with Comcast. And was -- without a time line, I was wondering if you could give any clarity in terms of timing. And then more broadly, how you think about MPBT in the U.S. as a driver of subscribers in the way that years ago, getting onto consoles and other devices actually lead to an acceleration of growth?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. We're very excited about the X1 integration. It's scheduled for the second half of this year, so between now and the end of the year. And really, we're focused on getting the integration points very smooth and the Comcast engineers are doing great w
componenttext: Sure. We're very excited about the X1 integration. It's scheduled for the second half of this year, so between now and the end of the year. And really, we're focused on getting the integration points very smooth and the Comcast engineers are doing great work on it. So I look for it later this year. It will help modestly. Again, we're more penetrated than we were before. So I don't know that it has big a breakthrough because many of those households, Comcast consoles now have a Smart TV or have a Roku, but it will certainly help. And from a user perspective to just live on the Comcast remote and to be able to say on that input as opposed to having the switch inputs is a great thing for them and then the integration, I think you'll be pleased with. So all of those is one more positive force for us coming later this year.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then secondly, maybe for Reed or Ted. The Disney deal is coming soon with content supposedly launching in September. How much of a factor is that in guidance? How significant do you think that content launch is from Disney will be for the business?
componenttext: And then secondly, maybe for Reed or Ted. The Disney deal is coming soon with content supposedly launching in September. How much of a factor is that in guidance? How significant do you think that content launch is from Disney will be for the business?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Keep in mind there, it is U.S.-only is the offered deal. Those films are -- I think they're very important for watching and distinguishing Netflix as a different destination for parents because we'll have all the Disney movies, all the Lucas movies, the P
componenttext: Keep in mind there, it is U.S.-only is the offered deal. Those films are -- I think they're very important for watching and distinguishing Netflix as a different destination for parents because we'll have all the Disney movies, all the Lucas movies, the Pixar movies. And which distinguishes us separately, but I think it's just great high-quality watching, but the movies they're about 10 months old, so we don't expect them to drive a lot of new subscribers, but we do expect them to drive a lot of customer joy.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And they come in one at a time, so you don't get the whole load of movies for example, that are coming on the Starz this summer. Those will stay with Starz for the 18 month window. It will build up over the first 12 to 18 months.
componenttext: And they come in one at a time, so you don't get the whole load of movies for example, that are coming on the Starz this summer. Those will stay with Starz for the 18 month window. It will build up over the first 12 to 18 months.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: When we think about the next 12 to 18 months or 24 months for the company, it would seem that the Olympics as well as the un-grandfathering are -- to some extent onetime events. And so as we think about 2017, I know you guys don't give guidance out that f
componenttext: When we think about the next 12 to 18 months or 24 months for the company, it would seem that the Olympics as well as the un-grandfathering are -- to some extent onetime events. And so as we think about 2017, I know you guys don't give guidance out that far. But I'm just wondering if it makes sense to assume that churn -- the churn impact from this stuff rolls off, and maybe the churn continues to decline the way it has been organically over the last several years, across the service really, at least if you're successful around original programming. I just want to give you the opportunity to talk about what the business looks like as you come out of this sort of multiple headwind period here over the next couple of quarters.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, let's see. In the individual market, we would expect it to be as you said, we would expect it to return to its normal patterns and then continue to improve. As we expand throughout Asia and Central and Eastern Europe, the overall global, may be a di
componenttext: Well, let's see. In the individual market, we would expect it to be as you said, we would expect it to return to its normal patterns and then continue to improve. As we expand throughout Asia and Central and Eastern Europe, the overall global, may be a different number because those as new territories will be more high churn. But fundamentally, I think your analysis is right, which means there's some short-term headwinds to this year. And then you're looking at the broad growth of Internet television, which is continuing to be very positive. And then that's offset by competitors getting better. But that hasn't seemed to affect us in any of these markets. So I wouldn't anticipate, because of all the online competitors, together we're competing against linear hours and there's still so much linear hours to feed at that there wouldn't be any material change competitively around the world.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then just on the rest of world markets, you mentioned I think Poland and Turkey in the letter. You also mentioned being economically prudent. May be you could spend a minute on how you're thinking about these localization efforts, what that eve
componenttext: Great. And then just on the rest of world markets, you mentioned I think Poland and Turkey in the letter. You also mentioned being economically prudent. May be you could spend a minute on how you're thinking about these localization efforts, what that even means, and sort of why the pace is what it is for that part of the business here over the next couple of quarters.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's a small additional investment in any market to localize. It's subtitling and sub dubbing across thousands of titles. It's localizing the service the different apps. And then it's doing local language marketing. And so we're just taking our time
componenttext: Yes, it's a small additional investment in any market to localize. It's subtitling and sub dubbing across thousands of titles. It's localizing the service the different apps. And then it's doing local language marketing. And so we're just taking our time one by one. The whole advantage of going broad in January was to increase our rate of learning. So we wouldn't have picked out Poland and Turkey in the absence of any knowledge. But now we can clearly see positive trends, so we're starting with those. And we'll continue to rollout improvements in other markets again as we see that the content is forming new great match with a society and continuing to work on that content.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just to round out then, Reed, some of the factors and we can do partner deals in certain countries. We can do local payment options. And so those are the ones that we're referring to, depend on the economic prudence like the size of the opportunity in
componenttext: And just to round out then, Reed, some of the factors and we can do partner deals in certain countries. We can do local payment options. And so those are the ones that we're referring to, depend on the economic prudence like the size of the opportunity in those areas.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ted, you've previously given aspirations of mix of 50% original versus acquired content. Could you talk a bit about where you feel you'll be in 2016 and whether 50-50 is still the right mix long-term?
componenttext: Ted, you've previously given aspirations of mix of 50% original versus acquired content. Could you talk a bit about where you feel you'll be in 2016 and whether 50-50 is still the right mix long-term?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Long-term, I think that certainly, a probable mix or may be a bit of a conservative one. But I think in the growth of those original films, series, series for kids, documentaries, have proven to be great investments in terms of their efficiency relative t
componenttext: Long-term, I think that certainly, a probable mix or may be a bit of a conservative one. But I think in the growth of those original films, series, series for kids, documentaries, have proven to be great investments in terms of their efficiency relative to other high profile content that we license, which is encouraging us. I think it's made our rest of world launch possible by having content that people want to see in markets where we haven't yet operated. And it certainly helps in terms of the complexity of global licensing, so we can really going to keep pushing and we've also been able to manage very high-quality at the same time of doing very high volume. So we put in a letter. But we've had 17 of our original films specialties and series nominated for Emmy Awards, 54 Emmy's this year. So we've gotten -- and add 33 for our kids programming and we've been able to manage both volume and quality pretty well. So that's encouraging us to keep pushing.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And you'll be at 600 hours of new content in 2016.
componenttext: And you'll be at 600 hours of new content in 2016.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: We -- yes, I expect that we'll surpassed that pretty comfortably.
componenttext: We -- yes, I expect that we'll surpassed that pretty comfortably.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: We thought about the business longer-term in terms of how much content you can actually put on the service before you no longer need to add content. And the question is that as it relates to originals specifically, is that a fair way to think about it whe
componenttext: We thought about the business longer-term in terms of how much content you can actually put on the service before you no longer need to add content. And the question is that as it relates to originals specifically, is that a fair way to think about it when trying to think through long-term content obligations?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, definitely. I think as we -- our appetite for licensing off net decreases with our appetite to increase -- decrease our originals volume. As long as the customers are happy with the transition, it encourages us to keep being aggressive in that space.
componenttext: Yes, definitely. I think as we -- our appetite for licensing off net decreases with our appetite to increase -- decrease our originals volume. As long as the customers are happy with the transition, it encourages us to keep being aggressive in that space.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Scott, we've been able to expand our contribution margin in the U.S. and we intend to reduce marginal losses which would imply that we're able to grow revenue faster than our content spend internationally. But we like to do both. I mean, the advantage
componenttext: And Scott, we've been able to expand our contribution margin in the U.S. and we intend to reduce marginal losses which would imply that we're able to grow revenue faster than our content spend internationally. But we like to do both. I mean, the advantage of our global distribution platform to the extent that we can find content that appeals broadly, there's an advantage and scale there in terms of distributing it. So we'd love to continue to expand that content spend and also to drive some to profit as we go, we think we can do both.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And let me just add real quick, one of the most positive developments from our original programming, is then today, an original show from Netflix can be just as attractive as a show from any network in the United States when licensing for territories arou
componenttext: And let me just add real quick, one of the most positive developments from our original programming, is then today, an original show from Netflix can be just as attractive as a show from any network in the United States when licensing for territories around the world. So it leads you -- we're doing licensing first window for some titles in some countries, and second window for global. What we're finding is when we're relaunching our new original there's a huge appetite for them around the world.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Scott, I think it depends when you ask how much content is enough, on whether you think of it as trying to attract 100 million members where we are now. Or whether you think of it as trying to attract 1 billion new members like Facebook or YouTube are
componenttext: And Scott, I think it depends when you ask how much content is enough, on whether you think of it as trying to attract 100 million members where we are now. Or whether you think of it as trying to attract 1 billion new members like Facebook or YouTube are at, today in the Internet. So it just depends on the size of your aspirations and as we accomplish 1 goal of course, our aspirations grow. So I think you'll see content continuing to grow at essentially forever.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Read, just going back to Internet TV as a segment and some of the initiatives there. How do you think about what we -- at least what we think o[f this new Hulu product is going to look like, which is let's just assume, it's the best of cable plus a fairly
componenttext: Read, just going back to Internet TV as a segment and some of the initiatives there. How do you think about what we -- at least what we think o[f this new Hulu product is going to look like, which is let's just assume, it's the best of cable plus a fairly robust on-demand offering. How do you think that impacts your business in the U.S. one way or another if they're successful?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't think it will. We haven't seen impact from existing Hulu. If there's a new cable system that's better, Sling TV is in the market today and our penetration among Sling TV users is quite high. So think about it as cable getting better, MVPD getting
componenttext: I don't think it will. We haven't seen impact from existing Hulu. If there's a new cable system that's better, Sling TV is in the market today and our penetration among Sling TV users is quite high. So think about it as cable getting better, MVPD getting better and Hulu is a potential example of that if the reports are correct.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Ted, when you think about your relationship with the owners of Hulu, particularly Disney who's a critical supplier of yours globally. Are you worried that they're going to start making an effort to deliver more content to Hulu versus Netflix? We've no
componenttext: And Ted, when you think about your relationship with the owners of Hulu, particularly Disney who's a critical supplier of yours globally. Are you worried that they're going to start making an effort to deliver more content to Hulu versus Netflix? We've noticed Disney did a deal for some kids programming during the second quarter. And then Fox has already made some pretty big shift towards Hulu from SVoD perspective. How do you feel your relationship of those companies in perspective of this Hulu launch?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the relationship remains very strong. We continue to witness with every studio with every network in every territory. They're in the business of selling their content to the highest bidder. So I don't -- I'm not concerned that they would sell it for
componenttext: Well, the relationship remains very strong. We continue to witness with every studio with every network in every territory. They're in the business of selling their content to the highest bidder. So I don't -- I'm not concerned that they would sell it for less to Hulu than it would to us because they have participation problems with the talent that they have to work through. Now they've made into a position where if they were really to take that position and by everybody out for everything, that will meaningfully change the economics of those networks studios. So I'm pretty confident that we're going to -- that it will be business as usual with the network and studios.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ted, in terms of local originals. Understanding that every market will be different, can you talk a bit in terms of us trying to understand longer-term profitability in international markets. How do you think about local originals as a portion of the mix
componenttext: Ted, in terms of local originals. Understanding that every market will be different, can you talk a bit in terms of us trying to understand longer-term profitability in international markets. How do you think about local originals as a portion of the mix if you could take a few examples or paint a broader brush throughout the international platform?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we're in the very early goings of our international original programming. We've launched in Marseille. We've launched our original shows like in Japan. We've launched in Mexico. And we currently have productions going on in Germany, Spain, Italy, Ko
componenttext: Well, we're in the very early goings of our international original programming. We've launched in Marseille. We've launched our original shows like in Japan. We've launched in Mexico. And we currently have productions going on in Germany, Spain, Italy, Korea, Japan, France, Brazil, Cambodia. So we are producing around the world on original programming. And it really has an outsized impact in those first couple of shows because I think it does show those local markets that we're investing in the area production infrastructure and most important, taking those shows and distributing them around the world. So when we release a show like Ivana in Japan, people are watching Ivana all around the world at the exact same time, which makes us a very important part of the entertainment landscape in those countries and ultimately, to those consumers as well.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And David, you seem to have changed the language in terms of the 40% contribution margin by 2020, and adding possibly earlier as well. I know the trends over the intermediate term past have been trending better. Can you just add some color to that comment
componenttext: And David, you seem to have changed the language in terms of the 40% contribution margin by 2020, and adding possibly earlier as well. I know the trends over the intermediate term past have been trending better. Can you just add some color to that comment?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's just acknowledging that like you just articulated, that we are running ahead on that. So we have to sort of acknowledge reality that we may get there sooner than we sort of initially targeted. I think for us, broadening it back from just this
componenttext: I think it's just acknowledging that like you just articulated, that we are running ahead on that. So we have to sort of acknowledge reality that we may get there sooner than we sort of initially targeted. I think for us, broadening it back from just this sort of quarterly performance of that progression towards U.S. contribution margin is the right amount to reinvest in the business. We know that we want to drive efficiency, so we want some discipline there between profit and additional investment. But we also have to figure what's the right amount of reinvestment in the business to maintain competitiveness both domestically and abroad. And I think the U.S. I mentioned this in the past, to the extent that we produce an original for the globe, now that we're in additional markets, we're in more and more markets. The U.S. PO does receive some of that relief because there's a smaller share of that allocation going to the U.S. and there was before. So some of those -- that was a play -- that was in the past may team reminds me. And nowadays, the profit growth of the U.S. is being driven just by growing revenue faster than content. But I think there's 2 things were at play in the sort of last 4 to 6 quarters as we look at the trends.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ted, just want to ask you to comment a little further on sort of the market for acquired programming, I think there's a concern in the marketplace that it's getting, it's sort of increasingly competitive and expensive. And I'd love to hear how you see the
componenttext: Ted, just want to ask you to comment a little further on sort of the market for acquired programming, I think there's a concern in the marketplace that it's getting, it's sort of increasingly competitive and expensive. And I'd love to hear how you see the markets of today, especially versus your expectations are your strategy around avoiding output fields. You're really finding the stuff that's globally exclusive and maybe could comment on the Amazon, PBS deal as well as your own agreement with the CW, the Star Trek announcement today and also the Chuck Lawry announcement from a few weeks ago.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: You've covered a lot of ground there, so let me try to address all of them. As for the CW, the CW is a real anomaly in terms of the network. They happen to produce programming that has a very consistent sensibility and a very consistent fan base and that
componenttext: You've covered a lot of ground there, so let me try to address all of them. As for the CW, the CW is a real anomaly in terms of the network. They happen to produce programming that has a very consistent sensibility and a very consistent fan base and that fits really nicely with the big viewing and demographic with Netflix. We've got a great relationship with them. We've opted to re-up that relationship even though it's domestic-only ended up individually license, many of those shows for global distribution. And we're -- we are thrilled to do that and not only to free up our business, but also to move up the availability date of those shows to just 8 days after their last episode airs, versus having to wait until just before the new season launches so the Franks arm as far us the PBS Amazon I would say we have so oh aggressively improved and expanded our original kids programming. In fact, we have 35 original kids programming, the kids shows on Netflix now many more in production and various forms of development. So more and more of that programming is leading to our exclusive global programming, our original programming in place of massive loads of content from other sources. So our appetite for that, meaning our appetite for high prices have gone down quite a bit. And what else did I miss there? Yes, the Star Trek. So Star Trek is an example of one that seems like an oddball because we don't have it in the U.S. this is one of those overheads of regional licensing is that CBS was not making the U.S. available and we wanted to make sure that we could bring that show to the rest of our subscribers around the world so we're happy to premiere the use Star Trek series all over the world outside of North America.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And I just wanted to maybe pick up on the content -- go ahead.
componenttext: Great. And I just wanted to maybe pick up on the content -- go ahead.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. You mentioned also pricing and I've mentioned this before, and still I think it holds true. You Should think about content cost like player personnel cost. At any given store, a superstar goes free agent and that particular players price those go thr
componenttext: Yes. You mentioned also pricing and I've mentioned this before, and still I think it holds true. You Should think about content cost like player personnel cost. At any given store, a superstar goes free agent and that particular players price those go through the roof. The player personnel costs, they remain pretty stack, pretty flat and that's the case here. Every once in a while, there's a breakout very competitive dial and the price for that goes up but over all of spend you haven't baked into our business model.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Just following up on margins. David, if you look at the international markets, which I realize is a portfolio, do you have a good sense of how much local programming you need in a given international markets? I realize there's a range. And does th
componenttext: Got it. Just following up on margins. David, if you look at the international markets, which I realize is a portfolio, do you have a good sense of how much local programming you need in a given international markets? I realize there's a range. And does that percentage impact the profitability of those markets long-term? In other words, if you need in a market by Germany half the content to just make something up, needs to be German, does that mean that market is structurally lower-margin than say the U.S. market or your broader portfolio or is it too early to figure those out?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's too early. I mean, the dominant aspect that affects profitability in any one given market is the competitiveness. And that can manifest itself in the competitiveness of content bidding. It can manifest itself for competitiveness that consumer
componenttext: I think it's too early. I mean, the dominant aspect that affects profitability in any one given market is the competitiveness. And that can manifest itself in the competitiveness of content bidding. It can manifest itself for competitiveness that consumers moment of truth, how much they're viewing, where they're viewing. What are they're of alternative sources of entertainment? So I would say it's too early we've been very successful with sort of an 18-20 model today and very, very disparate non-english markets in Chile, Finland, The Netherlands. And so we do have markets -- early markets like Japan that are tilted a little bit more towards local content. But I don't think the margin characteristics are going to be necessarily determined by the percent of local it's how competitive the market is.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016

componenttext: Sure viewing overall is pretty seasonally up to look at it on a year-over-year basis but on a year-over-year basis total viewing, which is the fact that sometimes release is up, we did think of it as we were I think it was 13 million a year-ago quarter ago where it was 10 million a year ago.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016

componenttext: Great. Download functionality, which is a hot topic. Some competitors have taken that on. You historically have suggested not interested and but it seems like that's changed recently. Can you talk about your interest there and also cost implications Contractual Cost Obligations?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016

componenttext: Yes, we're open-minded about it as we've expanded globally, it's something we've taken More of a look out given the strength of the cellular netowrs, not being terms be as strong then some of the new markets -- to take a look at it. As you know, some of our competitors in different markets in Germany, the U.S. and others include a local caching capability so it's a pretty standard part of most deals.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016

And in terms of the ratio of content cash the P&L, it's still in that 13 to 14 range where it could tee up to 14, but it's staying in that 1 3 to 1 4 range.

We're very confident of that. And our competitive position is very strong. So those are 2 very and that give us confidence in the long-term and make us want to continue on a.

componenttext: Yes, we talked about it after launch and debated, do we want to be a low cost service like a $2 service or should we try to add content to make it a viable $10 in service. And this lease for the next few years we're very much on the latter strategy. So we're going to invest to build a great $10 service. We look at the iPhone success globally. We're looking at some other high-value products. And we want to be an incredible content service of this $10 price point rather than be very low much lower cost or even free service. And so that's what we're focused on as our current model.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Around the world, e-commerce is unequally well developed. So in some markets, there's very strong, e-commerce payment platform like The Netherlands. In other markets like Cambodia, Vietnam, it's challenging. So today, we only accept international cre
componenttext:
Yes. Around the world, e-commerce is unequally well developed. So in some markets, there's very strong, e-commerce payment platform like The Netherlands. In other markets like Cambodia, Vietnam, it's challenging. So today, we only accept international credit cards. So we'll develop a really a long e-commerce in that whole ecosystem as people want to pay for things online. And that may come through mobile payments like Android and iOS. It'll come along with third-party payment systems. But again, the general economy that people are moving online through mobile and we're going to be able to take advantage and we are taking advantage of that. So in the long-term, it's not a big friction point because everyone's going to want to be able to purchase many things, including Netflix. 
So thank you, both, and thank you to all of our investors. We apologize for the volatility. I know it's not easy on everyone. The big picture is very much intact and we're very excited about it. And so we're continuing to execute on growing the business. Thank you very much.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome to the Q2 2016 Netflix Earnings Call. I'm David Wells, CFO. I'm joined today on the company side by our CEO, Reed Hastings and dialing in remotely, our Chief Content Officer, Ted Sarandos. Interviewing us today will be Ben Swinburne from Morgan St
componenttext: Welcome to the Q2 2016 Netflix Earnings Call. I'm David Wells, CFO. I'm joined today on the company side by our CEO, Reed Hastings and dialing in remotely, our Chief Content Officer, Ted Sarandos. Interviewing us today will be Ben Swinburne from Morgan Stanley and Scott Devitt from Stifel, Nicolaus. And I think Ben, you have the first question.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Reed, I'm sure we're going to spend a lot of time on the [indiscernible] and the long-term outlook, but I wonder if you can just give us a sense what gives you confidence that the churn shortfall in the quarter was really driven by sort of confusion among
componenttext: Reed, I'm sure we're going to spend a lot of time on the [indiscernible] and the long-term outlook, but I wonder if you can just give us a sense what gives you confidence that the churn shortfall in the quarter was really driven by sort of confusion among members around the price increases or the un-grandfathering versus other factors, for example, content or competition and any color you might have on voluntary versus nonvoluntary churn. Maybe you can help us put some color around what happened versus your expectations.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm getting a lot of echo.
componenttext: I'm getting a lot of echo.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, me, too.
componenttext: Yes, me, too.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ted, maybe you could mute or something. The -- listen, you asked question, why are we confident of this explanation. Well, the obvious explanations other than this, our competition, which we're pretty confident, is not a factor because we got this slight
componenttext: Ted, maybe you could mute or something. The -- listen, you asked question, why are we confident of this explanation. Well, the obvious explanations other than this, our competition, which we're pretty confident, is not a factor because we got this slight uptick in churn in multiple countries the same week. And of course, that's not a competitive signature, including Canada where many of the other S Cloud services don't operate. There's a separate set, Crave and Shomi, that operate in Canada. So that's why we're pretty confident it's not competition. And then, again, if it was saturation, what we'd be seeing is a hit to gross adds more than we would in terms of churn. So other possible explanations were that we did something on our service around that week, but we've looked at everything. And the fact that it's coincident with that Google Trend data we included, really indicates that people don't like price increases. We know that. It's a necessary phase for us to get through. And with the increased revenue, we're continuing to invest in better and better content. So that's what makes us feel very strong and positive about the long term and that this is a short-term phenomena.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And David, just as a follow-up, when you put the third quarter guidance together, are you assuming that this sort of churn throughout the entire base remains elevated? Or have you seen that initial April churn subside, and really, what we're looking at is
componenttext: And David, just as a follow-up, when you put the third quarter guidance together, are you assuming that this sort of churn throughout the entire base remains elevated? Or have you seen that initial April churn subside, and really, what we're looking at is just the impact from the -- on the actual un-grandfathering, which you talk about in the letter being in line with expectations.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ben, we're really assuming that it persists. So we might be wrong on that in terms of it relenting a bit or it gets better. But so far, we've seen it sort of persist through the second quarter and into the early part of the third, so we're assuming that p
componenttext: Ben, we're really assuming that it persists. So we might be wrong on that in terms of it relenting a bit or it gets better. But so far, we've seen it sort of persist through the second quarter and into the early part of the third, so we're assuming that persists into Q3 and maybe into Q4 as we continue to un-grandfather. And just a cautionary, the usual customary language, I realize I sort of went straight to your question. But we will be making forward-looking statements in this call, and actual results may vary. We'll go back to our regular questions.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Scott Devitt. Reed, just wondering if the effects of the un-grandfathering have any longer-term ramifications in terms of how you think of pricing power on the platform globally?
componenttext: This is Scott Devitt. Reed, just wondering if the effects of the un-grandfathering have any longer-term ramifications in terms of how you think of pricing power on the platform globally?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Not a ton. We're continuing to improve the content, which is the fundamental driver of value for subscribers, how much they watch, how unique the content is, how exclusive it is. We're going to continue to improve. And again, with new members, we haven't
componenttext: Not a ton. We're continuing to improve the content, which is the fundamental driver of value for subscribers, how much they watch, how unique the content is, how exclusive it is. We're going to continue to improve. And again, with new members, we haven't seen any effect. We changed prices to our $8, $10 and $12 last October, and we've had a couple quarters of great growth on the gross add side. So I think this is really around change resistance. Whatever the price is for something, people don't like it to go up. But in terms of new members, which is most of what drives growth, the new pricing's working great.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And in terms of -- for David, in terms of the timing, the links that you provided to Google Trends, I think the uptick started the week of April 3. So is the 3rd through the 16th predated when you gave earnings last quarter? What was the response? Was it
componenttext: And in terms of -- for David, in terms of the timing, the links that you provided to Google Trends, I think the uptick started the week of April 3. So is the 3rd through the 16th predated when you gave earnings last quarter? What was the response? Was it immediate in terms of the uptick in query volume and interest? Or was it somewhat delayed?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, let's keep in mind, Ben -- or Scott, that the -- what we're talking about is a very small change, right? But because of the large base, a small change can result in sort of 300,000 subscribers, which is the miss that we had on domestic resulting. Bu
componenttext: Well, let's keep in mind, Ben -- or Scott, that the -- what we're talking about is a very small change, right? But because of the large base, a small change can result in sort of 300,000 subscribers, which is the miss that we had on domestic resulting. But we did see it. We've learned through the -- in the past not to overreact to immediate trend changes. So it was a swing factor when we were discussing Q2 and into Q3 even and sort of trying to sift through what might affect us in the quarter. We saw a little bit of it, but it was very -- right before we sort of said earnings and we were on this call 3 months ago. And so we felt it was a small factor, but it did persist through the quarter. And that's one of the major driver of the lower year-on-year growth and also the lower growth versus expectations.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just sticking on the theme for -- around churn with another question. David, what are you seeing with the un-grandfathering members as they face different pricing options? I know you tested a lot over the last couple of months. What are you seeing in
componenttext: And just sticking on the theme for -- around churn with another question. David, what are you seeing with the un-grandfathering members as they face different pricing options? I know you tested a lot over the last couple of months. What are you seeing in terms of their choices? And how does that impact sort of your ARPU expectation? And when should we -- when would the grandfathering process be finished in the U.S.? Is that something in the fourth quarter? Any help there would be great.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. It finishes in the fourth quarter, so finishes about midway through to the -- towards the end of November. And then in terms of their choices, especially around plan mix or whether they choose the high plan or the low plan, it's as we expected. So we
componenttext: Yes. It finishes in the fourth quarter, so finishes about midway through to the -- towards the end of November. And then in terms of their choices, especially around plan mix or whether they choose the high plan or the low plan, it's as we expected. So we continue to see folks choose the lower plan in some smaller increments and the higher plan in some increments, so our expectations of ASP growth are still there, about consistent. What we're talking about is the population that it didn't face an immediate grandfathering choice. That's the part that was a bit of a surprise to us and continues to persist.

componenttext: And does any of your data suggest you've seen anything interesting around members that were inactive or maybe membership sharing as result of the pricing changes?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: This question may have been addressed in the letter given that you gave un-grandfathering commentary around international as well, but would be interested if you could just talk through your expectations for existing markets versus new markets and where y
componenttext: This question may have been addressed in the letter given that you gave un-grandfathering commentary around international as well, but would be interested if you could just talk through your expectations for existing markets versus new markets and where you beat and missed.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Let's see. I would say that we -- the trend was across multiple markets, and as we put in the letter, it was in markets that are more highly penetrated and less highly penetrated. That's why we think it is about the sort of pricing talk that was aff
componenttext: Sure. Let's see. I would say that we -- the trend was across multiple markets, and as we put in the letter, it was in markets that are more highly penetrated and less highly penetrated. That's why we think it is about the sort of pricing talk that was affected. But in addition to that, we would say that our newer markets have an expectation of multi-year growth. So we know that we've got work cut -- our work cut out for us and that we've hit a point where we're not adding on any new additional markets. But we are going to be seeing periods of accelerated growth and decelerated growth, and we've seen that in the past where some markets sort of pick up and then moderate and then pick up again. And I think that's what we saw in this quarter and forward. We're indicating that we've got multiyears just like we have in Latin America to build that market to where it, has taken us 4 or 5 years at this point to get it there.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Reed, you...
componenttext: And Reed, you...

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: There's nothing we've seen in the new markets in Asia, Central, Eastern Europe that's significantly different from early Latin America. It paints a pretty similar picture at least for these first 6 months.
componenttext: There's nothing we've seen in the new markets in Asia, Central, Eastern Europe that's significantly different from early Latin America. It paints a pretty similar picture at least for these first 6 months.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Reed, you reiterated the $60 million to $90 million in the U.S. We'd be interested if you could add some color in terms of where you think the friction points are, if it's content portfolio, competition, those being the 2 most significant, where you s
componenttext: And Reed, you reiterated the $60 million to $90 million in the U.S. We'd be interested if you could add some color in terms of where you think the friction points are, if it's content portfolio, competition, those being the 2 most significant, where you see sources of friction and what gives you confidence still in that range.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Again, I don't think there really is any friction. I mean smart TVs are continuing to sell. Everyone's using Internet video and Internet television more and more. You see the rise of these virtual MVPDs. All of these things are building out the Internet e
componenttext: Again, I don't think there really is any friction. I mean smart TVs are continuing to sell. Everyone's using Internet video and Internet television more and more. You see the rise of these virtual MVPDs. All of these things are building out the Internet ecosystem, and I don't see why, 10, 20 years from now why every American household isn't subscribing to Netflix except for maybe competition. So we've got to stay on our toes on that basis. But think about entertainment and pay television are pretty ubiquitous. So in the Internet video, that's a pretty big bet that's continuing to pay off. So you put those 2 forces together, and that's why we feel so good about the long term in this market.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I want to just ask about -- a little bit more about the guidance, David. Last quarter, you called out the comp versus Australia, which was I think a bigger one or a tougher one than we all understood. When you look at third quarter, I think you have Japan
componenttext: I want to just ask about -- a little bit more about the guidance, David. Last quarter, you called out the comp versus Australia, which was I think a bigger one or a tougher one than we all understood. When you look at third quarter, I think you have Japan and then fourth quarter, Southern Europe. Could you just maybe put those at least in relative context for -- versus Q2 so we can think about what those headwinds may or may not look like?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I mean, there's always a headwind when we've had a prior launch of a large market or a market like Australia where we saw strong initial uptake. In terms of that moderating, you've got a lot of pent-up demand that then sort of reverts to a more norm
componenttext: Sure. I mean, there's always a headwind when we've had a prior launch of a large market or a market like Australia where we saw strong initial uptake. In terms of that moderating, you've got a lot of pent-up demand that then sort of reverts to a more normal growth pattern over time. That can take several quarters. It can take 2 quarters. We've seen different experiences by market. So I would say Japan was a pent-up market in some respects and then starts to moderate. So that does factor into the comp. And some of our other markets may be experiencing flat or even down year on growth. It's just a mixture across that. But like I said, we've seen markets that have decelerated, then, pick up again and accelerate. So collectively, across the -- all of our basket of investments in markets, we think there is a large long-term opportunity that we're going to optimize against, and we know that we got work cut out for some of our newer markets that will take time to get there.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just want to ask you about the Olympics and where you're factoring that in or how you're factoring that into your guidance. You mentioned gross additions remain healthy, which, at least to me, sounds like flat to up, but I'll let you comment if you ch
componenttext: And just want to ask you about the Olympics and where you're factoring that in or how you're factoring that into your guidance. You mentioned gross additions remain healthy, which, at least to me, sounds like flat to up, but I'll let you comment if you choose. Are you assuming that impact to gross adds? And if so, is it a U.S. phenomenon or a global phenomenon in the third quarter?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: It would be global, and so you're back -- you're correctly surmising that gross adds, you can say roughly in line year-on-year. And so with an assumption of a hit from the Olympics, which largely affect us -- affects us in the past on gross adds or on new
componenttext: It would be global, and so you're back -- you're correctly surmising that gross adds, you can say roughly in line year-on-year. And so with an assumption of a hit from the Olympics, which largely affect us -- affects us in the past on gross adds or on new subscribers coming in. The basket of effect in terms of a year-over-year trend, we expect that to be a meaningful, small but still meaningful impact on the quarter, negative impact.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: You haven't announced the X1, the Xfinity deal with Comcast and was without a time line. I was wondering if you could give any clarity in terms of timing and then more broadly, how you think about MVPD in the U.S. as a driver of subscribers in the way tha
componenttext: You haven't announced the X1, the Xfinity deal with Comcast and was without a time line. I was wondering if you could give any clarity in terms of timing and then more broadly, how you think about MVPD in the U.S. as a driver of subscribers in the way that, years ago, getting onto consoles and other devices actually led to an acceleration in growth.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. We're very excited about the X1 integration. It's scheduled for the second half of this year, so between now and the end of the year. And really, we're focused on getting the integration points very smooth, and the Comcast engineers are doing great
componenttext: Sure. We're very excited about the X1 integration. It's scheduled for the second half of this year, so between now and the end of the year. And really, we're focused on getting the integration points very smooth, and the Comcast engineers are doing great work on it. So look for it later this year. It will help modestly. Again, we're more penetrated than we were before. So I don't know that it's as big a breakthrough because many of those households, Comcast households now have a smart TV or have a Roku, but it will certainly help. And from a user perspective, to just live on the Comcast remote and to be able to stay on that input as opposed to having to switch inputs is a great thing for them, and then the integration, I think you'll be pleased with. So all of those is one more positive force for us coming later this year.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then secondly, maybe for Reed or Ted. The Disney deal is coming soon with content supposedly launching in September. How much of a factor is that in guidance? How significant do you think that content launches from Disney will be for the business?
componenttext: And then secondly, maybe for Reed or Ted. The Disney deal is coming soon with content supposedly launching in September. How much of a factor is that in guidance? How significant do you think that content launches from Disney will be for the business?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, keep in mind there, U.S. only is the output deal. And those films are -- I think they're very important for watching and distinguishing Netflix as a different destination for parents because we'll have all the Disney movies, all the Lucas movies, th
componenttext: Well, keep in mind there, U.S. only is the output deal. And those films are -- I think they're very important for watching and distinguishing Netflix as a different destination for parents because we'll have all the Disney movies, all the Lucas movies, the Pixar movies and that -- which distinguishes us separately. But I think it's just great, high-quality watching. But the movies, they're about 10 months old, so we don't expect them to drive a lot of new subscribers. But we do expect it to drive a lot of customer joy.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And they come in one at a time, so you don't get the whole load of movies, for example, that are coming on to Starz this summer. Those will stay with Starz for the 18-month window. It will build up over the first 12 to 18 months.
componenttext: And they come in one at a time, so you don't get the whole load of movies, for example, that are coming on to Starz this summer. Those will stay with Starz for the 18-month window. It will build up over the first 12 to 18 months.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: When we think about the next 12 to 18 months or 24 months for the company, it would seem that the Olympics as well as the un-grandfathering are, to some extent, onetime events. And so as we think about 2017, I know you guys don't give guidance out that fa
componenttext: When we think about the next 12 to 18 months or 24 months for the company, it would seem that the Olympics as well as the un-grandfathering are, to some extent, onetime events. And so as we think about 2017, I know you guys don't give guidance out that far. But I'm just wondering if it makes sense to assume that churn -- the churn impact from this stuff rolls off, and maybe the churn continues to decline the way it has been organically over the last several years across the service, certainly, at least if you're successful around original programming. I just want to give the opportunity to talk about what the business looks like as you come out of this sort of multiple-headwind period here over the next couple of quarters.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, let's see. In the individual market, we would expect it to be as you said. We would expect it to return to its normal patterns and to continue to improve. As we expand throughout Asia and Central and Eastern Europe, the overall global may be a diffe
componenttext: Well, let's see. In the individual market, we would expect it to be as you said. We would expect it to return to its normal patterns and to continue to improve. As we expand throughout Asia and Central and Eastern Europe, the overall global may be a different number because those as new territories will be more high churn. But fundamentally, I think your analysis is right, which is there are some short-term headwinds for this year. And then you're looking at the broad growth of Internet television, which is continuing to be very positive. And then that's offset by competitors getting better, but that hasn't seemed to affect us in any of these markets. So I wouldn't anticipate because all of the online competitors, together, we're competing against linear hours, and there are still so much linear hours to feed at that there would be any material change competitively around the world.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And just on the rest of world markets, you mentioned I think Poland and Turkey in the letter. You also mentioned being economically prudent. Maybe you can just spend a minute on how you're thinking about these localization efforts, what that even m
componenttext: Great. And just on the rest of world markets, you mentioned I think Poland and Turkey in the letter. You also mentioned being economically prudent. Maybe you can just spend a minute on how you're thinking about these localization efforts, what that even means and sort of why the pace is what it is for that part of the business here over the next couple of quarters.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. It's a small additional investment in any market to localize. It's subtitling and some dubbing across thousands of titles. It's localizing the service, the different apps. And then it's doing local language marketing. And so we're just taking our tim
componenttext: Yes. It's a small additional investment in any market to localize. It's subtitling and some dubbing across thousands of titles. It's localizing the service, the different apps. And then it's doing local language marketing. And so we're just taking our time one by one. The whole advantage of going broad in January was to increase our rate of learning. So we wouldn't have picked out Poland and Turkey in the absence of any knowledge. But now we can clearly see positive trends, so we're starting with those. And we'll continue to roll out improvements in other markets again as we see that the content is forming a great match with the society and continuing to work on that content.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just to round out then, Reed, the -- some of the factors and we can do partner deals in certain countries. We could do local payment options. And so those are the ones that we're referring to, depend on the economic prudence like the size of the oppor
componenttext: And just to round out then, Reed, the -- some of the factors and we can do partner deals in certain countries. We could do local payment options. And so those are the ones that we're referring to, depend on the economic prudence like the size of the opportunity in those areas.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ted, you've previously given aspirations of mix of 50% original versus acquired content. Could you talk a bit about where you feel you'll be in 2016 and whether 50-50's still the right mix long term?
componenttext: Ted, you've previously given aspirations of mix of 50% original versus acquired content. Could you talk a bit about where you feel you'll be in 2016 and whether 50-50's still the right mix long term?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Long term, I think it -- that's certainly a probable mix or maybe even a conservative one. And -- but I think in -- the growth of those original films, series, series for kids, documentaries have proven to be great investments in terms of their efficiency
componenttext: Long term, I think it -- that's certainly a probable mix or maybe even a conservative one. And -- but I think in -- the growth of those original films, series, series for kids, documentaries have proven to be great investments in terms of their efficiency relative to other high profile content that we license, which is encouraging us. I think it's made our rest of world launch possible by having content that people want to see in markets where we haven't yet operated. And it certainly helps in terms of the complexity of global licensing. So we can -- we want to keep pushing it. And we've also been able to manage very high quality at the same time of doing very high volume. So we put in the letter. But we've had 17 of our original films specials and series nominated for Emmy Awards, 54 Emmys this year. So we've gotten -- and add 33 for our kids programming, and we've been able to manage both volume and quality pretty well. So that's what encouraged us to keep pushing.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And you'll be at 600 hours of new content in 2016.
componenttext: And you'll be at 600 hours of new content in 2016.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we -- I expect that we'll surpass that pretty comfortably.
componenttext: Yes, we -- I expect that we'll surpass that pretty comfortably.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: We've thought about the business longer term in terms of how much content can you actually put on the service before you no longer need to add content. And the question is, as it relates to originals specifically, is that a fair way to think about it when
componenttext: We've thought about the business longer term in terms of how much content can you actually put on the service before you no longer need to add content. And the question is, as it relates to originals specifically, is that a fair way to think about it when trying to think through long-term content obligations.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, definitely. I mean, I think as we -- our appetite for licensing off net decreases with our appetite to increase -- do increase our originals volume. And as long as the customers are happy with the transition, it encourages us to keep being aggressive
componenttext: Yes, definitely. I mean, I think as we -- our appetite for licensing off net decreases with our appetite to increase -- do increase our originals volume. And as long as the customers are happy with the transition, it encourages us to keep being aggressive in that space.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Scott, we've been able to expand our contribution margin in the U.S., and we intend to reduce international losses, which would imply that we're able to grow revenue faster than our content spend internationally. But we'd like to do both. I mean, the
componenttext: And Scott, we've been able to expand our contribution margin in the U.S., and we intend to reduce international losses, which would imply that we're able to grow revenue faster than our content spend internationally. But we'd like to do both. I mean, the advantage of our global distribution platform to the extent that we can find content that appeals broadly, there's an advantage and scale there in terms of distributing it. So we'd love to continue to expand that content spend and also to drive some to profit as we go. We think we can do both.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I would just add real quick, one of the most positive developments from our original programming has been today an original show from Netflix, can be just as attractive as a show from any network in the United States when licensing for territories aro
componenttext: And I would just add real quick, one of the most positive developments from our original programming has been today an original show from Netflix, can be just as attractive as a show from any network in the United States when licensing for territories around the world. So it leads you -- what we're doing licensing first window for some titles in some countries, and second window for global, that we're finding is, is that when we're launching our new original series, there's a huge appetite for them around the world.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Scott, I think it somewhat depends when you ask how much content is enough, on whether you think of it as trying to attract 100 million members where we are now or whether you think of it as trying to attract 1 billion members like Facebook or YouTube
componenttext: And Scott, I think it somewhat depends when you ask how much content is enough, on whether you think of it as trying to attract 100 million members where we are now or whether you think of it as trying to attract 1 billion members like Facebook or YouTube are at today on the Internet. So it just depends upon the size of your aspirations, and as we accomplish one goal, of course, our aspirations grow. So I think you'll see content continuing to grow essentially forever.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Reed, just going back to Internet TV as a segment and some of the initiatives there. How do you think about what we -- at least what we think this new Hulu product is going to look like, which is let's just assume it's so the best of cable plus a fairly r
componenttext: Reed, just going back to Internet TV as a segment and some of the initiatives there. How do you think about what we -- at least what we think this new Hulu product is going to look like, which is let's just assume it's so the best of cable plus a fairly robust on-demand offering. How do you think that impacts your business in the U.S. one way or the other if they're successful?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't think it will. We haven't seen impact from existing Hulu. If there's a new cable system that's better, Sling TV is in the market today, and our penetration among Sling TV users is quite high. So think of that as cable getting better or MVPD gettin
componenttext: I don't think it will. We haven't seen impact from existing Hulu. If there's a new cable system that's better, Sling TV is in the market today, and our penetration among Sling TV users is quite high. So think of that as cable getting better or MVPD getting better, and Hulu is a potential example of that if the reports are correct.
