componenttextpreview: Reed, time spent on the platform is such an important metric. Was wondering if you could update us just on time spent per user, extent that there's anything there that's changed in either direction. And then secondly, Sandvine that reports peak traffic sh
componenttext: Reed, time spent on the platform is such an important metric. Was wondering if you could update us just on time spent per user, extent that there's anything there that's changed in either direction. And then secondly, Sandvine that reports peak traffic showed a downtick in Netflix, still dominant but a little bit lower relative to peers in terms of that domination. You've implemented compression technology during that period. Can you just talk a little bit about how much of an effect that could have on a metric like that?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I think on the Sandvine, which covers North America, it might have been like 35% to 33%, something like that, which would correlate very well with what we think was the increase in coding efficiency. So think of that as a flat result as opposed to a
componenttext: Sure. I think on the Sandvine, which covers North America, it might have been like 35% to 33%, something like that, which would correlate very well with what we think was the increase in coding efficiency. So think of that as a flat result as opposed to a down result. And then what was the first question?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just time spent per user, how that's trending. You've given periodic updates on that. I'm just wondering if there's anything to say.
componenttext: Just time spent per user, how that's trending. You've given periodic updates on that. I'm just wondering if there's anything to say.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Viewing overall is pretty seasonal, so you have to look at it on a year-over-year basis. But on a year-over-year basis, total viewing, which is the fact that we sometimes release, is up. I forget exactly the numbers, but think of it as we were -- I
componenttext: Sure. Viewing overall is pretty seasonal, so you have to look at it on a year-over-year basis. But on a year-over-year basis, total viewing, which is the fact that we sometimes release, is up. I forget exactly the numbers, but think of it as we were -- I think it was 13 million a quarter ago, and it was maybe 10 million a year ago.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Scott, we -- sorry, Reed. We did -- you did release those numbers at CES in January, so there was a data point there. And I think that's what Reed was sort of referring back to.
componenttext: Yes. Scott, we -- sorry, Reed. We did -- you did release those numbers at CES in January, so there was a data point there. And I think that's what Reed was sort of referring back to.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Total viewing's continuing to grow on a year-over-year basis.
componenttext: Total viewing's continuing to grow on a year-over-year basis.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Download functionality, which is a hot topic, some competitors have taken that on. You historically have suggested not interested, and it seems like that's changed a little bit more recently. Can you talk about your interest there? And then also co
componenttext: Great. Download functionality, which is a hot topic, some competitors have taken that on. You historically have suggested not interested, and it seems like that's changed a little bit more recently. Can you talk about your interest there? And then also cost implications in terms of contractual obligations?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We're open minded about it as we've expanded globally. It's something we've taken more of a look at given the strength of cellular networks not being as strong in some of the new markets. So that's gotten us to take a look at it. And there's no mater
componenttext: Yes. We're open minded about it as we've expanded globally. It's something we've taken more of a look at given the strength of cellular networks not being as strong in some of the new markets. So that's gotten us to take a look at it. And there's no material cost implications. As you know, some of our competitors in different markets in Germany, in the U.S. and others include a local caching capability, so it's a pretty standard part of most deals.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: A question for David. Just turning to the financials a bit. Member growth fell short this quarter, as you guys acknowledged in the letter, but your comments about profitability next year haven't changed. You continue to expect substantial profits -- or ma
componenttext: A question for David. Just turning to the financials a bit. Member growth fell short this quarter, as you guys acknowledged in the letter, but your comments about profitability next year haven't changed. You continue to expect substantial profits -- or material profits, excuse me, in 2017. Can you talk about the cash flow burn, cash burn outlook '16 and '17, David? And any comment around P&L expense versus cash now that the top line at least seems to be growing a little more slowly than we all expected?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, cash flow, despite all the perturbations of sort of content coming in and out and the uncertainty around when that content might time, has been relatively steady at about $0.25 million a quarter. So I would say there's been no change on -- from my u
componenttext: Well, cash flow, despite all the perturbations of sort of content coming in and out and the uncertainty around when that content might time, has been relatively steady at about $0.25 million a quarter. So I would say there's been no change on -- from my understanding and expectation that it's about $1 billion, $1.2 billion in terms of the year, and we expect that again going forward. So free cash flow will improve when we drive more profit and start organically funding more of our content investment. And in terms of the ratio of content cash to P&L, it's still in that 1:3 to 1:4 range, where it could kick up to 1:4, but it's staying in that 1:3 to 1:4 range.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Any color on the sequential increase on contractual obligations? I think it was 13.2 [ph] at the end of the quarter. How do you think about that number again given the context of a slowing or a little bit of a lower top line than you thought?
componenttext: Any color on the sequential increase on contractual obligations? I think it was 13.2 [ph] at the end of the quarter. How do you think about that number again given the context of a slowing or a little bit of a lower top line than you thought?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, content is one of those things where you invest -- you don't invest by quarter. You invest several years or a year. So I think what you're seeing is our investment in rest of world, the rest of world launch and the growth of additional territories.
componenttext: Well, content is one of those things where you invest -- you don't invest by quarter. You invest several years or a year. So I think what you're seeing is our investment in rest of world, the rest of world launch and the growth of additional territories. You're also seeing increased investment in some of our younger territories where they're growing their content expense at a faster clip than some of our territories that are more highly penetrated or have been operating for more years. But just like Reed was saying that the off-line viewing or the downloading rights aren't really a factor, what you're seeing is the growth of additional territories. So that's what's driving the content commitments. And again, I look at this periodically on a per-member basis. And it's stayed in that sort of band and is consistent with sort of prior trends and prior territory launches.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And you have to remember, Scott (sic) [Ben], that when we look at it, we've been doing this a long time. We've had these short quarters before. 9 years ago in 2007, we actually went down in subscribers. So this quarter, we're growing but not as much as we
componenttext: And you have to remember, Scott (sic) [Ben], that when we look at it, we've been doing this a long time. We've had these short quarters before. 9 years ago in 2007, we actually went down in subscribers. So this quarter, we're growing but not as much as we want. But in 2007, we went down from $6.8 million to $6.7 million in this Q2, which is generally a seasonally tight quarter for us. And it didn't feel great going down, but now here we are at over $80 million. So you've just got to take a long-term perspective. And Internet TV is going to be an enormous market. We're very confident of that. And our competitive position is very strong. So those are the 2 fundamental things that give us confidence in the long term and want us to continue to invest in more content.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Any update, David, on the chip card transition to the extent there's any remnant that you may have seen in the quarter from that?
componenttext: Any update, David, on the chip card transition to the extent there's any remnant that you may have seen in the quarter from that?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a small background issue. It was back then that was sort of became outsized because we pointed to it as one of the explanatory reasons that we had an invol churn uptick. But I would say it continues to be a small background issue.
componenttext: It's a small background issue. It was back then that was sort of became outsized because we pointed to it as one of the explanatory reasons that we had an invol churn uptick. But I would say it continues to be a small background issue.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then for Ted. I don't know if there is a way to think of this that you've shared publicly. But in terms of the product portfolio today and global rights that you have, if you think of it maybe relative to your spend, what portion of the portfolio has
componenttext: And then for Ted. I don't know if there is a way to think of this that you've shared publicly. But in terms of the product portfolio today and global rights that you have, if you think of it maybe relative to your spend, what portion of the portfolio has global rights associated with it? And then secondly, as it relates to global rights, how are the allocations done between markets?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the allocations are done by media market share models, and our -- you should think about our global allocations as all of our original programming is fully global. Several but I -- we haven't broken out an exact percentage of our off-net licensees that
componenttext: So the allocations are done by media market share models, and our -- you should think about our global allocations as all of our original programming is fully global. Several but I -- we haven't broken out an exact percentage of our off-net licensees that we do on a global basis. And then there's individual libraries from each of them from each -- from around the world that we have global rights for of a lot of content that you may never have heard of but actually get healthy niches of watching all over the world as well.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Ted, it's right. Some of the content, when we say global, that's global Netflix. Like sometimes it includes China. Sometimes it doesn't.
componenttext: And Ted, it's right. Some of the content, when we say global, that's global Netflix. Like sometimes it includes China. Sometimes it doesn't.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Correct.
componenttext: Correct.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: So think of it as global to where we currently operate.
componenttext: So think of it as global to where we currently operate.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And with the exception of our -- on the original side, which today it has always included China.
componenttext: And with the exception of our -- on the original side, which today it has always included China.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you guys talk a little bit about how the Asian market rollouts have gone so far relative to your expectations and whether you're thinking about maybe different price tiers or still sticking to the global price point as you look at the results there.
componenttext: Can you guys talk a little bit about how the Asian market rollouts have gone so far relative to your expectations and whether you're thinking about maybe different price tiers or still sticking to the global price point as you look at the results there.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We thought about it after launch and debated do we want to try to be a low-cost service like a $2 service or should we try to add content to make it a viable $10 service. And at least for the next few years, we're very much on the latter strategy. So
componenttext: Yes. We thought about it after launch and debated do we want to try to be a low-cost service like a $2 service or should we try to add content to make it a viable $10 service. And at least for the next few years, we're very much on the latter strategy. So we're going to invest to build a great $10 service. We look at the iPhone success globally. We look at some other high-value products. And we want to be an incredible content service at this $10 price point rather than be very low -- much lower cost or even free service. And so that's what we're focused on as our current model.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ben, we already do have some price choices in our tiering, so we do use a sort of entry-level tier as a mechanism for those folks that might be more value oriented. So we do have some ability there to separate across price in terms of capturing the -- tho
componenttext: Ben, we already do have some price choices in our tiering, so we do use a sort of entry-level tier as a mechanism for those folks that might be more value oriented. So we do have some ability there to separate across price in terms of capturing the -- those subscribers that might be more value oriented.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just sticking with the emerging market theme but markets you've been in a while. Can you talk about the Latin American market and whether that continues to be strong and how you might think something like the second season of Narcos might impact resul
componenttext: And just sticking with the emerging market theme but markets you've been in a while. Can you talk about the Latin American market and whether that continues to be strong and how you might think something like the second season of Narcos might impact results there?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll...
componenttext: I'll...

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Go ahead.
componenttext: Go ahead.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Latin America's continued to grow well for us. And what's been fascinating is the growth's been pretty steady even in Brazil where we see a significant recession and a difficult government situation. So it seems that neither of those factors really a
componenttext: Yes. Latin America's continued to grow well for us. And what's been fascinating is the growth's been pretty steady even in Brazil where we see a significant recession and a difficult government situation. So it seems that neither of those factors really affect a value-oriented business like ours. With the second season of Narcos, we're hoping to see great viewing throughout Latin America and throughout the world but similar to our other originals.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: That second season comes September 2, and it's one of the things that we think is very exciting about the prospects of global television. We also have a new series we're filming in Mexico, Ingobernable, and a second season of Club de Cuervos in production
componenttext: That second season comes September 2, and it's one of the things that we think is very exciting about the prospects of global television. We also have a new series we're filming in Mexico, Ingobernable, and a second season of Club de Cuervos in production. So we've got a pretty healthy investment in Latin America. But I think that where we're at in emerging markets is exactly where we were at in the first few months of the Latin American market: trying to figure out what those people in each of those countries love to watch and creating a service that is worth every penny of the subscription fee.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ben and I have both asked questions around cost structure and other components of the international business, I guess, to try and get an understanding of longer-term profitability. Understanding differences in ARPU and content cost by country and local or
componenttext: Ben and I have both asked questions around cost structure and other components of the international business, I guess, to try and get an understanding of longer-term profitability. Understanding differences in ARPU and content cost by country and local originals and things of that nature, is there a reason to think that international, in aggregate, shouldn't have contribution margins that are similar to the U.S. over time?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think each market will be different, but when you roll them up, I think, structurally, we can still get to where we've gotten to in the U.S. We've demonstrated a Canadian sort of proof point as well. It depends on whether you include them in that
componenttext: Well, I think each market will be different, but when you roll them up, I think, structurally, we can still get to where we've gotten to in the U.S. We've demonstrated a Canadian sort of proof point as well. It depends on whether you include them in that international bucket or not. But we do think that we can see across the system sort of a variety, but if you average across it, we can get to those levels of profitability. At least with the markets that we've seen today, I mean, we may penetrate into -- deeper into markets that have much lower ARPUs that may have a different characteristic. So then it's a choice of sort of how big of a market do we want to address at that price point. Is that the bigger pie from a revenue profit perspective? Or do we want to experiment down in the price to broaden the market and go after sort of a bigger market at maybe a lower margin? And I think we're too early to tell on that latter case.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then second question again for David and apologies if this was answered earlier. But in terms of the un-grandfathering process, where are you in the U.S. and then where are you in the international markets that you've named, in terms of customers that
componenttext: And then second question again for David and apologies if this was answered earlier. But in terms of the un-grandfathering process, where are you in the U.S. and then where are you in the international markets that you've named, in terms of customers that are going through that process having seen it at this point?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think that you -- in the letter, we sort of characterize it, but we're roughly halfway through. And that'll play out -- continue to play out over Q3 and into early Q4.
componenttext: Yes. I think that you -- in the letter, we sort of characterize it, but we're roughly halfway through. And that'll play out -- continue to play out over Q3 and into early Q4.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And that's consistent U.S. and those international markets?
componenttext: And that's consistent U.S. and those international markets?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Correct. Now a point worth making here is that our international markets, because they're newer, have more -- disproportionately more subscribers that are newer and already at the higher price points than the U.S. does. That's what makes the U.S. unique i
componenttext: Correct. Now a point worth making here is that our international markets, because they're newer, have more -- disproportionately more subscribers that are newer and already at the higher price points than the U.S. does. That's what makes the U.S. unique in this discussion.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let's wrap up with 2 more questions, you guys. Why don't you pick one each?
componenttext: Let's wrap up with 2 more questions, you guys. Why don't you pick one each?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to ask about Europe, especially the continent. You've been in a lot of these markets now for a couple years, but I think they've been slow. For either of you or all of you, what do you think you need to do in sort of Continental Europe and S
componenttext: I just wanted to ask about Europe, especially the continent. You've been in a lot of these markets now for a couple years, but I think they've been slow. For either of you or all of you, what do you think you need to do in sort of Continental Europe and Southern Europe to sort of accelerate that growth? And what is -- how much of it is content versus some of the payment stuff or anything else you might call out that you're working on?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, let's see. Just to remind you, in Spain and Italy, we only launched it last October. France was -- and Germany was a year or so before that. And we've had really nice success in all of those markets with continued strong growth following the growth
componenttext: Well, let's see. Just to remind you, in Spain and Italy, we only launched it last October. France was -- and Germany was a year or so before that. And we've had really nice success in all of those markets with continued strong growth following the growth that we've seen, for example, in the U.K. or Canada, which would be the closest proxies in terms of wealthy markets with high pay-TV penetration. So big competitive markets but we've got a solid game plan. We're growing in those markets. Payments are not an issue. So we feel very positive about those markets.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Last one, Reed, you mentioned payments. You've had payments as a source of friction in some earlier international launch markets. Can you talk about that in the newer markets and what you're doing there to facilitate that?
componenttext: Last one, Reed, you mentioned payments. You've had payments as a source of friction in some earlier international launch markets. Can you talk about that in the newer markets and what you're doing there to facilitate that?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Around the world, e-commerce is unequally well developed. So in some markets, there's very strong e-commerce payment platforms like The Netherlands. In other markets like Cambodia or Vietnam, it's challenging. Today, we only accept international cred
componenttext:
Yes. Around the world, e-commerce is unequally well developed. So in some markets, there's very strong e-commerce payment platforms like The Netherlands. In other markets like Cambodia or Vietnam, it's challenging. Today, we only accept international credit cards. So we'll develop, really, along e-commerce and that whole ecosystem as people want to pay for things online. And that may come through mobile payments like Android and iOS. It'll come along with third-party payment systems. But again, the general economy and people are moving online through mobile and we're going to be able to take advantage -- or we are taking advantage of that. So in the long term, it's not a big friction point because everyone's going to want to be able to purchase many things, including Netflix.
So thank you, both, and thank you to all of our investors. We apologize for the volatility. I know it's not easy on everyone. The big picture is very much intact, and we're very excited about it. And so we're continuing to execute on growing the business. Thank you very much.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you.
componenttext: Thank you.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome to the Netflix Q3 2016 Earnings Call. I'm David Wells, CFO, and joining me on the company side today is Reed Hastings, our CEO; and Ted Sarandos, our Chief Content Officer. Interviewing us will be Scott Devitt from Stifel -- sorry, Scott Devitt fr
componenttext:
Welcome to the Netflix Q3 2016 Earnings Call. I'm David Wells, CFO, and joining me on the company side today is Reed Hastings, our CEO; and Ted Sarandos, our Chief Content Officer. Interviewing us will be Scott Devitt from Stifel -- sorry, Scott Devitt from Stifel; and Ben Swinburne from Morgan Stanley. Ben is in his fourth interview before he passes the baton. 
Before we get started, we will be making forward-looking statements. Actual results may vary. 
Ben, I think you have the first question. Over to you.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much. Reed, maybe we could start by focusing in on the international strength this quarter. Typically, I think you and your colleagues have downplayed the impact of originals. But in the letter, you really called out the benefit on acquisit
componenttext: Thank you very much. Reed, maybe we could start by focusing in on the international strength this quarter. Typically, I think you and your colleagues have downplayed the impact of originals. But in the letter, you really called out the benefit on acquisitions from your original content that you noted Stranger Things and Narcos. Can you just shed some light on that? Why do you think those are having such an impact on gross adds today? And any particular color on markets that might surprise us about where those originals are really driving the business?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. If you look over the whole year, we've generated 12 million net adds this year. Last year, we generated 12 million net adds. So there's been remarkable steadiness measured over the 3-quarter period. But if you look at any single quarter, we're high,
componenttext:
Sure. If you look over the whole year, we've generated 12 million net adds this year. Last year, we generated 12 million net adds. So there's been remarkable steadiness measured over the 3-quarter period. But if you look at any single quarter, we're high, we're low. And I think what's happening is that when we have some big originals, it definitely grows the business. But some of that is a pull forward from the natural underlying growth rate. And so like if in hindsight, if we look back in Q1, we over interpreted that. In Q2, then we over interpreted a low. But it's actually quite steady over the midterm, which is basically a fundamental organic growth of this on-demand Internet 
[Audio Gap]

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: There's probably some logic to say that your net adds could improve next year overall, given you're not going to have this elevated churn. How do you think about the impact of churn as we move into '17? And do you have any expectations for price increases
componenttext: There's probably some logic to say that your net adds could improve next year overall, given you're not going to have this elevated churn. How do you think about the impact of churn as we move into '17? And do you have any expectations for price increases at this point?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we definitely want to increase net adds. But when I look over the last 3 or 4 years and how steady they've been, how hard they've been to move up, and similarly, that they've been very steady, we're only probably going to be able to make a little pr
componenttext: Well, we definitely want to increase net adds. But when I look over the last 3 or 4 years and how steady they've been, how hard they've been to move up, and similarly, that they've been very steady, we're only probably going to be able to make a little progress on increasing year-over-year net adds next year. So we're fundamentally in this growth cycle just to do with the Internet, Smart TV, getting people used to on-demand. All those aspects. So we're continuing to make progress. I wouldn't hook into the micro variables about this churn or that churn or this show. It's much more of a deep force that's changing the market as more and more people are getting used to Internet television.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Ben, if I might add, it's probably useful to talk about U.S. international a little bit differently. The U.S. is a much older market in terms of our ability to improve that product and have more time. We've kind of settled into our rate of churn that
componenttext: Yes, Ben, if I might add, it's probably useful to talk about U.S. international a little bit differently. The U.S. is a much older market in terms of our ability to improve that product and have more time. We've kind of settled into our rate of churn that's lower than some of our international markets that get there over time. But I would say, just in terms of that conversation, we think that there's room left to improve the U.S. As we -- as that sort of un-grandfathering effect fades out over time. But outside the U.S., we'll definitely have more opportunity to improve churn over time as we improve these products outside of the U.S.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: And not to do my less your hold impression, but Reed, to make you answer the question, do you have any expectations for price increases at this point that you could talk about?
componenttext: And not to do my less your hold impression, but Reed, to make you answer the question, do you have any expectations for price increases at this point that you could talk about?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, we have no plans on price increases outside of an inflation adjustments that we do in Brazil on annual, which is the law there.
componenttext: No, we have no plans on price increases outside of an inflation adjustments that we do in Brazil on annual, which is the law there.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ben, just a follow-up on another part of Ben's question, which was international over performance. Which markets actually over perform to the extent that you can identify specific markets or even that it was some of the older markets that were over perfor
componenttext: Ben, just a follow-up on another part of Ben's question, which was international over performance. Which markets actually over perform to the extent that you can identify specific markets or even that it was some of the older markets that were over performing relative to new or otherwise?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: For competitive reasons, we're really not going to break out per country markets and results. I would say we're having broad success around international. We're continuing to make those investments. We've got a lot of room to go to improve the service. We
componenttext: For competitive reasons, we're really not going to break out per country markets and results. I would say we're having broad success around international. We're continuing to make those investments. We've got a lot of room to go to improve the service. We mentioned the letter that we've only now just now localized Poland and Turkey that brings us up to 22 languages, YouTube is at 50, so we got a long way to go in that localization effort.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll just add really quick, that one of the really encouraging points was our big series that we had going on in the quarter, Luke Cage, Stranger Things, The Get Down, Narcos, of course. The great thing is it performed proportionally well globally so this
componenttext: I'll just add really quick, that one of the really encouraging points was our big series that we had going on in the quarter, Luke Cage, Stranger Things, The Get Down, Narcos, of course. The great thing is it performed proportionally well globally so this -- the content is traveling in a way that we hoped.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Scott and Ben, I would say, it wasn't any one market, right? I think it's okay to talk about the fact that it was a very broad-based performance across multiple international markets, so very broad.
componenttext: And Scott and Ben, I would say, it wasn't any one market, right? I think it's okay to talk about the fact that it was a very broad-based performance across multiple international markets, so very broad.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then secondly, the quarterly volatility in the stock and the performance relative to your visibility, 3 months out domestically and internationally, it certainly does seem to accelerate the grain process for folks like me that watch the business on a
componenttext: And then secondly, the quarterly volatility in the stock and the performance relative to your visibility, 3 months out domestically and internationally, it certainly does seem to accelerate the grain process for folks like me that watch the business on a quarterly basis. And we're just wondering to the extent that, Reed, you just mentioned the visibility into the business and the linearity and progression of subscriber growth on an annual basis, seems to be more predictable. Is there any thought in terms of providing annual guidance as it relates to subscriber growth instead of quarterly guidance?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm not, particularly. I think we can all see that -- it's time for me to apologize for the volatility again. This time, it's in a good direction. But I think more and more investors are able to look at the multiyear picture and they see the patterns emer
componenttext: I'm not, particularly. I think we can all see that -- it's time for me to apologize for the volatility again. This time, it's in a good direction. But I think more and more investors are able to look at the multiyear picture and they see the patterns emerging, and so then it will be less and less about our guidance. I think the main thing about 1-year guidance as we probably don't have any more insight than investors do. Whereas in the current quarter when we're 2 or 3 weeks into it, we do have a little bit of an advantage so that's why we do the current quarter guidance.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me ask you, Reed or David, about the X1 integration. Brian demoed it recently at a conference. It looks quite elegant. Do you expect this to be a meaningful contributor in the fourth quarter when we look at your domestic net adds? And maybe stepping b
componenttext: Let me ask you, Reed or David, about the X1 integration. Brian demoed it recently at a conference. It looks quite elegant. Do you expect this to be a meaningful contributor in the fourth quarter when we look at your domestic net adds? And maybe stepping back, Reed, do you think these partnerships play a larger role over time in driving your business than they have maybe historically?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we sure hope so. I mean, it's rolling out this quarter. It's really nice integration. Comcast users tend to be pretty advanced, high-income households. So many of them already have Netflix. But having them integrate into X1 will make it easier to use
componenttext: Yes, we sure hope so. I mean, it's rolling out this quarter. It's really nice integration. Comcast users tend to be pretty advanced, high-income households. So many of them already have Netflix. But having them integrate into X1 will make it easier to use. That increases the word of mouth. And all of these MVPD integrations they help just like being integrated and Smart televisions. So think of it as the more devices we're in, the easier it is to use. But there's no step function here because, again, most of those homes probably have Netflix already.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: And do you have any concerns at all that the consumer who accesses it through the X1 is not as deep in the Netflix universe from an experience perspective as they might be, using in a Smart TV or an app because as you're sort of navigating through the Xfi
componenttext: And do you have any concerns at all that the consumer who accesses it through the X1 is not as deep in the Netflix universe from an experience perspective as they might be, using in a Smart TV or an app because as you're sort of navigating through the Xfinity guide, how do you get comfortable that, that was not going to be a negative? Net negative or may be you felt like it was offset by other positives?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, there's definitely concerns like that. And on the same side and MVPD has concerns that by putting on Netflix, they'll be more Netflix awareness, and we have concerns that UI. But ultimately, where we get together is let's try to learn together what
componenttext: Well, there's definitely concerns like that. And on the same side and MVPD has concerns that by putting on Netflix, they'll be more Netflix awareness, and we have concerns that UI. But ultimately, where we get together is let's try to learn together what the customer really wants. And if we're thoughtful with each other, we're focused on the customer together we're both going to be able to prosper. And then on the X1 specifically, when you click on, say, it's in the guide to the show, it brings you into the Netflix user interface for showing you the show. And then the post play kicks in where you got the different follow-up shows that you can watch on Netflix.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Scott and Ben, we have other partners that we've launched with Virgin and others that we've gotten sort of an early preview in terms of how the consumer interacts with the application. And as long as we're able to continue to improve the attractivenes
componenttext: And Scott and Ben, we have other partners that we've launched with Virgin and others that we've gotten sort of an early preview in terms of how the consumer interacts with the application. And as long as we're able to continue to improve the attractiveness and the compellingness of the content and the experience of Netflix, we feel like we're -- we -- it's a good partnership.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the X1 is the most powerful CPU box we've ever seen in the MVPD space. So the percentage of streams that are HD and the UI is really spectacular. It's the best that we've ever seen.
componenttext: And the X1 is the most powerful CPU box we've ever seen in the MVPD space. So the percentage of streams that are HD and the UI is really spectacular. It's the best that we've ever seen.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Reed, you mentioned no plans for price increase in the near term. Now that you've gone through the un-grandfathering, which has created a level of consistency and pricing across the customer base, I'm wondering how you think about pricing increases in the
componenttext: Reed, you mentioned no plans for price increase in the near term. Now that you've gone through the un-grandfathering, which has created a level of consistency and pricing across the customer base, I'm wondering how you think about pricing increases in the future? It seems like with where the product is priced in the U.S. and internationally today, that there's still quite a bit of room. I'm just wondering philosophically, how you think about acting on that over time.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, look we've had a great couple of years on these price points. And there's a lot of competition entering the market. What we're focused on is how do we increase value to the consumer by having more spectacular shows, so that people watch more of Netf
componenttext: Well, look we've had a great couple of years on these price points. And there's a lot of competition entering the market. What we're focused on is how do we increase value to the consumer by having more spectacular shows, so that people watch more of Netflix. And over time, that will take care of itself, but we don't want to get overconfident just because we've had a good couple of years here.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: And there's a small technical carve-outs on Reed's answer in terms that we do have some territories in the world, countries in the world, changing their VAT or their GST laws into the extent that we feel like that's a territory or a country-level response
componenttext: And there's a small technical carve-outs on Reed's answer in terms that we do have some territories in the world, countries in the world, changing their VAT or their GST laws into the extent that we feel like that's a territory or a country-level response that we can pass that to the consumer, we may do that. But it's just -- we have a lot of different price points across the world at this point, so it's just a technical addition to Reed's answer.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then David, back to you. In terms of the commentary about material profits, we're now closing in on 2017. You added some language in the shareholder letter about mature process, again, in 2017 and continuing to grow from there. Could you add any numbe
componenttext: And then David, back to you. In terms of the commentary about material profits, we're now closing in on 2017. You added some language in the shareholder letter about mature process, again, in 2017 and continuing to grow from there. Could you add any numbers to that in terms of what material profits actually means? How we should think about that next year and then coming years?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we've added some numbers in Q3 and in our guide in Q4, so you're starting to see that operating margin grow and the operating profit, now we're growing both revenue and operating margin. So you're starting to see that grow already, but it will grow
componenttext: Well, we've added some numbers in Q3 and in our guide in Q4, so you're starting to see that operating margin grow and the operating profit, now we're growing both revenue and operating margin. So you're starting to see that grow already, but it will grow more and more materially next year and forward. So I think as we are able to reduce our international losses, we don't have another set of territories that we're launching next year. And as we're able to grow both margin and revenue in the U.S., you're seeing that lift out, but we'll have more specifics to say in Q1 in terms of providing some more guidance on that.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dave, let me just pick up on that since we're talking about sort of the financial outlook. It looks like this year, I think you guys are guiding to about $1.5 billion of free cash burn, which is higher than we were before. I mean, can you talk what's driv
componenttext: Dave, let me just pick up on that since we're talking about sort of the financial outlook. It looks like this year, I think you guys are guiding to about $1.5 billion of free cash burn, which is higher than we were before. I mean, can you talk what's driving that variance? And then as we look to next year, $6 billion of content amortization is a 20% growth rate year-on-year versus 50% this year. So we're seeing the content cost grow slow, yet if we look at content obligation, which drive [ph] the billions sequentially or your free cash flow guidance, I think it used to be similar next year to this year. The gap seems to be widening between amort and cash, maybe you could just talk about what's driving that, if I have that right.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, a little bit right. Let me correct a few points in there, but I would say our former sort of guidance for free cash flow was around a negative $1 billion, $1.2 billion. Now we're seeing $1.5 billion for this year. It's a little -- it's uncertain next
componenttext: Yes, a little bit right. Let me correct a few points in there, but I would say our former sort of guidance for free cash flow was around a negative $1 billion, $1.2 billion. Now we're seeing $1.5 billion for this year. It's a little -- it's uncertain next year what that number might be. But I'd be surprised if it grows on a quarterly basis. So I would say as we're able to raise operating income, we'll be able to fund more of that organically. So we should be able to take more of that inside in terms of -- and reduce our free cash flow. But I want to give some level room for the scale of the business. If we're successful and if we grow faster than we expect, then we could expand our content even more than what we consider we would do today. So there's [ph] a little bit of matching that to the scale growth of that business. How successful we are, how big the business we are growing internationally. And I would say in terms of the commitment number, that number is up to 14 2 [ph] from the 13s [ph] before. And that has a lot to do with the expansion of our originals, our licensed originals and our international. So we launched the Rest of the World in January this year. We continue to add content to all of our international markets as well, so we're seeing that grow. I would expect that to somewhat moderate in the 18- to 24-month period as we go forward. We don't have another international launch to layer on to that. But we are expanding the business so you got 2 forces there that sort of counteracting each other. But in terms of our -- go ahead.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ted, maybe you can go to it a little bit when we do the self-produced content like Stranger Things, all the advantages to it for the business, despite the increased use of cash.
componenttext: Ted, maybe you can go to it a little bit when we do the self-produced content like Stranger Things, all the advantages to it for the business, despite the increased use of cash.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, absolutely. I think -- when we see something like Stranger Things come across, there's the simple one, which is it doesn't come with the studio markup it's attached to it. That is just purely expenses not on screen. And the other is the much, much mo
componenttext: Yes, absolutely. I think -- when we see something like Stranger Things come across, there's the simple one, which is it doesn't come with the studio markup it's attached to it. That is just purely expenses not on screen. And the other is the much, much more flexibility in terms of the rights that we have and the rights -- and how we exploit and how we continue to maintain exclusivity, but we're not seeing the content against our wishes going to other markets in the syndication, in DVD and others. And we're able to produce it at a very high-quality and also much more efficiently. So to the extent that we can do that, while it does it require more cash upfront to fund the development process versus a studio who take that on, we find it's a great trade-off for cash.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just to reconcile back to your question. Some of that was already reflected in our forecasting and in our guidance. But I would say, as we get better and we sort of exercise that muscle of our own pod, more of that is reflected in our pipeline. So you're
componenttext: Just to reconcile back to your question. Some of that was already reflected in our forecasting and in our guidance. But I would say, as we get better and we sort of exercise that muscle of our own pod, more of that is reflected in our pipeline. So you're seeing that number, that 1.2 [ph] number flip [ph] up to 1.5.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Ted, there was a comment in the letter where you were talking about your recent acquisitions like Quantico and Designated Survivor. We talked about ensuring early financing. So just kind of connect David's point, are you talking about providing early
componenttext: And Ted, there was a comment in the letter where you were talking about your recent acquisitions like Quantico and Designated Survivor. We talked about ensuring early financing. So just kind of connect David's point, are you talking about providing early financing to studio partners in exchange for better windowing globally? Was that what that comment's related to that's impacting the free cash flow timing?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Nothing has been done to date. It's basically just setting the table, there's a bunch of other different ways that you can get involved as a production partner with our studio partners versus a second window buyer. Some of that would include securing fina
componenttext: Nothing has been done to date. It's basically just setting the table, there's a bunch of other different ways that you can get involved as a production partner with our studio partners versus a second window buyer. Some of that would include securing financing rather than having the studios continue to pursue deficit finance models.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. 600 hours of original content in 2016 is going through 1,000 hours in 2017. I think David, you recently said at a conference that you're about 1/3 to 1/2 of the way to the 50-50 split between original and third-party content. Where would that 1,00
componenttext: Got it. 600 hours of original content in 2016 is going through 1,000 hours in 2017. I think David, you recently said at a conference that you're about 1/3 to 1/2 of the way to the 50-50 split between original and third-party content. Where would that 1,000 hours put you in 2017?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's a combination of Ted and I, so I'll pass it to Ted in a second, but I would say, we don't have a target. The 50 -- my comment about 50% was more sort of grounding people towards the earlier comments that we made about 20% or 30%. So I'd say we
componenttext: Well, it's a combination of Ted and I, so I'll pass it to Ted in a second, but I would say, we don't have a target. The 50 -- my comment about 50% was more sort of grounding people towards the earlier comments that we made about 20% or 30%. So I'd say we like what we see in terms of the engagement on our originals. So we're continuing to expand them. And so we're going to keep growing that. We don't have a magic target that we're trying to hit. It's more about continued expansion and that mix of our content, being more of originals and less of licensing, but we're still expanding both licensing content is still expanding. Ted, if you want to add to that.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I will say -- I would just say, to your point, the licensed business, while as a percentage of business will shrink, as an absolute number it'll continue to grow for the next couple of years. And there isn't a magic target to David's point. We want to do
componenttext: I will say -- I would just say, to your point, the licensed business, while as a percentage of business will shrink, as an absolute number it'll continue to grow for the next couple of years. And there isn't a magic target to David's point. We want to do this, a really great compelling and differentiated programming for our members. And we get there through original programming when we do it successfully. So we just want to keep steering the business that way.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: And do you have any targets for the original content that is produced by your own studio in terms of the ratio that is ultimately produced by your own studio versus licensed originals?
componenttext: And do you have any targets for the original content that is produced by your own studio in terms of the ratio that is ultimately produced by your own studio versus licensed originals?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. Similarly, what we're trying not to do is get trapped in the business model to making creative choices, meaning that sometimes no one else the IP, and you want to do it right by the viewer by giving them great things to watch, and the only way to do t
componenttext: No. Similarly, what we're trying not to do is get trapped in the business model to making creative choices, meaning that sometimes no one else the IP, and you want to do it right by the viewer by giving them great things to watch, and the only way to do that is do it through a third-party licensed deal. Our financial preference of course, is to produce it through our studios, and when that opportunity will continue to present itself, we're going to increasingly do that as well. But we're not locking into a formula of how much of the programming should be self-produced versus third-party license.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Exactly.
componenttext: Exactly.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ted, it's. Let's just stick with you here for a minute on the content side. Stranger Things and the Get Down, interesting content examples over the summer that got a lot of attention. I believe the Get Down was quite expensive. Didn't seem to get the same
componenttext: Ted, it's. Let's just stick with you here for a minute on the content side. Stranger Things and the Get Down, interesting content examples over the summer that got a lot of attention. I believe the Get Down was quite expensive. Didn't seem to get the same size audience as Stranger Things, which I believe was less expensive and attractive economics. Why when you look at the Get Down, is that a good investment for you given the ticket size? And I think you've renewed it for a second season, what is that doing for your business that people might be missing or presence is missing?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's still to come. It's the second half of the first season, so that's still coming up. We're excited about how it got started. Yes, it's an expensive piece of television, mostly because it's a very large-scale cinematic. The reason why limits film
componenttext: Well, it's still to come. It's the second half of the first season, so that's still coming up. We're excited about how it got started. Yes, it's an expensive piece of television, mostly because it's a very large-scale cinematic. The reason why limits film works around the world is that it kind of attractiveness. So we're still seeing how it's going to unfold for first season, and all of the shows land at a different level of noise in the press and probably depending on what circles you run in, whether or not your friends are talking about it. But we're really very excited about how the show's been performing, particularly in the quarter when we had 4 shows that turned out to be kind of big event programs for us.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: And you've commented before that sort of output deals and Pay 1 deals from a timing perspective are suboptimal, but at the same time, you said really nice things about Disney's product over the years and how they work on your platform. How is the Pay 1 de
componenttext: And you've commented before that sort of output deals and Pay 1 deals from a timing perspective are suboptimal, but at the same time, you said really nice things about Disney's product over the years and how they work on your platform. How is the Pay 1 deal performing versus expectations? Are you happy with short term deals? If you'd like to do more of overtime with Disney?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think, we expect it to be a very popular content and it's turning out to be. So Zootopia was the first really high profile film to come through, and it's performing in huge numbers because it's great kids viewing, beyond being great movie viewing.
componenttext: Yes. I think, we expect it to be a very popular content and it's turning out to be. So Zootopia was the first really high profile film to come through, and it's performing in huge numbers because it's great kids viewing, beyond being great movie viewing. And the Disney brand are different from any other studio can deliver that kind of tent pole kids programming that the family loves and as long as it continues to perform at those levels, we'd look to expand it with Disney. But I don't think any other studio can really match that output and match those economics, and therefore, deliver that viewing. So we're going to still look opportunistically. Our films are available for that window. But really continue to put the energy behind our original film viewership as well.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: And in some countries, we have Disney movie, Australia, Canada, U.S. But in other countries like in the U.K. we lost the bidding to Sky about 2 years ago. So it really varies by market. We're one of the bidders and we hope to overtime, be one of the bigge
componenttext: And in some countries, we have Disney movie, Australia, Canada, U.S. But in other countries like in the U.K. we lost the bidding to Sky about 2 years ago. So it really varies by market. We're one of the bidders and we hope to overtime, be one of the biggest bidders so they choose us, but it really does vary by market.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Reed, it's been speculated in the media that downloading off-line viewing may become available on Netflix by the end of 2016. Can you provide any insights or clarity on that speculation?
componenttext: Reed, it's been speculated in the media that downloading off-line viewing may become available on Netflix by the end of 2016. Can you provide any insights or clarity on that speculation?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, we said this year is we're open to it. It's something we're looking at. But we have nothing more specific to offer.
componenttext: Yes. Well, we said this year is we're open to it. It's something we're looking at. But we have nothing more specific to offer.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then secondly. Password sharing in the U.S., you have plans in place that limit that. Just interested still in the enforcement of password sharing in the U.S. in terms of limiting that currently and in the future. And then similarly, with VPN networks
componenttext: And then secondly. Password sharing in the U.S., you have plans in place that limit that. Just interested still in the enforcement of password sharing in the U.S. in terms of limiting that currently and in the future. And then similarly, with VPN networks within the international business. Your views of that in terms of addressing content outside the countries that have certain geographic rights.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we've been very successful in finding technological ways of inhibiting cross-border VPNs, which is roughly like I mentioned. We didn't win the bidding for the Disney movies in the U.K. so it's clearly not fair to rule out our U.K. subscriber
componenttext: Well, I think we've been very successful in finding technological ways of inhibiting cross-border VPNs, which is roughly like I mentioned. We didn't win the bidding for the Disney movies in the U.K. so it's clearly not fair to rule out our U.K. subscribers to watch the Disney movies from Canada or to use the U.S. And so we found that with the help of the studio, some more technology to enforce their rights. We tried to get global rights for everything like How To Get Away With Murder from ABC, because then it's available to everyone, which is clearly what consumers wants. In terms of -- what was the other question you had?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Password sharing.
componenttext: Password sharing.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: No plans on making any changes there. Password sharing is something you have to learn to live with because there's so much legitimate password sharing, like with sharing with your spouse, with your kids. So there's no bright line. And we're doing fine as
componenttext: No plans on making any changes there. Password sharing is something you have to learn to live with because there's so much legitimate password sharing, like with sharing with your spouse, with your kids. So there's no bright line. And we're doing fine as is.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Reed, just sticking with the theme of Disney, made some interesting comments a couple of weeks ago, talking about how his bountiful group list of brands ABC, Pixar, Marvel, may not be enough in the future and the distribution, figuring out distribution wa
componenttext: Reed, just sticking with the theme of Disney, made some interesting comments a couple of weeks ago, talking about how his bountiful group list of brands ABC, Pixar, Marvel, may not be enough in the future and the distribution, figuring out distribution was important, any reaction to that? Because it seems to be aimed at over the top and he does have a relationship with Hulu, which is a potential competitor or may be a bigger competitor over time. Do you have any reactions to those comments?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I mean, they have a great strategy. They've got Hulu. They've got the major league baseball initiative and they bought some of that. And then of course, they've got Disney Life, which they operate in a number of countries. So it makes a ton of sense f
componenttext: No, I mean, they have a great strategy. They've got Hulu. They've got the major league baseball initiative and they bought some of that. And then of course, they've got Disney Life, which they operate in a number of countries. So it makes a ton of sense for them to be growing in the OTT side and to figure that out as it does for us to do content. I think you'll see more -- you saw CBS All Access in the last 2 years, really become a big focus for CBS. So it's just a continuation of that theme.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Ted, just somewhat related here, I realize this is a hypothetical. But access to content, it's a big debate for Netflix. And I'm curious if you thought being part of a larger media company would inhibit your ability to acquire content from others in t
componenttext: And Ted, just somewhat related here, I realize this is a hypothetical. But access to content, it's a big debate for Netflix. And I'm curious if you thought being part of a larger media company would inhibit your ability to acquire content from others in the industry who are competitors for that kind of company?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Like I said in previous quarters, this kind of frienemy [ph] model has existed for decades in television where competing studios produce for one another constantly. It's really the question that I think that our suppliers want to make when they're making
componenttext: Like I said in previous quarters, this kind of frienemy [ph] model has existed for decades in television where competing studios produce for one another constantly. It's really the question that I think that our suppliers want to make when they're making decisions around their expansion over the top is, can they make better returns selling to Netflix? Or building their own thing? And that's both a long-term and a short-term question than currently hypothetical.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Reed, just following up on competitor comments. Jeff Basos [ph], recently made a comment that possibly,  Amazon video could be the fourth pillar of Amazon's business. Just wondering how do you think about, you have such an extensive lead in this global bu
componenttext: Reed, just following up on competitor comments. Jeff Basos [ph], recently made a comment that possibly,  Amazon video could be the fourth pillar of Amazon's business. Just wondering how do you think about, you have such an extensive lead in this global build out. How do you think about Amazon long-term as a competitor and Mr. Bazosn' comments there?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we think about it as share of screening time. And when people are doing other things with their screens be they mobile or television screens, they're not doing Netflix. So Snapchat, YouTube, Facebook video, all of that is -- takes a lot of hours, pr
componenttext: Well, we think about it as share of screening time. And when people are doing other things with their screens be they mobile or television screens, they're not doing Netflix. So Snapchat, YouTube, Facebook video, all of that is -- takes a lot of hours, probably much more so than Amazon. But there are so many competitors out there for screen time than we win today. Such a small percentage of total screen time that moves by specific competitors are unlikely to have a material effect. What affects us is can we continue to win affection? And that's through doing all of this incredible content through expanding globally, having all those rights be global eventually, so those are the things we're focused on.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: And David, you commented in the letter about going to market for acquiring more debt on incoming weeks. You also mentioned at a conference recently that you thought the business was under levered. You mentioned a 5%, I think debt to cap ratio. How do you
componenttext: And David, you commented in the letter about going to market for acquiring more debt on incoming weeks. You also mentioned at a conference recently that you thought the business was under levered. You mentioned a 5%, I think debt to cap ratio. How do you think about debt longer-term in terms of what that looks like? And how you think about it? Is it net debt-to-EBITDA or otherwise?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, my comments at the Goldman Sachs conference about a 20% debt rate or a long-term optimization and cost to capital. I don't think we're talking about by the end of the year, getting to a 20% leverage ratio. So just to talk about sort of a shorter term
componenttext: Yes, my comments at the Goldman Sachs conference about a 20% debt rate or a long-term optimization and cost to capital. I don't think we're talking about by the end of the year, getting to a 20% leverage ratio. So just to talk about sort of a shorter term or a medium-term, we would be looking to raise as needed in terms of funding our content expansion. So we've been pretty clear along the year that we would go-to-market sometime this year to add a modest amount of debt to the balance sheet. And then do that on a recurring basis as needed to fund our content expansion. So over time though, we anticipate that we could get and would optimize our cost of capital up to a 20% leverage ratio. And we're talking about a debt to market cap at that point that I think we would be closer to an EBITDA basis as well because the business is going to be growing in operating income and EBITDA.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, you guys recently localized your first batch of Rest of World markets. I believe it was Poland and Turkey. And it sounds like it's been successful in driving growth in those markets. I guess the obvious question would be, why not move faster on loc
componenttext: David, you guys recently localized your first batch of Rest of World markets. I believe it was Poland and Turkey. And it sounds like it's been successful in driving growth in those markets. I guess the obvious question would be, why not move faster on localization? You've got a lot of recent Rest of World launches. Is that a cost-benefit analysis or human bandwidth sort of throttle? What is keeping you from moving quicker? And what's the right pace for us to think about '17?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can we move faster? I think it's a quality aspect, right? In terms of, we want to make sure that we have an eye towards quality as well. We had a couple of rough blog entries about some of our localization and subtitling in some markets that we pay attent
componenttext: Can we move faster? I think it's a quality aspect, right? In terms of, we want to make sure that we have an eye towards quality as well. We had a couple of rough blog entries about some of our localization and subtitling in some markets that we pay attention to those. So we're moving as quickly as we can being methodical and thoughtful about those opportunities to localize. And yes, we are pleased with both Poland and Turkey in terms of those impacts. It makes sense that people want to consume in their language. So it's not going to make sense to localize in a super small territory. But for the larger territories, it's going to make sense. And even for the medium-sized territories. We'll get there eventually. I think it's just a matter of sequencing.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just to come back to maybe more of the short-term. You had talked earlier this year, about Australia and New Zealand being a difficult comp, I do believe in Q2. You called out in letter Q4 comp in Spain, Portugal, Italy. Is there anyway to kind o
componenttext: And then just to come back to maybe more of the short-term. You had talked earlier this year, about Australia and New Zealand being a difficult comp, I do believe in Q2. You called out in letter Q4 comp in Spain, Portugal, Italy. Is there anyway to kind of put that fourth quarter comp in the second quarter comp in any kind of context order of magnitude.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Again, back to the Reed's earlier comments about for competitive reasons we don't talk specifics about our market I probably wouldn't. But I would say that there is a harvesting on demand initially when we launch in the market if that first launch quarter
componenttext: Again, back to the Reed's earlier comments about for competitive reasons we don't talk specifics about our market I probably wouldn't. But I would say that there is a harvesting on demand initially when we launch in the market if that first launch quarter that it had we tend to have higher net additions that have moderate rates over time sort of a run rate that's just a little bit normalized. We have the same thing going on that we highlighted in Q1 that we have Rest of World in the first quarter of this year, was a large number. And when I look at Wall Street's estimates for Q1, they're higher I think they're not taking that into account, so we wanted to call that out so that folks had the benefit of anticipating that.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Any other Wall Street estimates that you'd like to call out?
componenttext: Any other Wall Street estimates that you'd like to call out?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a growing operating income and just the fact that I think Q1 was a little high relative to our expectations.
componenttext: Just a growing operating income and just the fact that I think Q1 was a little high relative to our expectations.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got you. Thank you.
componenttext: Got you. Thank you.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ted, as you look at localized content and new markets. How easy or difficult is it to find the talent in those markets to produce the content? How successful have you been there? And along that same topics, how do you think about some of these newer marke
componenttext: Ted, as you look at localized content and new markets. How easy or difficult is it to find the talent in those markets to produce the content? How successful have you been there? And along that same topics, how do you think about some of these newer markets in terms of how much of that content ultimately, will need to be localized to create that S-curve inflection in some of the markets that were launched in 2016?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: So in terms of successes to date. [indiscernible] was our first Mexican original. It was quite successful and we're getting ready to bring out the second season. Marseille for our French customers, not only successful in France but successful throughout E
componenttext: So in terms of successes to date. [indiscernible] was our first Mexican original. It was quite successful and we're getting ready to bring out the second season. Marseille for our French customers, not only successful in France but successful throughout Europe and got a significant amount of watching in the United States subtitled and dubbed in English. So we're continuing to push. It's on degrees of difficulties. It's just a matter of understanding the production and the local tastes and who's working and making great films in those markets in some cases and are anxious to make the migration to television that they've been seeing happening in the U.S. So it's difficult in terms of not being on the ground they're usually. But I think we're making trade-offs in terms of the company culture to travel our folks into territory, get to know the folks in the markets, work with the best and brightest filmmakers and television creators, and bring their shows to the global markets through Netflix. And in terms of localizing for taste. In many parts of the world, U.S. content or English-speaking content localize in the local languages have been incredibly successful. In some cases where tastes run much more local like Japan, like India. We're certain that will take more of a local approach in terms of licensing and producing more local language content there as well. But I think over time that the taste will fall into line with the kind of desire to see the big spectacular shows that people are talking about around the world no matter where you are.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: And ted, maybe you can give some color on [indiscernible] on cable growth, in terms of being content spent beyond their home market.
componenttext: And ted, maybe you can give some color on [indiscernible] on cable growth, in terms of being content spent beyond their home market.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Absolutely. What we're trying to do, we're producing -- as to Reed's point, we're trying to going into production with early today called dark in Germany. Quite a successful filmmaker whose films have traveled around the world. We've been in the business
componenttext: Absolutely. What we're trying to do, we're producing -- as to Reed's point, we're trying to going into production with early today called dark in Germany. Quite a successful filmmaker whose films have traveled around the world. We've been in the business of buying though films and making them travel around the world for years. So I think that will continue with the move into multi-episodic series as well. So we get that scale advantage of being able to take a German show that the German audiences will be very excited about and we know that, that will expand throughout Europe and that we've been really great at finding audiences even in the U.S. and subtitled and dubs, which has been really a niche business for most people but very mainstream numbers for us.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
