componenttextpreview: Going back to David's comment about the difficult first quarter comp internationally. You had 130 markets that launched in the beginning of 2016, so it's obvious what the comp issue is. But also in your business, you have that initial wave but then you ha
componenttext: Going back to David's comment about the difficult first quarter comp internationally. You had 130 markets that launched in the beginning of 2016, so it's obvious what the comp issue is. But also in your business, you have that initial wave but then you have things like localized content, awareness and other factors that actually drive as an example in the Latin American market that inflection that happened 2 to 3 years after the initial launch. So as we look at 1Q '17, and then think about the 130 [ph] new markets, how do we think about that initial bump relative to the potential of these new markets actually beginning to really kick in throughout the year in '17?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, as you say, they do -- one is going positive in terms of growth and one is negative in terms of initial launch. What I was trying to call out without actually providing our Q1 guidance in January, was back in January of this year, which I tried to m
componenttext: Well, as you say, they do -- one is going positive in terms of growth and one is negative in terms of initial launch. What I was trying to call out without actually providing our Q1 guidance in January, was back in January of this year, which I tried to moderate the estimates or the expectations coming out of our global launch, we had a very successful launch. In Q1, we had a lot of demand associated with that launch that started moderating into Q2. And I think people saw the success of Q1, and really raised their numbers for Q2, and trying to get a little bit ahead of that in the sense that we're trying to get the successful launch in Q1 this year, which is going to be very difficult to replicate. Some of that was pent-up demand and we're not going to be able to do that. That's not to say that many of our other markets are growing in terms of growth. It's just right now, in terms of what we see that large launch is going to overwhelm some of the growth in the other markets. So we still like what we're seeing in those markets. We're growing year-on-year in some. Some are moderate. We've had a very difficult a wide variety slow down and then accelerate in growth. So if you extract the back and the general trend is the world is embracing Internet television and we're riding on a very strong kind of tailwind of technological change. And that is definitely intact.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, any color on how the 2014 markets are ramping? Or at least France and Germany, at least in particular I think there's some concern in the marketplace that France isn't going well, I think you closed an office there. And in Germany, Amazon seems to
componenttext: David, any color on how the 2014 markets are ramping? Or at least France and Germany, at least in particular I think there's some concern in the marketplace that France isn't going well, I think you closed an office there. And in Germany, Amazon seems to be doing quite well. So can you just talk about how the model may or may not be working in those 2014 markets?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me disconnect one thing there, in terms that we did choose to consolidate some of our staff but that had nothing to do with the market whether the market was growing or not. That had everything to do with the synergy of communication and how the team
componenttext: Let me disconnect one thing there, in terms that we did choose to consolidate some of our staff but that had nothing to do with the market whether the market was growing or not. That had everything to do with the synergy of communication and how the team is working together. And then terms of the we don't see much for competitive reasons. But you have to take my earlier comment about what we saw in the very broad sort of outperformance relative to expectations in this quarter or in Q3, that will be inclusive of those markets. So I think [indiscernible] with things are going.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Shifting gears back to you, Ted I'm hoping pronouncing this right, [indiscernible] from NBC recently and one of her mandates is unscripted. So I'm just wondering is unscripted going from something you have a couple of bits into something more strat
componenttext: Great. Shifting gears back to you, Ted I'm hoping pronouncing this right, [indiscernible] from NBC recently and one of her mandates is unscripted. So I'm just wondering is unscripted going from something you have a couple of bits into something more strategic for you? You think about 600 hours to 1,000, how much is unscripted driving growth? Is it a material plan for next year, and why?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's not a material part to next year. But I imagine it will be growing over the next several years. It's been is an area of viewing that people around the world in joy. The content travels well. is efficient to produce. The current sources of second wind
componenttext: It's not a material part to next year. But I imagine it will be growing over the next several years. It's been is an area of viewing that people around the world in joy. The content travels well. is efficient to produce. The current sources of second window on scripted programming are under a great deal of programming under the not to sell their content to -- off of their own universe because many of the episode seem to be interchangeable. So being able to have a good steady flow of high-quality unscripted program is something we want to focus on because I think we can do it well and efficiently and may be elevated in now way that is the travel maybe more than it does today.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just follow up quickly on unscripted. It seemed to be not obvious for the on-demand binging consumption model. But maybe you have some talk stuff or your comedies that maybe suggests it is. I don't know, what can you tell us about that?
componenttext: And just follow up quickly on unscripted. It seemed to be not obvious for the on-demand binging consumption model. But maybe you have some talk stuff or your comedies that maybe suggests it is. I don't know, what can you tell us about that?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: There's certainly some benefits on the scale of those shows. but our ability to producing maybe not a lot of data and a lot of content that gets watched in with travels and what doesn't, what gets repeated and what doesn't. It gives us a higher degree of
componenttext: There's certainly some benefits on the scale of those shows. but our ability to producing maybe not a lot of data and a lot of content that gets watched in with travels and what doesn't, what gets repeated and what doesn't. It gives us a higher degree of confidence today than we had a couple of years ago and our ability or even desire to produce at the space, but it is a segmented programming. We keep opening up new segments of programming, the way we did talk shows last year. The way we did in the first quarter with ultimate Beast Master, our first competition show. So we're pressing into some areas of the business all the time to bring new, unique elevated and differentiated program to our members.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Reed, investors get caught up a lot in the 60 million to 90 million household number in the U.S. And as an indicator or predictor for success in international markets, overtime, if you can do it in the U.S., you can do it internationally, and if you can't
componenttext: Reed, investors get caught up a lot in the 60 million to 90 million household number in the U.S. And as an indicator or predictor for success in international markets, overtime, if you can do it in the U.S., you can do it internationally, and if you can't, you can't. You're running a little north of 4 million subscribers in 2016 from 5 million in 2015. How do you think about that business in terms of the trajectory over say, the next 1, 3, 5 years in terms of how many subs that you can put on the business in the U.S. on an annual basis?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: You don't have to take it year-by-year. It depends on how well we execute. Do we have more Stranger Things, wherever and breaks through, and everyone feels like they got to get get. Luke Cage, Get Down, Narcos. We have a show coming up the ground and some
componenttext: You don't have to take it year-by-year. It depends on how well we execute. Do we have more Stranger Things, wherever and breaks through, and everyone feels like they got to get get. Luke Cage, Get Down, Narcos. We have a show coming up the ground and some of our most impressive television I've ever seen. And so I think November 4, when you ask yourself about 60 million to 90 million, when you watch that show, it's going to seem quite achievable, but it's all hangs on how well we execute. And we're just going to work really hard on that front.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: And following along those lines in terms of the relevance of contents to drive subscribers given that that's why subscribers watch the shows on Netflix. On a P&L basis anyway, the growth in content spend has begun to very much leverage relative to the gro
componenttext: And following along those lines in terms of the relevance of contents to drive subscribers given that that's why subscribers watch the shows on Netflix. On a P&L basis anyway, the growth in content spend has begun to very much leverage relative to the growth in the digital revenue stream. And just wondering, as we look at that in '17 over '16, and then '18, '19 and '20, is that something that we can expect to continue into the future? Is there a point in time that some level of spend at which you think you've built a complete enough portfolio that, that leverage actually significantly accelerates?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, we'll keep investing in growing the content spend even domestically for quite a long time. We see an ability to continue to please consumers with a wide range of content. And so I think if you're trying to model the business long-term, you should thin
componenttext: No, we'll keep investing in growing the content spend even domestically for quite a long time. We see an ability to continue to please consumers with a wide range of content. And so I think if you're trying to model the business long-term, you should think of content and how it's viewed and brand love always continuing up in the U.S. and internationally for a long time. I mean, I'll take 2 more questions, one from each of you.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. I know we beat un-grandfathering to death last quarter, but if I can come back one more time before I sign off. David, you had talked last quarter about elevated churn even among members that were not seeing a price increase. And I think this quart
componenttext: Great. I know we beat un-grandfathering to death last quarter, but if I can come back one more time before I sign off. David, you had talked last quarter about elevated churn even among members that were not seeing a price increase. And I think this quarter talked about churn generally being in line with expectations. I just want to see if you had any color on that piece either the un-grandfathering elevate churn and I'll just ask my follow-up. On the fourth quarter, just want to confirm the only un-grandfathering that we have left is the $1 cohort is that -- how is that accurate?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's accurate on the last one. We had some sort of older generation devices that are difficult to as well, so I think that defines sort of the last few cohorts of people left. And then back to is a primarily question in terms of what did we see in the qua
componenttext: It's accurate on the last one. We had some sort of older generation devices that are difficult to as well, so I think that defines sort of the last few cohorts of people left. And then back to is a primarily question in terms of what did we see in the quarter relative to our expectations? And relative to prior quarters and actuals? I would say I mentioned earlier in the interview, that we still see some effect from the un-grandfathering. So there is a bit of an overhang from the price change. It's starting to fade, and we expect that to continue to fade but we do think there's opportunity to improve that going forward in terms of next year.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Reed, last one. An open-ended question. You've talked a lot historically about the opportunities in Internet TV and you're very right in terms of the direction where this industry is gone with where you're businesses now, I was wondering if you just share
componenttext: Reed, last one. An open-ended question. You've talked a lot historically about the opportunities in Internet TV and you're very right in terms of the direction where this industry is gone with where you're businesses now, I was wondering if you just share some updated news in terms of the way you think the industry progresses over the next 5, 10, 20 years in terms of what wins and what loses?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well we generally think that the growth of Internet TV like the growth of the mobile phone, that is fixed line telephony was an amazing invention, 100 years of development and broad, incredible benefits to society. In the same thing is true with linear TV
componenttext: Well we generally think that the growth of Internet TV like the growth of the mobile phone, that is fixed line telephony was an amazing invention, 100 years of development and broad, incredible benefits to society. In the same thing is true with linear TV. It's been an amazing innovation, but the age of linear is starting to fade and it's going to be replaced by Internet. And those firms like the BBC or CVS, that's doing all access that's invest heavily, I think will move into the future on Internet consumption. I think you'll see Internet growth generally more broadband kind of fiber optic to every village in town. Those general trend lines, the growth both of YouTube-type advertising support services, Facebook video, Snapchat. So you're just going to see these new scenarios everywhere. And eventually, movies and TV shows will be global, ubiquitous, some amazing budgets. So I think you have to think big about the future. We're closing in on 100 million members. But I'll remind everyone on Netflix that Facebook and YouTube have 1 billion daily actives. And so in many parts, we are just so small compared to those other Internet video firms. And we have a lot of catch-up to do and that's again investing in our content and making it globally interesting and compelling which we're working on. So there's a lot out there. But we only just have to take it year by year, and it's tremendous fun inventing the future. Thank you.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, gentleman.
componenttext: Thank you, gentleman.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome to the Netflix Q3 2016 Earnings Call. I'm David Wells, CFO, and joining me on the company side today is Reed Hastings, our CEO; and Ted Sarandos, our Chief Content Officer. Interviewing us will be Scott Devitt from Stifel -- sorry, Scott Devitt fr
componenttext:
Welcome to the Netflix Q3 2016 Earnings Call. I'm David Wells, CFO, and joining me on the company side today is Reed Hastings, our CEO; and Ted Sarandos, our Chief Content Officer. Interviewing us will be Scott Devitt from Stifel -- sorry, Scott Devitt from Stifel; and Ben Swinburne from Morgan Stanley. Ben is in his fourth interview before he passes the baton. 
Before we get started, we will be making forward-looking statements. Actual results may vary. 
Ben, I think you have the first question. Over to you.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much. Reed, maybe we could start by focusing in on the international strength this quarter. Typically, I think you and your colleagues have downplayed the impact of originals. But in the letter, you really called out the benefit on acquisit
componenttext: Thank you very much. Reed, maybe we could start by focusing in on the international strength this quarter. Typically, I think you and your colleagues have downplayed the impact of originals. But in the letter, you really called out the benefit on acquisitions from your original content that you noted Stranger Things and Narcos. Can you just shed some light on that? Why do you think those are having such an impact on gross adds today? And any particular color on markets that might surprise us about where those originals are really driving the business?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. If you look over the whole year, we've generated 12 million net adds this year. Last year, we generated 12 million net adds. So there's been remarkable steadiness measured over the 3-quarter period. But if you look at any single quarter, we're high,
componenttext: Sure. If you look over the whole year, we've generated 12 million net adds this year. Last year, we generated 12 million net adds. So there's been remarkable steadiness measured over the 3-quarter period. But if you look at any single quarter, we're high, we're low. And I think what's happening is that when we have some big originals, it definitely grows the business. But some of that is a pull forward from the natural underlying growth rate. And so like if in hindsight, if we look back in Q1, we over interpreted that. In Q2, then we over interpreted a low. But it's actually quite steady over the midterm, which is basically a fundamental organic growth of this on-demand Internet television. So think of it as it can affect the quarter a lot. It affects the year only a little that is as the total programming is there.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: And you mentioned that the churn, I think, globally was roughly in line with your expectations as you move through the quarters. So if we just think about the longer term, particularly next year. There probably some logic to say that your net adds could i
componenttext: And you mentioned that the churn, I think, globally was roughly in line with your expectations as you move through the quarters. So if we just think about the longer term, particularly next year. There probably some logic to say that your net adds could improve next year overall, given you're not going to have this elevated churn. How do you think about the impact of churn as we move into '17? And do you have any expectations for price increases at this point?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we definitely want to increase net adds. But when I look over the last 3 or 4 years and how steady they've been, how hard they've been to move up, and similarly, that they've been very steady, we're only probably going to be able to make a little pr
componenttext: Well, we definitely want to increase net adds. But when I look over the last 3 or 4 years and how steady they've been, how hard they've been to move up, and similarly, that they've been very steady, we're only probably going to be able to make a little progress on increasing year-over-year net adds next year. So we're fundamentally in this growth cycle just to do with the Internet, Smart TV, people getting used to on-demand. All of those aspects. So we're continuing to make progress. I wouldn't hook into the micro variables about this churn or that churn or this show. It's much more of a deep force that's changing the market as more and more people are getting used to Internet television.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Ben, if I might add, it's probably useful to talk about U.S. and international a little bit differently. The U.S. is a much older market in terms of our ability to improve that product and have more time. We've kind of settled into our rate of churn
componenttext: Yes, Ben, if I might add, it's probably useful to talk about U.S. and international a little bit differently. The U.S. is a much older market in terms of our ability to improve that product and have more time. We've kind of settled into our rate of churn that's lower than some of our international markets that get there over time. But I would say, just in terms of that conversation, we think that there's room left to improve the U.S. As we -- as that sort of un-grandfathering effect fades out over time. But outside the U.S., we'll definitely have more opportunity to improve churn over time as we improve these products outside of the U.S.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: And not to do my Lester Holt impression but, Reed, to make you answer the question, do you have any expectations for price increases at this point that you could talk about?
componenttext: And not to do my Lester Holt impression but, Reed, to make you answer the question, do you have any expectations for price increases at this point that you could talk about?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, we have no plans on price increases outside of an inflation adjustments that we do in Brazil on an annual, which is the law there.
componenttext: No, we have no plans on price increases outside of an inflation adjustments that we do in Brazil on an annual, which is the law there.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ben, to just follow up on another part of Ben's question, which was international over performance. Which markets actually over perform to the extent that you can identify specific markets or even that it was some of the older markets that were over perfo
componenttext: Ben, to just follow up on another part of Ben's question, which was international over performance. Which markets actually over perform to the extent that you can identify specific markets or even that it was some of the older markets that were over performing relative to new or otherwise?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: For competitive reasons, we're really not going to break out per country markets and results. I would say we're having broad success around international. We're continuing to make those investments. We've got a lot of room to go to improve the service. We
componenttext: For competitive reasons, we're really not going to break out per country markets and results. I would say we're having broad success around international. We're continuing to make those investments. We've got a lot of room to go to improve the service. We mentioned the letter that we've only just now localized Poland and Turkey that brings us up to 22 languages, YouTube is at 50, so we got a long way to go in that localization effort.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll just add really quick, that one of the really encouraging points was our big series that we had going on in the quarter, Luke Cage, Stranger Things, The Get Down, Narcos, of course. The great thing is it performed proportionally well globally so this
componenttext: I'll just add really quick, that one of the really encouraging points was our big series that we had going on in the quarter, Luke Cage, Stranger Things, The Get Down, Narcos, of course. The great thing is it performed proportionally well globally so this -- the content is traveling in a way that we'd hoped.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Scott and Ben, I would say, it wasn't any one market, right? I think it's okay to talk about the fact that it was a very broad-based performance across multiple international markets, so very broad.
componenttext: And Scott and Ben, I would say, it wasn't any one market, right? I think it's okay to talk about the fact that it was a very broad-based performance across multiple international markets, so very broad.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then secondly, the quarterly volatility in the stock and the performance relative to your visibility, 3 months out domestically, internationally, it certainly does seem to accelerate the grain process for folks like me that watch the business on a qua
componenttext: And then secondly, the quarterly volatility in the stock and the performance relative to your visibility, 3 months out domestically, internationally, it certainly does seem to accelerate the grain process for folks like me that watch the business on a quarterly basis. And we're just wondering to the extent that, Reed, you just mentioned that the visibility into the business and the linearity and progression of subscriber growth on an annual basis, seems to be more predictable. Is there any thought in terms of providing annual guidance as it relates to subscriber growth instead of quarterly guidance?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm not, particularly. I think we can all see that -- it's time for me to apologize for the volatility again. This time, it's in a good direction. But I think more and more investors are able to look at the multiyear picture and they see the patterns emer
componenttext: I'm not, particularly. I think we can all see that -- it's time for me to apologize for the volatility again. This time, it's in a good direction. But I think more and more investors are able to look at the multiyear picture and they see the patterns emerging, and so then it will be less and less about our guidance. I think the main thing about 1-year guidance as we probably don't have any more insight than investors do. Whereas in the current quarter when we're 2 or 3 weeks into it, we do have a little bit of an advantage so that's why we do the current quarter guidance.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me ask you, Reed or David, about the X1 integration. Brian demoed it recently at a conference. It looks quite elegant. Do you expect this to be a meaningful contributor in the fourth quarter when we look at your domestic net adds? And maybe stepping b
componenttext: Let me ask you, Reed or David, about the X1 integration. Brian demoed it recently at a conference. It looks quite elegant. Do you expect this to be a meaningful contributor in the fourth quarter when we look at your domestic net adds? And maybe stepping back, Reed, do you think these partnerships play a larger role over time in driving your business than they have maybe historically?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we sure hope so. I mean, it's rolling out this quarter. It's a really nice integration. Comcast users tend to be pretty advanced, high-income households. So many of them already have Netflix. But having them integrate into X1 will make it easier to u
componenttext: Yes, we sure hope so. I mean, it's rolling out this quarter. It's a really nice integration. Comcast users tend to be pretty advanced, high-income households. So many of them already have Netflix. But having them integrate into X1 will make it easier to use. That increases the word of mouth. And all of these MVPD integrations they help just like being integrated and Smart televisions. So think of it as the more devices we're in, the easier it is to use. But there's no step function here because, again, most of those homes probably have Netflix already.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: And do you have any concerns at all that the consumer who access is it through the X1 is not as deep in the Netflix universe from an experience perspective as they might be, using in a Smart TV or an app because they're sort of navigating through the Xfin
componenttext: And do you have any concerns at all that the consumer who access is it through the X1 is not as deep in the Netflix universe from an experience perspective as they might be, using in a Smart TV or an app because they're sort of navigating through the Xfinity guide, how do you get comfortable that, that wasn't going to be a negative? Net negative or may be you felt like it was offset by other positives?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, there's definitely concerns like that. And on the same side and MVPD has concerns that by putting on Netflix, they'll build more Netflix awareness, and we have concerns that the UI. But ultimately, where we get together is let's try to learn togethe
componenttext: Well, there's definitely concerns like that. And on the same side and MVPD has concerns that by putting on Netflix, they'll build more Netflix awareness, and we have concerns that the UI. But ultimately, where we get together is let's try to learn together what the customer really wants. And if we're thoughtful with each other, we're focused on the customer together we're both going to be able to prosper. And then on the X1 specifically, when you click on, say, it's in the guide to the show, it brings you into the Netflix user interface for showing you the show. And then the post play kicks in where you got the different follow-up shows that you can watch on Netflix.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Scott and Ben, we have other partners that we've launched with Virgin and others that we've gotten sort of an early preview in terms of how the consumer interacts with the application. And as long as we're able to continue to improve the attractivenes
componenttext: And Scott and Ben, we have other partners that we've launched with Virgin and others that we've gotten sort of an early preview in terms of how the consumer interacts with the application. And as long as we're able to continue to improve the attractiveness and the compellingness of the content and the experience of Netflix, we feel like we're -- we -- it's a good partnership.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the X1 is the most powerful CPU box we've ever seen in the MVPD space. And so the percentage of streams that are HD and the UI is really spectacular. It's the best that we've ever seen.
componenttext: And the X1 is the most powerful CPU box we've ever seen in the MVPD space. And so the percentage of streams that are HD and the UI is really spectacular. It's the best that we've ever seen.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Reed, you mentioned no plans for pricing increase in the near term. Now that you've gone through the un-grandfathering, which has created a level of consistency in pricing across the customer base, I'm wondering how you think about pricing increases in th
componenttext: Reed, you mentioned no plans for pricing increase in the near term. Now that you've gone through the un-grandfathering, which has created a level of consistency in pricing across the customer base, I'm wondering how you think about pricing increases in the future? It seems like with where the product is priced in the U.S. and internationally today, that there's still quite a bit of room. I'm just wondering, philosophically, how you think about acting on that over time.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, look, we've had a great couple of years at these price points. And there's a lot of competition entering the market. What we're focused on is just how do we increase value to the consumer by having more spectacular shows, so that people watch more o
componenttext: Well, look, we've had a great couple of years at these price points. And there's a lot of competition entering the market. What we're focused on is just how do we increase value to the consumer by having more spectacular shows, so that people watch more of Netflix. And over time, that will take care of itself, but we don't want to get overconfident just because we've had a good couple of years here.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: And there's a small technical carve-outs on Reed's answer in terms of we do have some territories of the world, countries of the world, changing their VAT or their GST laws into the extent that we feel like that's a territory or a country-level response a
componenttext: And there's a small technical carve-outs on Reed's answer in terms of we do have some territories of the world, countries of the world, changing their VAT or their GST laws into the extent that we feel like that's a territory or a country-level response and we can pass that to the consumer, we may do that. It's just -- we have a lot of different price points across the world at this point. So it's just a technical addition to Reed's answer.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then David, back to you. In terms of the commentary about material profits, we're now closing in on 2017. You added some language in the shareholder letter about mature process, again, in 2017 and continuing to grow from there. Could you add any numbe
componenttext: And then David, back to you. In terms of the commentary about material profits, we're now closing in on 2017. You added some language in the shareholder letter about mature process, again, in 2017 and continuing to grow from there. Could you add any numbers to that in terms of what material profits actually means? How we should think about that next year and then coming years?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we've added some numbers in Q3 and in our guide in Q4, so you're starting to see that operating margin grow and the operating profit, and we're growing both revenue and operating margin. So you're starting to see that grow already, but it will grow
componenttext: Well, we've added some numbers in Q3 and in our guide in Q4, so you're starting to see that operating margin grow and the operating profit, and we're growing both revenue and operating margin. So you're starting to see that grow already, but it will grow more and more materially next year and forward. So I think as we are able to reduce our international losses, we don't have another set of territories that we're launching next year. And as we're able to grow both margin and revenue in the U.S., you're seeing that lift out, but we'll have more specifics to say in Q1 in terms of providing some more guidance on that.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, let me just pick up on that since we're talking about sort of the financial outlook. It looks like this year, I think you guys are guiding to about $1.5 billion of free cash burn, which is higher than we were before. I mean, we could talk about wha
componenttext: David, let me just pick up on that since we're talking about sort of the financial outlook. It looks like this year, I think you guys are guiding to about $1.5 billion of free cash burn, which is higher than we were before. I mean, we could talk about what's driving that variance? And then as we look to next year, $6 billion of content amortization is a 20% growth rate year-on-year versus 50% this year. So we're seeing the content costs grow slow, yet if we look at content obligation, which are up a billion sequentially or your free cash flow guidance, I think it was -- it used to be similar next year to this year. The gap seems to be widening between amort and cash, maybe you could just talk about what's driving that, if I have that right.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, a little bit right, I mean -- correct a few points in there. But I would say our former sort of guidance for free cash flow was around a negative $1 billion, $1.2 billion. Now we're seeing $1.5 billion for this year. It's a little -- it's uncertain n
componenttext: Yes, a little bit right, I mean -- correct a few points in there. But I would say our former sort of guidance for free cash flow was around a negative $1 billion, $1.2 billion. Now we're seeing $1.5 billion for this year. It's a little -- it's uncertain next year what that number might be. But I'd be surprised if it grows on a quarterly basis. So I would say as we're able to raise operating income, we'll be able to fund more of that organically. So we should be able to take more of that inside in terms of -- and reduce our free cash flow. But I want to give some level room for the scale of the business. If we're successful and if we grow faster than we expect, then we could expand our content even more than what we consider we would do today. So there's a little bit of matching that to the scale growth of that business. How successful we are, how big the business we are growing internationally. And I would say in terms of the commitment number, that number is up to 14 2 from the 13s before. And that has a lot to do with the expansion of our originals, our licensed originals and our international. So we launched the Rest of World in January this year. We continue to add content to all of our international markets as well, so you're seeing that grow. I would expect that to somewhat moderate in the 18- to 24-month period as we go forward. We don't have another international launch to layer on to that. But we are expanding the business so you got 2 forces there that sort of counteracting each other. But in terms of our -- go ahead.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ted, maybe you can go to it a little bit when we do the self-produced content like Stranger Things, all the advantages to it for the business, despite the increased use of cash.
componenttext: Ted, maybe you can go to it a little bit when we do the self-produced content like Stranger Things, all the advantages to it for the business, despite the increased use of cash.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, absolutely. I think -- when we see something like Stranger Things come across, there's the simple one, which is it doesn't come with the studio markup it's attached to it. That is just purely expenses not on screen. And the other is the much, much mo
componenttext: Yes, absolutely. I think -- when we see something like Stranger Things come across, there's the simple one, which is it doesn't come with the studio markup it's attached to it. That is just purely expenses not on screen. And the other is the much, much more flexibility in terms of the rights that we have and the rights -- and how we exploit and how we continue to maintain exclusivity, but we're not seeing the content against our wishes going to other markets in the syndication, in DVD and others. And we're able to produce it at a very high-quality and also much more efficiently. So to the extent that we can do that, while it does -- it require more cash upfront to fund the development process versus a studio who take that on, we find it's a great trade-off for cash.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: To reconcile back to -- just to reconcile back to your question. Some of that was already reflected in our forecasting and in our guidance. But I would say, as we get better and we sort of exercise that muscle of our own production, more of that is reflec
componenttext: To reconcile back to -- just to reconcile back to your question. Some of that was already reflected in our forecasting and in our guidance. But I would say, as we get better and we sort of exercise that muscle of our own production, more of that is reflected in our pipeline. So you're seeing that number, that 1.2 number float up to 1.5.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Ted, there was a comment in the letter where you were talking about your recent acquisitions like Quantico and Designated Survivor. You talked about ensuring early financing. So just trying to connect David's point and Ted's point, are you talking abo
componenttext: And Ted, there was a comment in the letter where you were talking about your recent acquisitions like Quantico and Designated Survivor. You talked about ensuring early financing. So just trying to connect David's point and Ted's point, are you talking about providing early financing to studio partners in exchange for better windowing globally? Was that what that comment's related to and then maybe that's impacting the free cash flow timing?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Nothing has been done to date. It's basically just setting the table, there's a bunch of other different ways that you can get involved as a production partner with our studio partners versus a second window buyer. And some of that would include securing
componenttext: Nothing has been done to date. It's basically just setting the table, there's a bunch of other different ways that you can get involved as a production partner with our studio partners versus a second window buyer. And some of that would include securing financing rather than having the studios continue to pursue deficit finance models.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. 600 hours of original content in 2016 is going through 1,000 hours in 2017. I think David, you recently said at a conference that you're about 1/3 to 1/2 of the way to the 50-50 split between original and third-party content. Where would that 1,00
componenttext: Got it. 600 hours of original content in 2016 is going through 1,000 hours in 2017. I think David, you recently said at a conference that you're about 1/3 to 1/2 of the way to the 50-50 split between original and third-party content. Where would that 1,000 hours put you in 2017?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's a combination of Ted and I, so I'll pass it to Ted in a second, but I would say, we don't have a target. The 50 -- my comment about 50% was more sort of grounding people towards the earlier comments that we made about 20% or 30%. So I'd say we
componenttext: Well, it's a combination of Ted and I, so I'll pass it to Ted in a second, but I would say, we don't have a target. The 50 -- my comment about 50% was more sort of grounding people towards the earlier comments that we made about 20% or 30%. So I'd say we like what we see in terms of the engagement on our originals. So we're continuing to expand them. And so we're going to keep growing that. We don't have a magic target that we're trying to hit. It's more about continued expansion and that mix of our content, being more of originals and less of licensing, but we're still expanding both. Licensing content is still expanding. And then Ted, if you want to add to that.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I will say -- I would just say, to your point, the licensed business, while as a percentage of business will shrink, as an absolute number it will continue to grow for the next couple of years. And there isn't a magic target to David's point. What we want
componenttext: I will say -- I would just say, to your point, the licensed business, while as a percentage of business will shrink, as an absolute number it will continue to grow for the next couple of years. And there isn't a magic target to David's point. What we want to do is have really great compelling and differentiated programming for our members. And we get there through original programming when we do it successfully. So we just want to keep steering the business that way.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: And do you have any targets for the original content that is produced by your own studio in terms of the ratio that is ultimately produced by your own studio versus licensed originals?
componenttext: And do you have any targets for the original content that is produced by your own studio in terms of the ratio that is ultimately produced by your own studio versus licensed originals?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. Similarly, what we're trying not to do is get trapped in the business model to making creative choices, meaning that sometimes no one else owns the IP, and you want to do it right by the viewer by giving them great things to watch, and the only way to
componenttext: No. Similarly, what we're trying not to do is get trapped in the business model to making creative choices, meaning that sometimes no one else owns the IP, and you want to do it right by the viewer by giving them great things to watch, and the only way to do that is do it through a third-party licensed deal. Our financial preference, of course, is to produce it through our studios, and when that opportunity will continue to present itself, we're going to increasingly do that as well. But we're not locking into a formula of how much of the programming has to be self-produced versus third-party license.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Exactly.
componenttext: Exactly.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ted, it's -- let's stick with you here for a minute on the content side. Stranger Things and The Get Down, an interesting content examples over the summer that got a lot of attention. I believe The Get Down was quite expensive. It didn't seem to get the s
componenttext: Ted, it's -- let's stick with you here for a minute on the content side. Stranger Things and The Get Down, an interesting content examples over the summer that got a lot of attention. I believe The Get Down was quite expensive. It didn't seem to get the same-size audience as Stranger Things, which I believe was less expensive and attractive economics. Why when you look at The Get Down is that a good investment for you given the ticket size? And I think you've renewed it for a second season, what is that doing for your business that you might be missing or the popular press is missing?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: What's still to come is the second half of the first season, so that's still coming up. We're excited about how it got started. Yes, it's an expensive piece of television, mostly because it's very large-scale cinematic. The reason why Baz Luhrmann films w
componenttext: What's still to come is the second half of the first season, so that's still coming up. We're excited about how it got started. Yes, it's an expensive piece of television, mostly because it's very large-scale cinematic. The reason why Baz Luhrmann films work around the world is that it kind of attractiveness. So we're still seeing how it's going to unfold for the first season, and all of the shows land at a different level of noise in the press and probably depending on what circles you run in, whether or not your friends are talking about it. But we're really very excited about how the show's been performing, particularly in the quarter where we had 4 shows that turned out to be kind of big event programs for us.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: And you've commented before that sort of output deals and Pay 1 deals from a timing perspective are suboptimal, but at the same time, you said really nice things about Disney's product over the years and how they work on your platform. How is the Pay 1 de
componenttext: And you've commented before that sort of output deals and Pay 1 deals from a timing perspective are suboptimal, but at the same time, you said really nice things about Disney's product over the years and how they work on your platform. How is the Pay 1 deal performing versus expectations? Are you happy with it? I believe it's a relatively short-term deals, and then you think you'd like to do more of over time with Disney?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Look, and I think, we expect it to be a very popular content and it's turning out to be. So Zootopia was the first really high-profile film to come through, and it's performing in huge numbers because it's great kids viewing, beyond being great movie
componenttext: Yes. Look, and I think, we expect it to be a very popular content and it's turning out to be. So Zootopia was the first really high-profile film to come through, and it's performing in huge numbers because it's great kids viewing, beyond being great movie viewing. And the Disney brand are different than any other studio can deliver that kind of tent-pole kids programming that the family loves and as long as it continues to perform at those levels, we'd look to expand it with Disney. But I don't think any other studio can really match that output and match those economics, and therefore, deliver that viewing. So we're going to still look opportunistically. Our films are available for that window. But really continue to put energy behind our original film initiative as well.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: And in some countries, we have the Disney movie, I'll put Australia, Canada, U.S. But in other countries like in the U.K., we lost the bidding to Sky about 2 years ago. So it really varies by market. We're one of the bidders and we hope to over time, be o
componenttext: And in some countries, we have the Disney movie, I'll put Australia, Canada, U.S. But in other countries like in the U.K., we lost the bidding to Sky about 2 years ago. So it really varies by market. We're one of the bidders and we hope to over time, be one of the biggest bidders so they choose us, but it really does vary by market.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Reed, it's been speculated in the media that downloading off-line viewing may become available on Netflix by the end of 2016. Can you provide any insights or clarity on that speculation?
componenttext: Reed, it's been speculated in the media that downloading off-line viewing may become available on Netflix by the end of 2016. Can you provide any insights or clarity on that speculation?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, we said this year is we're open to it. It's something we're looking at. But we have nothing more specific to offer.
componenttext: Yes. Well, we said this year is we're open to it. It's something we're looking at. But we have nothing more specific to offer.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then secondly. Password sharing in the U.S., you have plans in place that limit that. Just interested still in the enforcement of password sharing in the U.S. in terms of limiting that currently and in the future. And then similarly, with VPN networks
componenttext: And then secondly. Password sharing in the U.S., you have plans in place that limit that. Just interested still in the enforcement of password sharing in the U.S. in terms of limiting that currently and in the future. And then similarly, with VPN networks within the international business, your views of that in terms of accessing content outside of countries that have certain geographic rights.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we've been very successful in finding technological ways of inhibiting the cross-border VPNs, which is roughly like I mentioned. We didn't win the bidding for the Disney movies in the U.K. so it's clearly not fair to allow our U.K. subscribe
componenttext: Well, I think we've been very successful in finding technological ways of inhibiting the cross-border VPNs, which is roughly like I mentioned. We didn't win the bidding for the Disney movies in the U.K. so it's clearly not fair to allow our U.K. subscribers to watch the Disney movies from Canada or to the U.S. And so we found with the help of the studio, some more technology to enforce their rights. And we tried to get global rights for everything like How To Get Away With Murder from ABC, because then it's available to everyone, which is clearly what consumers want. In terms of -- what was the other question you had?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's password sharing. Password sharing.
componenttext: It's password sharing. Password sharing.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: No plans on making any changes there. Password sharing is something you have to learn to live with because there's so much legitimate password sharing, like you sharing with your spouse, with your kids. So there's no bright line. And we're doing fine as i
componenttext: No plans on making any changes there. Password sharing is something you have to learn to live with because there's so much legitimate password sharing, like you sharing with your spouse, with your kids. So there's no bright line. And we're doing fine as is.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Reed, just sticking with the theme of Disney, Bob Iger made some interesting comments a couple of weeks ago, talking about how his bountiful group -- list of brands ABC, Pixar, Marvel, may not be enough in the future and that distribution -- figuring out
componenttext: Reed, just sticking with the theme of Disney, Bob Iger made some interesting comments a couple of weeks ago, talking about how his bountiful group -- list of brands ABC, Pixar, Marvel, may not be enough in the future and that distribution -- figuring out distribution was important to him. Do you have any reaction to that? Because it seems to be aimed at over the top, and he does have a relationship with Hulu, which is a potential -- a competitor or may be a bigger competitor over time. But do you have any reactions to those comments?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I mean, they may have a great strategy there. They've got Hulu. They've got the major league baseball initiative and they bought some of that. And then, of course, they've got DisneyLife, which they operate in a number of countries. So it makes a ton
componenttext: No, I mean, they may have a great strategy there. They've got Hulu. They've got the major league baseball initiative and they bought some of that. And then, of course, they've got DisneyLife, which they operate in a number of countries. So it makes a ton of sense for them to be growing in the OTT side and to figure that out as it does for us to do content. I think you'll see more -- you saw CBS All Access in the last 2 years, really become a big focus for CBS. So it's just continuation of that theme.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Ted, just somewhat related here, I realize this is a hypothetical. But access to content, it's a big debate for Netflix. And I'm curious if you thought being part of a larger media company would inhibit your ability to acquire content from others in t
componenttext: And Ted, just somewhat related here, I realize this is a hypothetical. But access to content, it's a big debate for Netflix. And I'm curious if you thought being part of a larger media company would inhibit your ability to acquire content from others in the industry who are competitors for that kind of company?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. Like I said in previous quarters, this kind of frenemy model has existed for decades in television where 2 competing studios produce for one another constantly. And it's really the question, I think, that our suppliers want to make when they're making
componenttext: No. Like I said in previous quarters, this kind of frenemy model has existed for decades in television where 2 competing studios produce for one another constantly. And it's really the question, I think, that our suppliers want to make when they're making decisions around their expansion over the top is, can they make better returns selling to Netflix, or building their own thing? And that's both a long-term and a short-term question than currently hypothetical.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Reed, just following up on competitor comments. Jeff Bezos, recently made a comment that possibly,  Amazon video could be the fourth pillar of Amazon's business. And I was just wondering how you think about, you have such an extensive lead in this global
componenttext: Reed, just following up on competitor comments. Jeff Bezos, recently made a comment that possibly,  Amazon video could be the fourth pillar of Amazon's business. And I was just wondering how you think about, you have such an extensive lead in this global build out. How you think about Amazon long term as a competitor and Mr. Bezos' comments there?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we think about it as share of screen time. And when people are doing other things with their screens be they mobile or television screens, they're not doing Netflix. So Snapchat, YouTube, Facebook video, all of that is -- takes a lot of hours, proba
componenttext: Well, we think about it as share of screen time. And when people are doing other things with their screens be they mobile or television screens, they're not doing Netflix. So Snapchat, YouTube, Facebook video, all of that is -- takes a lot of hours, probably much more so than Amazon. But there are so many competitors out there for screen time and we win today such a small percentage of total screen time that moves by specific competitors are unlikely to have a material effect. What affects us is can we continue to win affection? And that's through doing all of this incredible content through expanding globally, having all those rights be global eventually, so those are the things we're focused on.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: And David, you commented in the letter about going to market for acquiring more debt on incoming weeks. You also mentioned at a conference recently that you thought the business was under levered. You mentioned a 5%, I think debt-to-cap ratio. How do you
componenttext: And David, you commented in the letter about going to market for acquiring more debt on incoming weeks. You also mentioned at a conference recently that you thought the business was under levered. You mentioned a 5%, I think debt-to-cap ratio. How do you think about debt longer term in terms of what that looks like? And how you think about it? Is it net debt-to-EBITDA or otherwise?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, my comments at the Goldman Sachs conference about a 20% debt rate or a long-term optimization and cost to capital. I don't think we're talking about by the end of the year, getting to a 20% leverage ratio. So just to talk about sort of a shorter term
componenttext: Yes, my comments at the Goldman Sachs conference about a 20% debt rate or a long-term optimization and cost to capital. I don't think we're talking about by the end of the year, getting to a 20% leverage ratio. So just to talk about sort of a shorter term or a medium term, we would be looking to raise as needed in terms of funding our content expansion. So we've been pretty clear along the year that we would go to market sometime this year to add a modest amount of debt to the balance sheet. And then do that on a recurring basis as needed to fund our content expansion. So over time, though, we anticipate that we could get and would optimize our cost of capital up to a 20% leverage ratio. And we're talking about a debt-to-market cap at that point, but I think we would be closer to EBITDA basis as well because the business is going to be growing in operating income and EBITDA.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, you guys recently localized your first batch of Rest of World markets. I believe it was Poland and Turkey. And it sounds like that's been successful in driving growth in those markets. I guess, the obvious question would be, why not move faster on
componenttext: David, you guys recently localized your first batch of Rest of World markets. I believe it was Poland and Turkey. And it sounds like that's been successful in driving growth in those markets. I guess, the obvious question would be, why not move faster on localization? You've got a lot of recent Rest of World launches. Is that a cost-benefit analysis or human bandwidth sort of throttle? What is keeping you from moving quicker? And what's the right pace for us to think about '17?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: It move faster. I think it's a quality aspect, right? In terms of we want to make sure that we have an eye towards quality as well. We had a couple of rough blog entries about some of our localization and subtitling in some markets that we pay attention t
componenttext: It move faster. I think it's a quality aspect, right? In terms of we want to make sure that we have an eye towards quality as well. We had a couple of rough blog entries about some of our localization and subtitling in some markets that we pay attention to those. So we're moving as quickly as we can being methodical and thoughtful about those opportunities to localize. And yes, we are pleased with both Poland and Turkey in terms of those impacts. It makes sense that people want to consume in their language. So it's not going to make sense to localize in a super-small territory. But for the larger territories, it's going to make sense. And even for the medium-sized territories. We'll get there eventually. I think it's just a matter of sequencing.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just to come back to maybe more of the short term. You had talked earlier this year about Australia and New Zealand being a difficult comp, I do believe in Q2. You called out in a letter Q4 comp of Spain, Portugal, Italy. Is there anyway to kind of pu
componenttext: And just to come back to maybe more of the short term. You had talked earlier this year about Australia and New Zealand being a difficult comp, I do believe in Q2. You called out in a letter Q4 comp of Spain, Portugal, Italy. Is there anyway to kind of put that fourth quarter comp in the second quarter comp in some kind of context just to be maybe taking an order of magnitude.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, again, back to the Reed's earlier comments about for competitive reasons we don't talk specifics about our market, I probably wouldn't. But I would say that there is a harvesting of demand initially when we launch in the market. It's that first-laun
componenttext: Well, again, back to the Reed's earlier comments about for competitive reasons we don't talk specifics about our market, I probably wouldn't. But I would say that there is a harvesting of demand initially when we launch in the market. It's that first-launch quarter that we tend to have higher net additions and then that moderates over time into sort of a run rate that's a little bit more normalized. We have the same thing going on that we highlighted in Q1 where we have Rest of World in the first quarter of this year, was a large number. And when I look at Wall Street's estimates for Q1, they're higher, I think. They're not taking that into account. So we wanted to call that out so that folks had the benefit of anticipating that.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Any other Wall Street estimates you'd like to call out?
componenttext: Any other Wall Street estimates you'd like to call out?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a growing operating income and just the fact that I think Q1 was a little high relative to our expectations.
componenttext: Just a growing operating income and just the fact that I think Q1 was a little high relative to our expectations.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ted, as you look at localized content and new markets. How easy or difficult is it to find the talent in those markets to produce the content? How successful have you been there? And along that same topic, how do you think about some of these newer market
componenttext: Ted, as you look at localized content and new markets. How easy or difficult is it to find the talent in those markets to produce the content? How successful have you been there? And along that same topic, how do you think about some of these newer markets in terms of how much of that content ultimately, will need to be localized to create that S-curve inflection in some of the markets that were launched in 2016?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: So in terms of successes to date. Club de Cuervos, our first Mexican original, was quite successful and we're getting ready to bring out the second season. Marseille for our French customers, not only successful in France but successful throughout Europe
componenttext: So in terms of successes to date. Club de Cuervos, our first Mexican original, was quite successful and we're getting ready to bring out the second season. Marseille for our French customers, not only successful in France but successful throughout Europe and got a significant amount of watching in the United States subtitled and dubbed in English. And so we're continuing to push. It's not degrees of difficulties. It's just a matter of understanding the production community and the local taste and who's working and making great films in those markets in some cases and are anxious to make the migration to television that they've been seeing happening in the U.S. And so it's difficult in terms of not being on the ground there usually. But I think we're making trade-offs in terms of the company culture to travel our folks into territory, get to know the folks in the markets, work with the best and brightest filmmakers and television creators, and bring their shows to the global markets through Netflix. And in terms of localizing for taste. In many parts of the world, U.S. content or English-speaking content localize in the local languages have been incredibly successful. In some places where taste run much more local like Japan, like India, we certainly will take more of a local approach in terms of licensing and producing more local language content there as well. But I think over time that the taste will fall into line with the kind of desire to see the big spectacular shows that people are talking about around the world no matter where you are.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Ted, maybe you can give us some color on Dark Svoda [ph], Cable Girls in terms of being content that may spread beyond their home market.
componenttext: And Ted, maybe you can give us some color on Dark Svoda [ph], Cable Girls in terms of being content that may spread beyond their home market.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, absolutely. What we're trying to do, we're producing -- to Reed's point, we're producing a show right now that just went into production literally today called Dark in Germany, and it's with quite a successful filmmaker whose films have traveled arou
componenttext: Yes, absolutely. What we're trying to do, we're producing -- to Reed's point, we're producing a show right now that just went into production literally today called Dark in Germany, and it's with quite a successful filmmaker whose films have traveled around the world. We've been in the business of buying though films from those film makers and making them travel around the world for years. So I think that will continue with the move into multi-episodic series as well. So we get that scale advantage of being able to take a German show that the German audiences will be very excited about and that we know that, that will expand throughout Europe and that we've been really great at finding audiences even in the U.S. and subtitles and dubs, which has been really a niche business for most people but very mainstream numbers for us.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Going back to David's comment about the difficult first quarter comp internationally. You had 130 markets that launched at the beginning of 2016, so it's obvious what the comp issue is. But also in your business, you have that initial wave but then you ha
componenttext: Going back to David's comment about the difficult first quarter comp internationally. You had 130 markets that launched at the beginning of 2016, so it's obvious what the comp issue is. But also in your business, you have that initial wave but then you have things like localized content, awareness and other factors that actually drive as an example in the Latin American market, an inflection that happened 2 to 3 years after the initial launch. So as we look at 1Q '17, and then think about the 130 new markets, how do we think about that initial bump relative to the potential of these new markets actually beginning to really kick in throughout the year in '17?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, as you say, they do -- one is going positive in terms of growth in growth and one is negative in terms of initial launch. What I was trying to call out without actually providing our Q1 guidance until January was back in January of this year, which
componenttext: Well, as you say, they do -- one is going positive in terms of growth in growth and one is negative in terms of initial launch. What I was trying to call out without actually providing our Q1 guidance until January was back in January of this year, which I tried to moderate the estimates or the expectations coming out of our global launch, we had a very successful launch. In Q1, we had a lot of demand associated with that launch that started moderating into Q2. And I think people saw the success of Q1, and really raised their numbers in Q2, and I'm trying to get a little bit ahead of that in the sense that we had a very successful launch in Q1 of this year that is going to be very difficult to replicate. Some of that was pent-up demand, and we're not going to be able to do that. That's not saying that we're -- many of our other markets are growing in terms of the growth. It's just right now, in terms of what we see that large launch is not going to -- is going to overwhelm some of the growth in the other markets. So we still like what we're seeing in these markets. We're growing year-on-year in some. Some are moderate. We've had very different -- a wide variety of results across markets. We've had markets that slowdown and then accelerate in growth. And so if you abstract back, I think, the general trend is the world is embracing Internet television, and we're riding on a very strong kind of tailwind of technological change. And that is definitely intact.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, any color on how the 2014 markets are ramping? Or at least France and Germany in particular, I think there's some concern in the marketplace that France isn't going well, I think you closed an office there. And in Germany, Amazon seems to be doing
componenttext: David, any color on how the 2014 markets are ramping? Or at least France and Germany in particular, I think there's some concern in the marketplace that France isn't going well, I think you closed an office there. And in Germany, Amazon seems to be doing quite well. So can you just talk about how the model may or may not be working well in those 2014 markets?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me disconnect one thing there in terms of we did choose to consolidate some of our French staff into our Amsterdam staff, but that had nothing to do with the market whether the market was growing or not. That had everything to do with the synergy of c
componenttext: Let me disconnect one thing there in terms of we did choose to consolidate some of our French staff into our Amsterdam staff, but that had nothing to do with the market whether the market was growing or not. That had everything to do with the synergy of communication and how the teams are working together. And then in terms of the other market, again, we don't say much specifically about our markets for competitive reasons. But you would have to take my earlier comment about the fact that we saw very broad sort of outperformance relative to expectations in this quarter or in Q3 that will be inclusive of those markets. So I think we're pleased with how things are going.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Shifting gears. Back to you, Ted. You hired -- I'm hoping pronouncing this right, Bela Bajaria, from NBC recently, and one of her mandates is unscripted. So I'm just wondering is unscripted going from something that you have a couple of that's in t
componenttext: Great. Shifting gears. Back to you, Ted. You hired -- I'm hoping pronouncing this right, Bela Bajaria, from NBC recently, and one of her mandates is unscripted. So I'm just wondering is unscripted going from something that you have a couple of that's in to something more strategic for you? When you think about 600 hours to 1,000, how much is unscripted driving growth? Is it a material plan for next year? And why?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's not a material part for next year, but I imagine it could be -- it will be growing over the next several years. It's been -- it's an area of viewing that people around the world enjoy. The content travels well. It's efficient to produce. The current
componenttext: It's not a material part for next year, but I imagine it could be -- it will be growing over the next several years. It's been -- it's an area of viewing that people around the world enjoy. The content travels well. It's efficient to produce. The current sources of second window unscripted programming are under a great deal of pressure from the cable operators not to sell their content to -- off of their own universe because many of the episode seem to be interchangeable. So being able to have a good steady flow of high-quality unscripted programming is something we want to focus on because I think we can do it well and efficiently and may be an elevated in a way that it would travel even more than it does today.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just if I can follow up quickly on unscripted. It would seem to be not obvious for the on-demand binging consumption model. But maybe you've had some experience so far with some of your talk stuff or your comedies that maybe suggest it is. I don't kno
componenttext: And just if I can follow up quickly on unscripted. It would seem to be not obvious for the on-demand binging consumption model. But maybe you've had some experience so far with some of your talk stuff or your comedies that maybe suggest it is. I don't know, what can you tell us about that?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: There's certainly some benefits from the scale off of those shows. But our ability to produce -- maybe we have a lot of data and a lot of content that gets watched and what travels and what doesn't, what gets repeated and what doesn't. It gives us the hig
componenttext: There's certainly some benefits from the scale off of those shows. But our ability to produce -- maybe we have a lot of data and a lot of content that gets watched and what travels and what doesn't, what gets repeated and what doesn't. It gives us the higher degree of confidence today than we had a couple of years ago and our ability or even desire to produce in the space, but it is a segment of programming. We keep opening up new segments of programming, the way we did with talk shows last year. The way we will -- in the first quarter with Ultimate Beastmaster, our first competition show. So we're pressing into some new areas of the business all the time to bring new, unique elevated and differentiated program into our members.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Reed, investors get caught up a lot in the 60 million to 90 million household number in the U.S. And as an indicator or predictor for success in international markets, over time, if you can do it in the U.S., you can do it internationally; and if you can'
componenttext: Reed, investors get caught up a lot in the 60 million to 90 million household number in the U.S. And as an indicator or predictor for success in international markets, over time, if you can do it in the U.S., you can do it internationally; and if you can't, you can't. You're running a little north of 4 million subscribers in 2016 from 5 million in 2015. How do you think about that business in terms of the trajectory over, say, the next 1, 3, 5 years in terms of how many subs that you can put on the business in the U.S. on an annual basis?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have to take it year by year. It depends on how well we execute. Do we have more Stranger Things, where it breaks through, and everyone feels like they got to get in, Luke Cage, Get Down, Narcos. We have a show coming up The Crown that some of the most
componenttext: We have to take it year by year. It depends on how well we execute. Do we have more Stranger Things, where it breaks through, and everyone feels like they got to get in, Luke Cage, Get Down, Narcos.
